Bill presented by Mr Martin.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Public Service (Parliamentary Departments) Amendment Bill 1996 proposes to abolish the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Joint House Department and the parliamentary service heads of those departments and to create a new department—the Department of Parliamentary Services—with one head.

BREAK.PARA: As honourable members will recall, during the last parliament an all‐party advisory committee was commissioned to inquire into and report on the creation of one department to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Department of the Parliamentary Library. On 24 November 1993, I, as Speaker, presented a bill to give effect to this measure, which was agreed to by this House but which, for a number of reasons, was bogged down in the Senate. Since the change of government, there has been a frenzied atmosphere of cost‐cutting in public expenditure. I invite honourable members to take one step further than the 1993 bill and endorse the combination of all departments serving the parliament, except for the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate, which are most desirably separate on a constitutional basis.

The amalgamation would represent a recognition of the attitude previously adopted by the Presiding Officers and the then Minister for Finance that the Senate department, the House of Representatives department and the three service departments were separate entities for budgetary purposes.

In a period of increasing emphasis on micro‐economic reform, when the Public Service is being called upon to increase efficiency, it is impossible to justify the pinnacle of the democratic system, the legislature, being served by a system the origins of which are in the beginning of this century and which has not kept pace with the demands of modern times. This bill will send a streamlined structure into the next century.

The benefits from corporate services alone, including the financial benefits, will be approximately $1½ million a year at 1996 prices. The benefits will not only be in financial services and in financial savings. Not only will services to senators and members not be diminished but there is every indication that they will in fact improve. There will be improvement in the delivery of information services with the Parliamentary Library, Hansard, the Parliamentary Information Systems Office, the Sound and Vision Office, the guide service, et cetera, all operating as separate client service programs and all supported by a single administrative and corporate management structure.

Physical and information support will be delivered under the one structure. It is envisaged that the Library Committee and the Joint House Committee of the parliament will continue, as will the Presiding Officers' advisory groups, so that members and senators will continue to have an input.

Mr Speaker, I call on both you and the President not to proceed with filling the position of the Parliamentary Librarian, which is currently vacant. This is a perfect opportunity to save immediately one position. If this bill is turned into an act, then obviously this will occasion the first of many savings. I call upon both government and opposition members to support this initiative and to give it speedy passage through not only this House but also the Senate.

Mr Speaker, I know that you in your new role understand that, as you embrace the responsibilities which you have—virtually as a minister—for a number of parliamentary departments, you will be subjected to pressures from government in looking at ways in which savings can be introduced across the whole range of the parliamentary structures that we have here. I think one of the easiest ways for you to tackle this problem would be to throw your wholehearted support behind this bill. In my view, it in no way will diminish the service which we as members and senators will receive. In fact, it will enhance that service. The argument that was run by Liberal‐National Party senators at the behest of others on the Senate side of this building in 1993 when this particular bill was proposed can be dismissed as nonsense.

At a time when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has stood in this parliament and called for micro-economic reform, called for efficiencies to be gained, called for enhanced business practices and called for improvements in bottom lines, this is one way in which this can occur. I commend the bill to the House, and I seek leave to present the explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Monday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) celebrates 1996 marking the 75th anniversary of Edith Cowan entering the Western Australian Parliament;
(2) acknowledges that Edith Cowan was the first woman to enter any Australian parliament;
(3) congratulates the largest contingent of women parliamentarians ever to enter the federal Parliament, formed from the 1996 federal election;
(4) recognises that the majority of these new parliamentarians enter Parliament on their own abilities without the need of a quota system; and
(5) encourages more female Australians to enter the service of their country by active participation within the political process.

Edith Cowan OBE died in 1932. At the time of her death, after 71 years, she could possibly have been considered the most significant woman in our nation's history, and certainly her impact in Western Australia was profound. Recently the Australian published the top 100 most influential women in the world. I believe some half a dozen Australian women were listed. If Edith Cowan were alive today, she would no doubt be listed in the top 20 internationally and ranked well ahead of any of the Australian women listed.

Mrs Cowan was the great defender of social equity. Contrary to some of the recent social equity debate leaders, she not only spoke about it but also acted upon it. I believe she would have rejected many of the modern activists because rhetoric does not meet their reality. Edith Cowan was a woman of action.

She is best remembered as the first woman to enter any Australian parliament. This year marks the 75th anniversary of her electoral success. How pleasing then that the 75th anniversary of her entry into parliament should also celebrate the biggest entry of women into the Australian federal parliament. Mrs Cowan would have been very pleased. She quoted Scriptures in her maiden speech when referring to the need for more women in parliament. She said, `It is not good for man to be alone.' She also said, `Men need a reminder, that a woman beside them could achieve great things for humanity and the home.'

She nominated the poorly constructed State Children's Court Act and the expenditure of government funds in the development of government buildings as prime examples of her motivation to join parliament. At 60 years of age Edith Cowan was not young when she joined parliament, yet her extensive reputation for community service already preceded her.

She was born in 1861 near Geraldton. Her mother died in childbirth. Her father was later hanged for the murder of her stepmother. Although these tragedies affected her to the extent of her becoming quite a loner, she most certainly made up for it with her service to the community. She was committed to social reforms which enhanced women's dignity and responsibility. She was also committed to reform for the care of mothers and children.

She married James Cowan in 1879 and had four children. Although her social position became secure by her husband's appointment as Registrar and Master of the Supreme Court, she was able to appreciate the wider society's problems and work towards resolving many of these issues.

Mrs Cowan dedicated herself to voluntary work. She was the inaugural Secretary and later President of the Karrakatta Club. She was a state education advocate and served on the North Fremantle Education Board, one of the few public offices open to women at that time. She worked for the Ministering Children's League and the House of Mercy for Unmarried Mothers. She was a foundation member of the Children's Protection Society. She pioneered day nursing for working mothers in 1909.

She was the first woman appointed to the bench of the Children's Court. She was a justice of the peace and constantly urged the appointment of more women to these positions. She was the initiator of the Women's Service Guild. Through this membership as the guild's vice-president, she was part of the lobbying and fundraising processes, which realised the opening of the King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women in Perth in 1916. She was secretary of the hospital's advisory board.

She was prominent in the creation of the Western Australian National Council of Women and was president until she entered parliament and vice-president until her death. She was a foundation member of co‐freemasonry. She was the first female member of the Anglican Social Questions Committee and a coopted member of the Synod from 1923. She was an Australian delegate to the Seventh International Conference of Women. She was the co-founder of the Western Australian Historical Society and was active in the planning of the centennial celebrations in 1929. In 1920 she was appointed OBE for her social work and her work during the war years. Mr Speaker, I am sure you would agree that Edith Cowan was one great Australian.

Until her death she led a group of forceful, articulate women who made the Western Australian women's movement a model for others to follow. While she shared the movement's concern for purity, temperance and ameliorative social work, she also provided rational analysis of issues and an austere dedication—not quotas, but dedication.

Edith Cowan spoke many times in parliament on many issues. She championed migrant welfare, infant health centres, women's rights and sex education in state schools. She was convinced of the necessity of a motherhood endowment and defended the idea of a housewives union. She introduced a private member's bill—the Women's Legal Status Act—in 1923 which opened the legal profession to women.

Edith Cowan was in parliament for only three years. She was of the opinion that she belonged to a non-party organisation, being the Nationalist Party. She voted on issues rather than along party lines. She said in her maiden speech that she would be responsible only to her constituents. She also said:
There are too many here today who are possessed of the old party spirit, which seems ever to exist, but I cannot see why we should drag party into things that concern the whole of the state.
She was a very wise woman. Edith Cowan was a remarkable woman. A view of her first speech shows that she canvassed many issues. On the deficit, she said:
We all regret the country is obliged to debt . . . We certainly have a large one and it will be a bad day for us if it should suddenly be called up from Europe or elsewhere.
I wonder what she thinks of today's debt. On industrial relations, she said:

Many a strike would be prevented if the women had the right to vote . . . It is unfair that a strike could be called simply at the word of mainly single men, when they would be far better off without a strike.
That is a unique concept worthy of further discussion nowadays, considering family impacts, et cetera. On migration, she said:
It is necessary that we select the right type of immigrant . . . The very best type of immigrant are our children.

Mr Speaker, as you can see, Mrs Cowan was a woman with a social justice message, if her first speech is anything to go by. Edith Cowan did not need the help of her party. Edith Cowan did not need the help of her position. Edith Cowan did not need a quota. Edith Cowan achieved what she achieved on merit. She ended her maiden speech, and let me also end my speech, by saying:

If men and women can work for the state side by side and represent all sections of the community and if the male members of the House would be satisfied to allow women to help them and would accept their suggestions when they are offered, I cannot doubt that we should do very much better work in the community than was ever done before.

I want members to recollect when speaking and thinking of these things that we should all be wiser if we realised the truth of Kipling's lines: there are nine and sixty ways of constructing tribal laws. And every single one of them is right.

We do not always remember this principle. People are apt to think that the point of view of men only must be right for men, whilst women think that the point of view of women only must be right for women. That of course does not necessarily follow.

What we should aim at is to get via the media, so that we may work side by side, the women working along with the men and thus there will come to us "self knowledge, self reverence and self control, for these three alone lead men to sovereign heights" and to the achievement of those aims which should be sought by all parliaments . . . the peace and happiness of those for when they legislate.

Edith Cowan was a great Australian. She has been recognised this year, the 75th anniversary of her election to parliament, with the inclusion of her picture on top of the $50 note. I am both proud and very humbled to stand in this place representing a seat in her name on the 75th anniversary of her election to parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to commend Edith Cowan. She is a great Western Australian. She has been one of our forebears in ensuring that women are in this parliament, as in many others. It was in 1920 that legislation was first passed in Western Australia to allow women to stand for our parliament. Edith Cowan was elected soon after that, in 1921, as the member for West Perth. I disagree with some of the observations made by the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) about her standing aside from the party system. Although she did that in the parliament, she paid a price: she lost her seat as a result of the combined efforts of the two major parties. So I think she learned, to her sorrow, that status had a cost.

SPEECH.PARA: Edith Cowan was born near Geraldton—indeed, my home territory. She was the daughter of a pastoralist, and her mother was a energetic educator—something that influenced Edith Cowan for all her life. Sadly, her mother died when she was but seven and, as we have heard, her father was hanged for the murder of his second wife—something that must have been a very sad outcome for Edith Cowan. She had to overcome some adverse publicity. The fact that she did is considerable testament to her courage and determination—something I think all women would say is necessary in public life even today.

Edith Cowan spent a lifetime dedicated to improving the situation of women, children and families generally. She was interested in those less fortunate than herself. She was apparently a very powerful and persuasive public speaker. She had a very significant public life well before she entered parliament. She was a member of many committees and organisations and, indeed, the founder of a great number.

Within the community, one of her major aims was for wider participation of women in public life and in policy formation. She promoted and fought for the vote for women, which was achieved in 1899. She was something of a beneficiary of that in 1921, as we have heard, but she fought for it anyway. She thought it was important for women not to be behind the throne but on it whenever that was possible to achieve.

As we have heard, she also made a very significant contribution to education and was particularly keen on ensuring that government schools were properly funded. She was also interested in tertiary education and an advocate for women achieving that level of education. Indeed, she worked tirelessly to raise funds for scholarships for Western Australian students, who at that time needed to go out of the state to get an education. In the end she got government support for her proposals, her various scholarship fundraising enterprises.

Edith Cowan was also a member of the District Education Board of North Fremantle. Again, I am pleased to underline that because that is where I live and part of the constituency I represent. She was one of the first women delegates at the first conference of the Boards of Education in 1911.

The importance of all these characteristics is that Cowan regarded education as a necessity, especially for women. It was not simply a nice gloss to be put on for a polite society. She thought it was absolutely essential that, if women were ever to be taken seriously, they had to be well educated. It was one of the reasons we named the university `Edith Cowan University' when I was in government. Edith Cowan University is the result of the amalgamation of various teachers colleges, or CAEs as they became.

There was some resistance when the Labor government which I led put forward that proposal. Some said it was not appropriate to name a university after a woman who had not taken advantage, or not been able to take advantage, of tertiary education. In fact, quite the reverse is true: she was very worthy indeed, given the efforts that she made. I am delighted that it still remains the pre-eminent university with a woman's name—the only one, as I understand it.

It is important for us to recognise today that Edith Cowan fought battles that still need to be fought. While we might congratulate the Liberal members opposite and the National Party for an increase in the number of women on their side of parliament, and I do, I also advise against complacency. We need only to look at the reduced numbers on our side to see why. I remind members of the House, particularly the women, that from 1980 to 1995 women on our side consistently outnumbered the conservatives, in the House of Representatives at least. We also went to the polls in 1996 with a comparable number of women candidates. A major swing produced a move: we lost women; you gained them. The net improvement is not very great. So whenever we see those nationwide swings we will see women going in and out with the tide, unless they are cemented into safe seats and they are not all sitting in marginals.

Liberal members opposite would know—I am sure they have looked at their own figures—that a good number of their female members, seven of them, would disappear with a swing of less than three per cent. Most of them would go with a swing of less than five per cent. I do not particularly want to see that, although I certainly want us to return to government. I would rather see more women remain every time there is a change of government.

It is important to recognise—and we certainly want to make sure it is—that Labor women and the Democrats have generally led the debate on greater numbers of women in public life. I hope the members opposite, in particular the new women members, will contribute to that debate and help to set the agenda. I am sure that is what they want. They will know the problems of fighting in a marginal seat—not only of the risk of losing the seat but also of having to work extremely hard to maintain it. So, even if women around the country are in a parliament and in a marginal seat, they often have to put in extra effort. They have to put that much more time into their constituency. They cannot be away sitting on committees. They cannot be making sure that their point of view is in the policy of their parties to the same extent as if they were in safer seats. That puts them at greater risk when it comes to promotions and getting into cabinets, ministries and so on. So we are not there by any means.

I know there has been criticism from those opposite of our quota system. We thought it was important not to promote women against merit but to recognise that, if merit principles operated, 50 per cent of us here would be women. We have to recognise that there is still a lot militating against the participation of women in public life today. We set a realistic time frame for our 35 per cent quota. It was not yesterday or tomorrow; it is the year 2002. We want to cement women into safe seats so that those problems I mentioned of being in marginal seats do not apply.

The quota has already been reached in some of our state parliaments, particularly in the lead-up to the next round of elections. The problems we have are principally here in the House of Representatives and in a couple of states such as Queensland and New South Wales. I think it is also important to look not only at the representation of women in public life but also at what women might seek to achieve. I take the example of Edith Cowan. She was very clear that she was there in part, although not wholly, to improve the status and standing of all women. She was interested in industrial relations, and she was interested in education.

PARA.BREAK: Women need to strongly represent the interests of women. It can be done by proxy, as we have seen by the member for Cowan speaking on behalf of a great woman. But it is better if we do it directly, if we do it ourselves. I want to mention a couple of areas where I think women in this parliament should stand up and comment and, where appropriate, criticise. I hope women on the government side will do so also. I want to mention the negative impact of the industrial relations proposals on women. There is no doubt that a lot of the proposals that have been put forward by the new government will be detrimental to women. They will be detri mental to low wage, low skilled workers with poor union representation. And, unfortunately, that describes a great many women in our society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that, because those contracts will be secret, it will be very difficult to know what is happening. We have these kinds of agreements in Western Australia. There is a lot of similarity between what is proposed at the federal level and what is going on in Western Australia, where women's wages have fallen behind in the last little while. The most recent figures from Western Australia show that Western Australian males earn above the national average. The seasonally adjusted average weekly ordinary time earnings for Western Australian males are $748.20 compared with the national average of $705. When you turn to women, the reverse is true. The national average weekly earnings for women are $586 whereas Western Australian women earn $570. That is a gap of nearly $200, and it is worse than the average for Australia as a whole. What that signifies to me is that those minimum standards which we have come to expect through the award system have already been eroded.

I am also very clearly opposed to the removal from the Industrial Relations Commission of the power to examine examples where there is not equal remuneration. The government's proposal will mean that only equal pay can be looked at and not overaward entitlements. We know that very often that is where the big gap occurs. They are just a couple of examples about which I hope the women in this House will speak out. I also hope they will speak out against cuts to education.

PARA.BREAK: It has been mooted that there will be substantial cuts to tertiary education in the amounts available and perhaps greater impositions of HECS on some students. The impact on women will be great. They are the ones who have benefited from an extension of the number of places and a reduction in costs. We change that at our peril. It is not good enough to have more women in this House if they are not able to prevent those sorts of changes, which are inimical to the long‐term interests of women. I certainly urge the women mem bers opposite to speak as women on these matters and not as members of their party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) for taking the initiative in presenting this motion to the House today. It is entirely appropriate that we mark the 75th year of the first woman, Edith Cowan, entering an Australian parliament. Edith Cowan entered the Western Australian parliament some 27 years after South Australia became the first place in the world to simultaneously grant women the right to vote and to stand for parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1921, when Edith Cowan defeated a sitting member, she campaigned on her record for community service, law and order, and on the need for women in parliament to `nag a little on social issues'. During her time in parliament Edith Cowan promoted migrant welfare, sex education in state schools, infant health centres and women's rights. She also argued that a woman should be legally entitled to a share of her husband's income. It is also worth noting that Vida Goldstein was the first woman to attempt to enter federal parliament when she stood for the Senate in 1903. But it was not until 1943 that Enid Lyons was elected to this House and Dorothy Tangney took her seat in the other place. Vida Goldstein is on the record in 1911 as saying:
You will find there is a great tendency to regard everything affecting women as a side issue.
Dame Enid Lyons commenced her maiden speech by saying:

It would be strange indeed were I not to‐night deeply conscious of the fact, if not a little awed by the knowledge, that on my shoulders rests a great weight of responsibility, because this is the first occasion upon which a woman has addressed this House. For that reason it is an occasion which for every woman in the Commonwealth marks in some degree a turning point in history. I am well aware that, as I acquit myself in the work that I have undertaken for the next three years, so shall I either prejudice or enhance the prospects of those women who may wish to follow me in public service in the years to come.
She goes on to say that she understands `many honourable members have viewed the advent of women to the legislative halls with something approaching alarm'.

BREAK.PARA: Prior to the recent election, the Liberal Party had 11 women in the federal parliament—six in the other place and five members of the House of Representatives. Now the number of women has increased to 26—eight in the Senate and 17 in this place. In this chamber 23 per cent of my Liberal colleagues are women, and they all know that they came here on merit and not because of a quota. I take some satisfaction in South Australia's representation in this place. Of 12 seats, the Liberal Party holds 10, and of those 10 women hold four.

Like the member for Cowan, I congratulate the record number of women who came to this place after the recent federal election, noting that the ALP has four; the National Party brings its first woman to this chamber; there is one Independent; and that I have 16 Liberal colleagues. I wish them all well.

But we still need more women in this place. Labor's failure shows that its quota system does not work. Quotas were accepted as policy and then ignored and became just one more political stunt. The Australian public has become very cynical about political stunts. If the ALP had been truly committed to increasing women's representation in this place, it would have brought Mary Easson back via the former Prime Minister's electorate of Blaxland. But only two days ago a Labor man was preselected.

The Liberal approach has been different. Guidelines have been written and the Liberal Women's Forum has been established with the specific purpose of encouraging and assisting women into parliament and giving them the opportunity to attend training seminars. The member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash), the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) and the member for Hughes (Ms Vale), along with Senator-elect Helen Coonan, are all graduates of the New South Wales Liberal Women's Forum.

We will all be different, and we will all have our different styles. But for my own part, I say that we should remember that the public is looking for better behaviour in this place and that we remember Dame Enid Lyons's first speech because, until there are more of us, we still have to perform well so that others will be encouraged to follow. While giving the people in our electorates strong, sensitive and sensible representation, we will also have to ensure that Vida Goldstein's fears are no longer founded and that issues affecting women are not just seen as side issues. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and join him in acknowledging the unprecedented number of women members in the parliament. I would like to add my congratulations, along with those of the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), to every new woman member in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As a woman and a mother of young children, I think I have some idea of the efforts that have been necessary by all the female members of parliament to actually achieve office—in a marginal seat as well. However, mere presence in larger than normal numbers in the chamber is not enough. This government has clearly demonstrated, already, that it has embarked upon a course of action whose outcomes will fundamentally erode the quality of the lives of women in Australia.

During the terms of previous Labor governments, policies were implemented in many areas that made things better for women. Labor's subsidised child-care policies recognised that many women—now the vast majority of women—wish to continue with careers or as family breadwinners and enabled large numbers of women to rejoin the work force with considerable child‐care support. Labor's industrial relations policies have also made fundamental differences to women's lives. People in Australia now expect that women carrying out the same work as men would be paid an equal wage—something that I am sure would be supported, certainly on this side of the chamber. Most people would also expect that anyone in a workplace would get a fair go. This is an attitude that has grown largely as a result of the work of the Industrial Relations Commission.

But now this government proposes to weaken the powers of the commission. Not only will this seriously threaten the conditions already won for women workers but also it will make it nearly impossible to reach a position of full equality because much more needs to be done. Women still earn only half the overaward wage payments of men. The tendency will be exacerbated where the discretion is left to the employer. Labor gave the commission power to address this issue of overaward payments. It also planned to look at the value of women's traditional skills through the equal remuneration provisions which drew on the ILO convention regarding equal pay. That too is about to go out the door.

One of the traditional areas of work for women has of course been in the role of carer. Labor's policies toward the elderly and disabled recognised that women traditionally have played and taken the role of carer and we provided considerable support for women in those roles. The number of people—mostly women—employed in these important areas has grown enormously over the last 10 years. But now we find that most of these gains for women are at risk. What will be the effect on the working conditions of women in child-care centres and homes for the aged if the role of the commission in dispute settling is removed? I think that is something that those opposite should think about. They will have nowhere to go. Women will be caught and exploited by their desire to provide care.

What will be the effect on family life of this government's proposed changes to the nature of part-time work? Working hours will be changeable at the whim of the employer and thus quite unpredictable. When hours are lengthened—and don't think it's a joke: this is what will happen, particularly in the retail sector and the finance sector—difficulties will face each and every woman who has children. They will find difficulties finding care for their children. When their hours are reduced they will generally still be liable for the costs associated with longer periods of child care.

These changes for the worse will come not only as a result of the weakening of the Industrial Relations Commission but also because this government has flagged its intention to abdicate its responsibilities in many other areas that affect women's lives. Care for the aged and other service provisions are to be handed back to the dubious attentions of the states, as is responsibility for regulation and supervision.

It is not good enough just to say that we should have more women in this place. It is terribly important that we as women know that it is women who will be left with the pieces as we see the disintegration of the industrial relations system, as these important areas of care are handed back to the states: it will be women as mothers, sisters, daughters, relatives and unpaid community workers that take up these very difficult roles in our community. I do not think that is good enough. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion acknowledging the 75th anniversary of Edith Cowan entering the Western Australia parliament. In my own electorate of Gilmore, so named after Dame Mary Gilmore, there is much to remind us of this woman. Whilst not a politician, she was a major influence on women of her day. She experienced much of Australia and was a champion of many causes, in particular the struggle of women. She was the first woman to have a regular weekly column in the Tribune , something she used without fear or favour to further her cause.

SPEECH.PARA: This recognition of Edith Cowan gives me the opportunity to emphasise the importance of support systems for women entering the political arena. Going back in New South Wales history, it was in 1888 that the Dawn Club was founded. This was a club in which women could share, debate and use their expertise in social reforms. In 1891 the Womens Progress Association was established, a forum to encourage public debate. In 1887 Louise Lawson launched the first journal for women, written by women and highlighting the right to vote. She also formed the Womanhood Suffrage League of New South Wales. In 1902 the Womens Political Education League was started by Ruth Scott.

PARA.BREAK: When my own thoughts turned to politics there were no set criteria for entry. It was obvious that one had to have commonsense and the ability to recognise the possible from the impossible. Women are natural peacemak ers and we have the life experiences to equip us very well for life in the political arena. We are conscious of budget restraints and have sensitivity and the ability to make decisions. However, there are basic fundamentals that need to be addressed. We must have adequate training to improve our natural skills. This opportunity certainly exists in New South Wales under the guidance of the Liberal Womens Forum run by the federal women's president, Chris McDiven. This forum provides speech, media, debating and interview training and training on policy issues. It prepares possible candidates for preselection and personal appearances.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the former New South Wales Premier, John Fahey, and Minister for Women, Kerry Chikarovski, another source for women was set up—the Women's Advisory Council. This was a bipartisan committee that discussed issues relating to women at home and in the workplace. We produced a magazine called Hersay. Unfortunately, this has been discontinued under the Carr government. Women in the local government associations are also well versed in matters of policy debate, and training is given for women entering local politics. There are now a number of mayors in this association and all are committed to encouraging more women to stand for their local councils.

The pen is mightier than the sword and is lighter to work with. This is the reason why we women are choosing it as our weapon with which to fight the great battle for equal rights.

At all times, Edith Cowan combined commonsense and her experience in community work with her political career. She had an innate ability to reduce complex issues to a practical level. For example, she highlighted the problem of poor returns for farmers in comparison with the end retail price by giving concrete examples of the price of mutton. However, Edith was not one simply to criticise. She invariably offered a solution or at least an idea for discussion. In this example she declared that there should be a woman on the price fixing commission.
