We support any measure needed to keep our country safe from the curse of guns, up to and including the holding of a national referendum changing the Constitution to give the Commonwealth Government, not the States, jurisdiction over these weapons. If that is what it takes to secure tough, uniform gun laws in this nation and severe penalties for those who break them, then so be it.
Port Arthur must never be allowed to happen in this land again, even if me must surrender some of our so‐called civil liberties and pay higher taxes for this time to be.
Thank you for your attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) in making a few comments about the gun lobby. I think 10 May was a historic date—that is, when the Commonwealth and state governments were able to reach an agreement on sensible guns laws. I have to say to all members in this House that, as one who has been threatened both electorally and physically over the last week, I will stand up for those gun laws. What we saw in Gympie, Queensland, last week was an absolute disgrace. Mr McNiven in particular stands condemned by everybody. Really, it is not about responsible gun ownership; it is about the generation in our society of a militia concept, which is quite foreign to Australia. I heard him talk about our American brothers. Heaven help us, we do not want shades of Oklahoma City. I strongly support what the honourable member for Dobell had to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —If the front page of the Sydney Daily Telegraph on Saturday 18 May is accurate, I would like to tell the Labor government in New South Wales not to even contemplate putting in legislation that will allow poker machines to go into hotels. In New South Wales we have a charter which sees many clubs within the state catering for about 1.8 million members and about 2,000 hotels.

SPEECH.PARA: The charter of the club movement requires the clubs to direct the profits back to the members. They assist with sports and schools and the aged and the young. If we were to allow poker machines into hotels—that is, on top of what they already have with the card machines—what we would be doing is providing a red carpet for hoteliers to go straight to their banks and put the money into their bank accounts.

I believe that, if the government is going to contemplate doing this, other people like me and the club movement should condemn the actions of our government in New South Wales. They must give consideration to what the clubs have achieved in the state of New South Wales and most particularly how the communities have grown because of the involvement of the club movement.

Recently, one of our clubs gave something like $200,000 to a spastic centre. On Friday, another $50,000 was given to provide a school bus. I could go on and on about the assistance, help and growth in my community due to the contributions from the clubs. We do not have the same from hotels.

I am not condemning the hotel movement, but if they are having business problems perhaps they should not be in it. If a person has a fruit shop or dress shop that is having business problems we do not put poker machines in there to assist that person to make money. What we should be doing is making sure that we learn from some of the problems that have been encountered in the other states which have just put the machines in. We have experience which shows that these machines should be located in the club movement in New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great sadness that I rise today to pay tribute to one of my electorate's best known and loved residents, Clem O'Keeffe, who passed away on 7 May at the age of 81. Clem was committed to his country and his community. In World War II, he served in the South West Pacific with the RAAF. He was awarded life membership of Salisbury RSL and later received an Order of Australia Medal for his services to our local community, in particular QEII Hospital. Since 1981, Clem was the president of the QEII Hospital auxiliary. With Clem's leadership, the auxiliary raised over $850,000 over the years which was used to purchase state‐of‐the‐art equipment for the hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years, Clem galvanised local action against the previous state government's attempts to close the hospital. Clem effectively saved QEII from closing. He fought on as the Goss administration stripped away much of the equipment that he and others had helped obtain.

Whilst I had known Clem for only a few years we became great mates. He had the energy and mental awareness of someone at least 30 years younger, but sadly his body gave out. I consider it a great honour to have known him and I am privileged that he publicly endorsed me at the recent general election. Clem O'Keeffe will be remembered as a great Queenslander. I wish to extend my sympathy and that of the electorate of Moreton to his widow, Marjorie; their daughter, Leanne; son‐in‐law, Joseph Ludwig; and their children. Clem O'Keeffe will be sorely missed by me and many people in my local community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pay tribute to Nick Origlass, a fighter for working class interests, who died last Friday at the age of 88. Nick will be remembered for his leadership of the iron workers' dispute in 1945. He served 33 years on the Leichhardt council, including two terms as mayor, one from 1971‐73 and the other from 1987‐88. He retired from the council in 1995. He will be remembered for his support for open council and residents' participation and for the protection of the urban environment, particularly of the Balmain Peninsula.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many areas in which I would disagree with Nick's politics, but what it shows is that you do not have to agree with someone to have respect for them. Nick had respect across the political spectrum, be it Labor, Independent or conservative, because he was fair dinkum. He was well into his 80s when he was running off leaflets detailing issues of concern and distributing them by hand around the Balmain Peninsula. This will always attract respect from the working class Balmain community and the newer residents.

My sympathy goes to his wife, Joan, his son, Peter, his two grandchildren and his two great‐grandchildren. There are many people in the Balmain area who will miss him greatly, and his family can certainly be proud of his achievements.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders: Language Programs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 March I received a letter from the Top End Linguistic Circle in Katherine, which is an organisation of linguists from the Top End of the Northern Territory. The letter notes the pre‐election commitment of the Liberal Party to the maintenance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages and welcomes its commitment on an issue vital to the wellbeing of indigenous Australians. This letter further states:

SPEECH.PARA: This issue is even more pressing in the Northern Territory, where 70% of the indigenous population speak their own language at home.
We look forward to seeing the details of the implementation of pre‐election commitment, and would be grateful to be informed of the developments in this area.
We feel confident, given the recognition that you've accorded this issue, that no funding will be withdrawn from the relevant programs.

The coalition policy says that it will `maintain existing language programs, and where original languages are in decline, assist Indigenous communities to develop language retrieval programs'. I call on the minister responsible for ATSIC to advise TELC that funding levels will be maintained.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mossfield, Frank, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I advise the House that 75 students from one of the many excellent schools in the Greenway electorate are visiting parliament this week. The school is the Patrician Brothers College, Blacktown, which has 1,100 students and has operated in the Blacktown area for over 43 years.

SPEECH.PARA: The school has an excellent academic and sporting record. In the maths and science Australia wide competition, the school had a healthy number of high distinctions and credits. Students' art work was on display in the Commonwealth Bank during the year. The music department continues to thrive, with the students performing creditably at two concerts during the year. The industrial arts department has its usually high quality of work on display on open night.

Debating and public speaking have been encouraged amongst the students to increase self‐confidence. The winning of the Apex debating competition by years 8 and 9 was a fitting reward for the hard work that goes into competitive debating.

In the sporting field, the college won the statewide Berg Shield cricket competition title and the prestigious Junior Commonwealth Bank Cup rugby league competition. The school captain, David Beacroft, won the Metropolitan Catholic Schools Association junior sports boy of the year award and was the state and Australian champion in both the 1,500 metres walk and run.

The college developed an international spirit with some 16 Japanese students visiting the school for a two‐week period during 1995. This was the first group of overseas students to visit the school, so it was an experience for all concerned. The families that billeted the students, the Japanese visitors and the students from the school found the cultural exchange quite an eye‐opener. Special thanks went to the Australian Institute of International Understanding for arranging the program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly, Jackie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commend the completion of the Olympic rowing course in my electorate of Lindsay. The Olympic rowing team has just completed nine days training there in preparation for their departure this Thursday for the Atlanta Games. Some of them travelled from as far away as Western Australia simply to train on the Nepean River and at the Olympic rowing course at the Penrith Lakes scheme. Peter Antonie and Jason Day will be competing.
—A Bendigo boy.

—That is right. It is a very international course; we get them from all over Australia. Peter Antonie is 1986 world lightweight champion. He won a gold medal in Barcelona in 1992 and now he is trying again in 1996 at Atlanta to bring medals home to Australia. He is a very good prospect who has been training on the Nepean for in excess of 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: We currently have a problem with four different types of naturally occurring weed in the Nepean River, which is the main training venue. Any rower will tell you that it gets pretty boring going up and down 2,000 metres on the racing course and, on the Nepean, we have 26 kilometres of clear, flat water, as high up as, or even further than, the Warragamba Dam. It is an excellent training venue but it is under challenge from these weeds which we are in the process of trying to find some natural or environmentally friendly way of dealing with.
The river is also used by jetskiers, waterskiers, swimmers and triathletes but, again, the weed is causing a safety problem, so we are in the middle of doing something about that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly those members representing rural and regional electorates would be aware that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is poised to sign an approval which will allow for the importation to this country of cooked chicken meat. The implications of this for my own electorate and for the Hunter Valley generally are horrendous. In the Hunter Valley the value of the industry is around $70 million and it employs 3,000 people directly and many more indirectly.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware of course of our obligations under GATT, but members should become more rapidly aware that the level playing field is a misnomer and that, in the case of the chicken growing and processing industry, the field is particularly unlevel. In this instance, we have a perfect opportunity to renege on our obligations under GATT because there is a very great health concern in this instance. AQIS has found that cooked chicken meat can be successfully imported into this country without concern to our people's health, but I think we have had several examples in recent times of how AQIS has got it wrong. In this case, we have a very strong case indeed to resist, at every opportunity, the importation of cooked chicken meat into this country.

It seems that the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and I are the only people in this House capable of defending rural Australia on this matter, and I implore the minister to reconsider and to undertake further consultation before taking any such decision. I also implore him to talk to the industry, understand its concerns and, at the very least, defer any decision to allow for the importation of cooked chicken meat into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I inform the House that the Treasurer is absent as he is attending the ministerial meeting of the OECD. Questions which would normally be directed to him should on this occasion be directed to the Minister for Finance.

—Before I ask my question of the Prime Minister, I want to place on record the opposition's appreciation of his role in securing an agreement with the states on gun control matters which was made the day after parliament rose a week or so ago. Would the Prime Minister advise the House of progress being made by the states and territories to implement the necessary legislative changes agreed at the meeting of ministers; by what date does the Prime Minister intend that legislative changes will be in place and operational in the states and territories?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his comments. May I also place on record here, as I have elsewhere, the appreciation of the government for the completely bipartisan attitude and the constructive approach taken by the Leader of the Opposition and members of the Australian Labor Party, both federal and state, on this very difficult and important issue. I also take the opportunity of recording my thanks to state governments of both political persuasions for the attitude that they have taken.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition asked me what progress has been made. My understanding is that the ACT Legislative Assembly passed legislation last week. It is my understanding that legislation is being prepared in the other states. In the case of New South Wales, it was given effect to by regulation pending the preparation of legislation. In some of the other states, most notably Western Australia and South Australia, in relation to registration there are already laws and regulations which go very close to meeting, if they do not in fact meet, the aspirations of the police ministers meeting.

So far as the other states are concerned, in relation to the other particulars I do not have the dates available to me. It is my understanding that they are moving as soon as possible. I undertake to the Leader of the Opposition that I will specifically find out whether there are dates and, if there are, I will make them available to him and make them public.

I take this opportunity, as the Leader of the Opposition has asked me this question, of saying a couple of other things about the issue. It was an important decision and it was a decision that I believe was welcomed by the overwhelming majority of the Australian community, irrespective of their politics and irrespective of whether they live in the cities or the rural or provincial areas of this country.

There have been a lot of remarks made since the meeting and it is fair to record that this is a decision that will cause some inconvenience to many thousands of law abiding Australians. I have had occasion already to remark on the impact it might have on the rural community of Australia. Can I say again that I am sorry for that because the rural people of Australia normally put the national interest ahead of other considerations and I regret that many tens of thousands of law abiding primary producers will no longer have quite the same flexibility in relation to the possession of weapons that they have had in the past.

The decision that was made at the police ministers conference made it plain that self‐loading weapons were to become prohibited weapons except for limited categories. One of those exceptions was the police, another was the armed forces, another was professional shooters and, where a clear need was demonstrated to the satisfaction of the local licensing authorities, also primary producers. There is no intention on the part of the Commonwealth government to encourage any expansion of those exemptions. We believe that those exemptions cover all appropriate cases and it is very important that they be adhered to. I will certainly be encouraging all my colleagues at a state level to ensure that that happens.

PARA.BREAK: Some of the remarks that have been made on behalf of those who disagree with the decision of the governments of Australia have unfairly besmirched the reputation of people who are sporting shooters. I say to the sporting shooters associations of Australia: I understand that you are upset with the Commonwealth government's decision and the decisions of the state governments. I know that you are not personally responsible for any of the tragedies that have occurred in this country involving weapons over the past few years. I can feel for people who believe that something that they enjoy is being taken away from them and that a way of life that they have come to like is being taken from them. That is unfortunate and I—and I think every body in the House—sympathise with them. In no way do we associate some of the more irresponsible remarks made by particular individuals with the bulk of sporting shooters in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: That having been said, there won't be any change in the government's approach on this issue. Our position is firm and irrevocable. In stating that, I know that I have the support of the opposition and, more importantly, with no disrespect to the opposition, the support of the bulk of the Australian community.

This has been a great trauma for Australia. It was an enormous tragedy that is going to leave its scar on this country for many years to come. We owe it to the people who died in that tragedy and to the people who continue to suffer the scars of that tragedy to grab something better and build something new out of it. What the governments of Australia decided to do last Friday week was to take a new turn in this country. We decided as a community, across party lines, to reject the American approach, to say that this country rejected resort to violence and physical abuse as a way of settling differences whether in the community, the home or anywhere else. The best way that we can symbolise the fact that we are a non‐violent society is to make absolutely certain that there is a determination in this chamber and in this parliament, across party lines, to give full faith, effect and credit to the decision that was taken last Friday week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the Prime Minister's response to the previous question, I ask the Prime Minister: what action has the Commonwealth government taken to implement the result of the 10 May conference and, in particular, what compensation will be given to gun owners for the loss of their automatic and semi‐automatic weapons?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The specific action taken by the Commonwealth was to prohibit at the customs barrier the importation of the weapons newly included in the prohibition that was announced last Friday week. That customs prohibition took effect last Monday. The other decision that has been announced by the federal government is to increase by 0.2 per cent on a one-off basis only the Medicare levy for the purposes of financing the buyback of the weapons. That will raise about $500 million. On our calculations, that will be sufficient.

ANSWER.PARA: If there is any surplus, that will be returned through the Medicare system to the Australian people. I want to make it clear that this is a one-off increase. It is designed specifically and exclusively to finance the buyback of the weapons. If there is any over then it will, as I described, go back to the Australian people. So they are the two specific actions that have been taken.

Might I also take the opportunity of saying to the honourable member for Groom that when the legislation dealing with the increase in the Medicare levy is introduced it will include a provision to impose the 0.2 per cent component of the levy on members of the ADF who are currently exempt from the payment of the Medicare levy. We are taking that decision in the interest of equity. It is only fair and reasonable that the only people exempted from this particular increase are those taxpayers who, by virtue of the low level of their incomes, are not affected by the Medicare levy. That is why that particular anomaly was thrown up. I would not think anybody on either side of the House would have any particular objection to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that his Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs flagged last week to university vice-chancellors the possibility of cuts to higher education funding exceeding 12 per cent? I understand her precise words were, `How about 12 per cent for starters.' Given the enormous anxiety and outrage this response has provoked throughout the higher education sector, is the Prime Minister prepared to allay these concerns by repeating and confirming his pre-election promise to `at least maintain the level of Commonwealth funding to universities both in terms of operating grants and research grants'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports and I have read reports. Some of those reports, I guess, like all of these reports, are accurate and some of them are wildly inaccurate.
—Tell us which are and are not.

—I am not going to respond to the member's invitation. I learnt a long time ago not to dance to the tune of the frontbench of the Labor Party. That is one of the first lessons I learnt when I came into this place. I have never forgotten it and I will not.

ANSWER.PARA: I can assure the member for Sydney that the decisions we are going to take in this area will be fair and sensible decisions. I think the member for Sydney may, in the final analysis, be a little disappointed in some of decisions we are going to take. I want to echo the assurance that was given by the minister: this government places enormous store in the importance of higher education in the Australian community and has a great deal of confidence in the professional ability and quality of people who teach in Australia's universities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that this government has the community's support to improve the workplace situation in Australia? Answering that, does the Prime Minister believe that the waterfront is a very special place in a world of its own which should be exempt from attempts to improve its operations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe and the government believes that there is very strong community support for moderate, progressive change to Australia's industrial relations system. Of all of the things that we have argued for on this side of the House over the last 10 years, nothing has been more consistent, nothing has been more important and nothing has been more passionately advocated than the need for industrial relations reform.

ANSWER.PARA: I am very happy to say that the day is very near when my very competent colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations—this is important—symbolically is not going to introduce an industrial relations bill but is going to introduce the workplace relations bill. What that symbolises is a changed cultural approach to relations between employers and employees in this country. He will find, as I believe the great majority of members of this parliament will find, that there is very widespread support for the reforms that are going to be contained in the legislation.

I had the opportunity last Friday of exchanging some views on this subject with a group of people who took a walk from the Sydney town hall. They had a meeting; they were addressed by some of the leaders of the union movement; then they walked in peaceful assembly through the streets of Sydney and they sent me a message. They wanted to see me. So I said, `Come on up.'

Jennie George, the President of the ACTU, and the leaders of the Maritime Union of Australia came up and we had a very amiable discussion. We disagreed on one or two points; but, by and large, it was a very amiable discussion. I thought the President of the ACTU made one very interesting comment during that discussion which she repeated on a television program over the weekend. I think it is a phrase of hers that will probably get repeated quite a lot over the next few weeks. She said, `Freedom of choice, I can live with that.'

I am very pleased to hear that—and I see the shadow minister for industrial relations nodding. That is a very big advance, and it cheers me no end, that the Labor Party now believes in freedom of choice in the workplace. Is that what you were nodding about?

TALK.START.PARA: —You didn't know 20 years ago, and you still don't know.

—Ah, Simon is shaking his head. Wasn't he reading the script? The truth of the matter is that our legislation is all about freedom of choice in the workplace. I am delighted that not only the President of the ACTU but also the current industrial relations shadow spokesman are in favour of freedom of choice in the workplace.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Australian waterfront is concerned, I told the delegation that I would be happy to expedite the meeting between the ACTU, the maritime unions of Australia and the government regarding an establishment of a sort of fact basis for future discussions and decisions in relation to the waterfront. We have no desire to destroy the Maritime Union of Australia, as is so wrongly alleged. We have every intention of lifting productivity on the waterfront. We have every intention of ensuring that the Australian waterfront is competitive on a world basis. We have every intention of ensuring that, so far as the ANL is concerned, we are not bullied into submission by the maritime unions of Australia, as was the previous government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ships of shame!
—You were more responsible than anybody else for that bullying. Notice the smug, complacent smile on his face. He knows that it is true. Look at him.

ANSWER.PARA: What we intend to do is ensure that there is a competitive waterfront, but it will not be done on the basis of an ideological pursuit of an individual union. We intend to have a rational basis of discussion with the maritime unions, but it will be on the basis that we were elected with the authority of the Australian people to fix the waterfront, we were elected with the authority of the Australian people to reform the industrial relations system and, most important of all, we were elected with the authority of the Australian people to deliver freedom of choice in the workplace—and that is what we are happily going to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you were elected on the guarantee that no person would be worse off.
—The Leader of the Opposition will get to the question.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister and follows his earlier answer on the proposed `12 per cent for starters' cuts to university funding and programs. Will the Prime Minister now provide an assurance that the 4,000 additional places in Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia which were announced by the former government last year will be provided?
—I have nothing to add to my earlier answer.
—Mr Speaker—
—Where are the 23 Queensland members on their feet?
—Order! Members on both sides.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister whether he has seen reports of disaffection among some women in the community about the number of women who are elected to parliament? What action is the government taking to ensure that the success of large numbers of women at the last election is continued and that barriers which could stifle this trend are not reconstructed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As it happens, by chance, I do. I would not want people to get the wrong idea from this and to imagine there is some kind of new alliance being formed, but my attention was again drawn to some remarks made by the President of the ACTU on a television program at the weekend. She said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is very disappointing because the longer it goes on and the less evidence there is about the Labor Party's genuine seriousness about the issue I think the greater the disaffection amongst women voters.

She was clearly referring to the fact that on Saturday night the Australian Labor Party in the electorate of Blaxland chose Mr Hatton, who was an electorate officer of the former Prime Minister, in order to succeed. It demonstrated that, when it comes to choosing women in safe seats, the right wing of the Labor Party is just as bad as the left wing of the Labor Party, particularly in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the women holding safe seats on your side?

—There are millions of them. I would not talk about safe seats if I were you, brother. This little exercise indicates the absolute hypocrisy, duplicity and sophistry of the Labor Party when it comes to female representation in parliament. We all remember that demonstration at the national conference of the Labor Party with the streamers, balloons—
—And flowers.

—And flowers and everybody embracing everyone else and saying it was a new dawn. But when it actually came to delivering some results, when it actually came to delivering some women into parliament, where has the Labor Party been left? It has been left pathetically short of the quota that it set itself. By contrast, the coalition, which does not believe and never will believe in patronising quotas for any one section of the Australian community, has delivered a record number of female representatives in parliament. You know it, and don't you feel uncomfortable about it and so you ought to feel uncomfortable about it.
—No, not at all.
—The other day I heard that great friend of yours Meredith Burgmann—one of your mates in New South Wales—
—Not my mate. A colleague!

—I know she is not a friend of yours. I said that with a touch of irony, Janice. I heard Meredith Burgmann being interviewed on radio and she said that the trouble with the Right in New South Wales is that they will not choose any women. The reporter was cheeky enough, to my amazement, to say, `Yeah, but what about when Jeannette McHugh retired and she was replaced by Albanese, who is a member of the Left? You're as bad as the Right in New South Wales, aren't you?', and she said, `Well, our record hasn't been too good.' No wonder it has not been too good.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of the matter is that collectively the record of the ALP on this issue has been symbolised by lots of words and a total lack of action. What you are demonstrating to the women of the 1990s and to the great mainstream of female voters in Australia is that you are big on rhetoric and big on words but, when it comes to delivering women into positions of authority, you are a country mile behind the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I refer the minister to an Australian Customs Service internal minute on staff cuts. Can the minister confirm plans to cut more than 400 jobs in regional locations in the Australian Customs Service? Can he also confirm the decision to abolish all shift work for border interception around the country of illegal goods? Will the minister explain to this House how these cuts will assist in the crackdown on illegal drugs, on prohibited firearms and on pornographic material?

—I thank the member for his question. The Customs Service, like other departments, is evaluating at present the staff reductions needed to meet the government's target to fill Beazley's $8 billion black hole. In addition to that—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question of the justification for the cuts was dealt with last week. I would ask the minister to refer his answer to my question.
—There is no point of order.

—I remind the honourable member that some of the staff reductions occurring at Customs are still a result of the opposition's one per cent running cost measures, which opposition members seem to forget. I might add that Customs went through one hell of a period after the Conroy report was released, and that was a result of the opposition's incompetence. The member's question was in regard to the way that we are going to control the borders. The government is relying on better equipment, risk management and—
—Oh!

—Well, Customs already processes some six million incoming passengers. You should be aware that, in regard to X-ray equipment, better processing and better targeting, Customs has a very good record of targeting incoming passengers for prohibited substances and narcotics. In regard to prohibited weapons, the Prime Minister just mentioned that we have targeted programs in place to protect the borders, and we will continue with them.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. What are the benefits for home buyers, small businesses and families in my electorate of Lindsay and in other regions around the country with high numbers of first home buyers and young families of reducing the Commonwealth debt and closing the $8 billion black hole?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lindsay for her question. As all Australian people now know, Labor would not tell the Australian people the truth during the election campaign. The current Leader of the Opposition was going around Australia saying that the budget was in surplus, when Treasury figures gave a very different point of view and told a very different story. On 12 March—
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Is the minister in a position to deliberately mislead the House?
—`Deliberately mislead' requires a substantive motion.

—I go to the question of relevance. The minister is suggesting that I had before me a set of Treasury figures which maintained that the budget was in deficit. That is absolutely untrue, and he persists with this untruth.
—There is no point of order.
—On 12 March, the Treasurer released the Treasury fiscal and economic outlook.
—How many pages have you got?

—Just be patient. This outlook contained updated forecasts for the 1996-97 financial year. We all know now that the headline deficit for the 1996-97 year has been revised from a surplus of $3.4 billion to a deficit of $4.9 billion, and this represents a shortfall of $8.3 billion.

ANSWER.PARA: The more appropriate measure of the budget position, the underlying measure, is the forecast by Treasury of a deficit of $7.6 billion for 1996-97. This compares with Labor's 1994-95 budget estimate of an underlying deficit of only $590 million for 1996-97. So we can all see that the state of the government's fiscal inheritance is appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish.
—It is not a fiction, as those sitting opposite who will not listen try to suggest. It is a legacy of mismanagement, a legacy of deception. What we are left with is a massive task—
—On a point of order: can the minister give an undertaking that he is not going to renege on his unfunded promises?
—I will not take frivolous points of order from the Leader of the Opposition.

—What we in the government are left with is a massive task to reshape the budget and transfer a huge deficit to a balanced budget. This means a tightening of around $8 billion over two years, and that is the program we have set ourselves. The figuring is based upon current Treasury estimates.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: is it in the spirit of question time for the finance minister to simply read a script as an answer to a question?
—This is again a frivolous point of order, and they will not be tolerated. Honourable members should be very careful.

—They obviously do not like hearing the truth about the state of the budget that we inherited. What we have heard from Labor in recent times is the opposition calling for the government to slow down the deficit reduction. Those calls are coming from the shadow Treasurer. On 24 April, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Labor in opposition does not resile for a moment from the proposition that we adopted as a government that it is very desirable, other things being equal, for there to be a return to underlying fiscal balance as soon as possible.
That is from the shadow Treasurer. When he thought the budget should be returned to surplus, he said on the PM program:

BREAK.PARA: We'd spread it out over a much longer period, depending on what the size of the task is going to be. We'd spread it out over a much longer period.
May I have some water?

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it for him, John!
—It's a long answer.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is very thirsty work, and I have great empathy with the minister.

—The government and the Reserve Bank have made it perfectly clear. The budget has now been in recovery for some four to five years. Responsible fiscal management tells us all that a government must have the budget in balance at this stage of the cycle if it is to have the necessary flexibility in an economic downturn.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order, I draw your attention to standing order 321. The minister appears to be reading from a document, and I request that he table it.
—Is the minister reading from confidential documents?

—Mr Speaker, I am referring to notes, but I am happy to table them at the conclusion of my answer. A benefit of balancing of the budget is reducing the pressure on interest rates. The government believes that tighter fiscal policy is conducive to higher, not lower, employment. That view is shared by many respected authorities, including Mr Ian Macfarlane, the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank. He said that the proposition that fiscal consolidation automatically represented lower economic growth has been disproved during the 1990s. The issue being missed, of course, by the opposition every day is the powerful factor of investor confidence. I noted last week that consumer confidence had increased—
—On a point of order: I do not ask this question of you frivolously, Mr Speaker, but this is not a question. He is just reading a speech. What about the answer?
—There is no point of order. Resume your seat. I would encourage the minister to wind up his answer.

—Mr Speaker, if I could refer to the honourable member for Lindsay's question again. The honourable member for Lindsay indicated she was concerned about interest rates for her constituents. She was concerned about home buyers and their capacity to acquire homes. It is the policy of this government to reduce the deficit, which will lead to greater opportunities for the people in Lindsay and western Sydney and right around Australia to buy their homes.

BREAK.PARA: The confidence that has been returned to the private sector will also boost the opportunities that are available. This government has the task of getting things in order so that this nation can go forward, and that will benefit all people in Australia. I table my notes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. I have been advised that the investigation unit of the Australian Customs Service in Tasmania will be closed down and that the staffing levels of Customs is to be reduced by 36 per cent. How can you, on the one hand, introduce measures to reduce violence in our community and look after the people of Tasmania while you are slashing the services of the Australian Customs Service and its investigation unit? How can you possibly monitor the origin and the movement of illegal firearms, drugs and child pornographic material without an investigation unit and with significantly reduced personnel numbers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. As I mentioned a while ago, reviews of staff numbers within Customs are being carried out by the department in consultation with the staff and unions at present. There should be no confusion about the role of Customs at barrier control and the role of Customs in internal inland policing. The role of Customs at the barrier is to stop the importation of banned and prohibited imports of narcotics—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you interested in what comes into this country or not? You do not seem to be. You seem to be ignoring the question and the role that Customs plays in this.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members on my left, if you are less boisterous, you will get to the answers more quickly.
—Customs, together with its barrier control, as you should know, runs front‐line and customs watch programs, so the community plays a role in these things as well.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the importation of weapons and the importation of narcotics, it is not a case of searching every bag. Those days have gone. What you would want is a return to the past when every box and every crate are opened. We cannot do that, though, with modern passenger movement and with cargo processing. What Customs has introduced in regard to risk management and targeted passenger procedures is the ability to screen and process. In this way, Customs is able to stop the importation of illegal material, such as narcotics, into this country. The reduction of any staff numbers will not impede that work.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister of Finance. Is the minister aware of a proposal to impose a levy or a tax on Telstra's pre‐tax profits to fund a Natural Heritage Trust? What effect would this proposal have on Telstra's ability to meet the needs of the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week the Leader of the Democrats issued a press release which indicated that they proposed to bring forward a new tax, effectively a hypothecation of the dividends from Telstra, to fund an environmental fund. I am sure the honourable member for Fremantle would not support a hypothecation on the basis of past experiences that she has had and, Mr Speaker, I am sure that everyone would appreciate that such a tax goes against all of what government trading enterprises are about.

ANSWER.PARA: This tax would affect very much Telstra's capacity to consolidate its position in respect of that competitive world that it is now in and that it will enter as it goes through the next several years as more competitors come on-line in the communications area. Its being saddled with a tax, I believe about seven per cent, would prevent it from engaging in its various other activities, including its increased technology.

It is a new tax; it is an unfair tax. What the Democrats are asking the government to do is break an election commitment. We made it very clear that there will be no new taxes—and there will be no new taxes. Under it, Telstra would have a reduced capacity to fund its expansion and its network modernisation, and to meet its obligations to rural customers, which is very much part of what this government's program is. It is essential for Telstra to be placed appropriately as it enters its next few years in a competitive world.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. I know he just took his glasses off, but he is reading and under standing order 321 I ask that he table the document that he is obviously reading from.
—Is the minister reading from confidential documents?
—I am referring briefly to a couple of points.
—On a further point of order, the minister said he was not reading from a confidential document, Mr Speaker, so you should require him to table it.
—The minister has indicated that he has no problem tabling the document at the end of this very interesting dissertation.

—I am happy to table my notes at the conclusion of my answer. What we would see is a Democrat Telstra tax. That would prevent Telstra from proceeding forward. It would amount to $200 million, or thereabouts, each year. That would impact on family services, education and the government's capacity to meet its commitments in those areas. The government will not support this proposal.

—My question is to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. He would be aware that modern Customs practice involves targeting suspected cargoes. Can he tell us who is going to target those cargoes in Tasmania in the absence of an investigations unit?

—I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. The Leader of the Opposition may or may not be aware that during the Midford inquiry from which came the Conroy report there was a reference to investigations. That report indicated that the investigations unit will be concentrated rather than there being a spreading of resources around the country. I can assure members of this House that the role of Customs and the role of the barrier will be maintained in any rationalisation of staff. It will not lead to any diminution of the investigations procedures. That will continue to apply.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister will be aware of recent statements that have been critical of the accord‐style system of industrial relations, due to its failure to deliver real benefits for Australian workers. I ask the minister: what is the government's position on developing a new accord?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. The government will not be adopting a new form of accord. In fact, like the Prime Minister, I take some comfort from the remarks of the President of the ACTU, who last night said that, under the previous accord:

ANSWER.PARA: Workers made sacrifices in the national interest—
but—
They got no thanks for it.
She went on to say:
What we saw happening in the process of a very centralised arrangement, unions leaving too much to the ACTU and workers being disaffected . . .
Not only has she been saying that but it would be hard to disagree with the words expressed by the CFMEU in a recent statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, now!
—I know it is a bit hard, Prime Minister. The statement reads:

BREAK.PARA: . . . we call on the ACTU and the union movement generally to soberly reflect upon the damage caused to the trade union movement over the last 13 years and ensure there is no repeat of a process which in effect puts the political survival of the ALP before industrial interests of workers.

That is a lesson that members ought to take heed of. It is interesting that whilst the Leader of the Opposition is said to be cutting his close links with the ACTU—according to the Sydney Morning Herald and the shadow minister who does not know whether he is for it or against it—the shadow treasurer thought it was such a good idea that recently he said:
I believe we can and should try and deliver that all over again back in government.

So there are some for it and some against it. The reality is that, because they cannot work out their relationship with the ACTU, they have no position on one of the major debates in this country today; that is, the question of industrial relations reform. It is true, as Jennie George said, that workers actually lost out as a result of the accord. She is not the first woman on Labor's side to say that. That is exactly what Jenny Mikakos said—one of those girls in the ALP who was denied preselection by the boys now sitting on the front bench.

The fact is that reform is necessary after the last 13 years because, as even those of our political opponents have made quite clear, the accord did not work. So it is time for change, and we look forward to introducing it this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and I refer to the pre‐election commitments: firstly, that employees covered by an award will remain under that award unless they choose to enter an agreement; and, secondly, that no worker can be worse off under your proposals—I think it was the so‐called `rock solid guarantee'. How can you claim that those guarantees can be delivered, given that your legislation will permit state workplace agreements to automatically override federal awards and that in Victoria, for example, state workplace agreements have to comply with just five minimum conditions which are substantially less than current federal award provisions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We will keep faith with the commitments that we gave prior to the election. In fact, that will be made very clear in the bill that will be introduced into the parliament very shortly. As Jennie George was saying, workers were worse off under Labor. That is one of the prime reasons for our change—we want some changes so that in future workers will be better off.

ANSWER.PARA: In the 13 years of Labor, your people boasted how you reduced the wages of workers. It is no wonder a lot of workers woke up to you after a while and switched their support to us. I can say to those workers: when they see this bill, when they see our resolution, our determination to protect the situation of workers, they will know that only one side of politics can deliver better pay and it is this side.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. The minister will be aware of the high rate of youth unemployment in my electorate of Forde and the southern suburbs of Brisbane. The minister will also be aware of the personal and economic hardship unemployment causes young Australians. Will the minister inform the House what action the government is taking to preserve youth jobs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is very concerned about the high rates of youth unemployment. We are absolutely determined to do all that we can to ensure that, unlike in the previous 13 years, in the future young people have a chance of a job.

PARA.BREAK: The issue raised by the honourable member relates to some part of the ill‐fated Brereton reforms in 1993 which, by the initiative of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, introduced certain age discrimination, or anti‐age discrimination processes. They were due to come into effect. The previous government deferred their coming into effect until 22 June 1997, because I believe that they themselves were also concerned about the effect of those provisions on the youth labour market. Our proposals will defer indefinitely the discrimi natory anti‐discriminatory provisions of the existing Industrial Relations Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The previous government's idea was to find an alternative to junior wage rates based on competency. It is true the parties have been sitting down trying to find a reasonable solution; but it is also a fact that they really have failed to do so. It is true that the matter has been before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission but, on any fair reading of it, a third‐best solution has been arrived at.

Furthermore, in the competency provisions of this alternative, they rely very heavily on asking questions of applicants as to how many years they had at school and how many years it has been since they left school. In other words, they have a so‐called alternative competency based system, but it really is a de facto age based system anyway. The nonsense of this is that that proposal, if it were to come into effect on 22 June, would probably be subject to legal challenge anyway.

We have had lots of discussions about this matter in our consultations. Looking at the labour market in Australia, for example, in the retail industry, 283,000 young people have got jobs. We have had discussions with the Retailers Council of Australia and, on their estimates, they say something of the order of 220,000 of those jobs could be at risk if Labor's scheme were allowed to continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—Two hundred and twenty thousand. I do not know the exact figure; obviously it is a projection. Any reasonable person can hardly, in my view, afford to ignore the likely impact on young people as a result of that proposal proceeding.

ANSWER.PARA: I do say to the other side that, if they are genuinely concerned about young people, then they ought to support this particular aspect of our proposal. I should add that exemptions for junior wage rates are provided in all the state and territory jurisdictions—in other words, supported by branches of the Labor Party around the states.
Lastly, there have been quite a lot of public comments about this in the last few days. The Retailers Council of Australia in a statement say:

Unless the Minister's proposal is endorsed by Parliament almost a quarter of a million jobs of young Australians will be at risk and Australia's already high level of youth unemployment will skyrocket.
That has been followed up by an editorial in the Courier‐Mail which says:
This is a sensible move—
referring to the government's proposal. It also says:

In a situation where young people are increasingly competing with older, more experienced employees for a limited pool of jobs, youth wages can provide a competitive advantage. For many, this might be the only means by which they can achieve an employment foot in the door.
The ACCI media release makes the same point. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Western Australia says:
The removal of junior wage rates from awards would see youth unemployment rates soar. The jobless rate among teenagers is already running at 30 per cent.
And it goes on and on and on. This is a very simple decision to be made. It ought to be supported by the opposition parties.

As to the government's position, youth unemployment rates in Australia are already far too high as a result of your economic mismanagement. We are not going to sit idly by and see a lot of young people lose their jobs next year because of your incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications. Minister, how will you protect the many Internet access providers and service providers from the consequences of Telstra becoming an Internet access provider as well as a telecommunications carrier—a clear conflict of interest and anti-competitive in nature, and which will undoubtedly affect prices?
—The matter that the honourable member raises is a matter for consideration by Senator Alston right at the present time. I will refer the matter to him for consideration.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training and the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Youth Affairs. I ask the minister: has the government frozen labour market program expenditure? Further, I ask: why has the government brought forward $30 million of expenditure from next year's budget to pay for this year's labour market program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Richmond for his question. The government is aware of concerns being expressed by a number of contracted case managers and private training providers of labour market programs that funds are not currently being made available under these contracts. The government has not frozen labour market program expenditure. The government is engaged in an exercise of prudent management of this funding in view of the situation which it found on coming to office after the federal election this year. The government has been forced to act because of the fact that so large a proportion of the moneys allocated for this year, the $2.1 billion allocated in last year's budget, to help unemployed people had been spent in the run-up to the election campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: In the months before the election campaign, members of this House will recall that the coalition constantly warned that expenditure was getting out of hand by the government in order to hide the unemployed from the statistics and in an attempt to redefine long-term unemployed people as short-term unemployed people. On coming to office we found that most of the budget for programs to help unemployed people had already been spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!

—You listen to the facts. You knew these facts. Just over halfway through the year, by 25 January, 61 per cent of the total budget had already been spent. At the beginning of March, that is, at the time of the federal election this year, with 66 per cent of the year elapsed, Labor had promised 95 per cent of the money already—
—But not spent.
—And had spent—wait for it—71 per cent of the funds. By 4 March—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't like to hear this, do you? By 4 March, that is, the Monday after the federal election campaign, out of the $2 billion allocated for the year only $91 million was left. The fact is that you did not care that the cupboard was bare when the new government came in because you were so concerned to protect your political hide in the run-up to the election.

ANSWER.PARA: I have here, Mr Speaker, a minute from the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education and Training, circulated to all area managers, which points out that any blame for this overexpenditure should be sheeted home to the previous minister. The reason for this? The previous minister had two options. When he saw this gross overexpenditure of money taking place he realised that this was going to leave all those responsible for the delivery of programs in a very difficult situation in the last third of the year. He had the option of slowing down the expenditure. Did he do that? No, no. The message went out: `Spend up, spend more up to the election campaign, try and hide the unemployed in the figures.' Or he had the option of bringing funding forward from next year. Mr Speaker, he did neither. In a gross dereliction of duty he allowed this mismanagement of this enormous budget to take place with the result that there is now considerable concern throughout the community at the flow of funds. The government is very conscious of this and has brought forward $30 million from next year's expenditure—

TALK.START.PARA: —Created by you. You have frozen the programs.
—There has been no freezing of programs. The government has brought forward $30 million worth—
—What did you do with Skillshare?

—You read the minute that I am tabling, which makes it absolutely clear that there has been no freezing of programs. I want to make it clear that funding for wage subsidy programs such as jobstart continues. There are still some additional places for the brokered programs, new work opportunities, LEAP and jobskills. All contracted case managers will be advised by the government of where these places are located in the country.

ANSWER.PARA: So when honourable members are approached by constituents who are concerned that anticipated funding is not coming through, they can point their finger to the honourable member for Hotham, who mismanaged this enormous budget in the run-up budget to the election campaign, and say that he is the person responsible. The government will continue to manage this situation with great care in relation to the budget and with sensitivity to clients' needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: can you guarantee that, under your proposed industrial relations legislation, no young person will be required to work for less than the existing training wage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We have given particular consideration to young people under training arrangements in respect of those who may wish to take up the option of an Australian workplace agreement, mindful that we gave a guarantee about people's remuneration under an Australian workplace agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: The bill will provide that, for example, for a young person who has four days work and one day's training, they be paid for those four days proportionate to the award applicable to them. Obviously, they are not paid for the training day. That is the principle which has been adopted in the national training award provisions, and we have picked it up in our bill. I should add, though, that we do have some greater flexibility than the national training award provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? To reduce wages?

—Not a downward flexibility for wages. Don't get excited; you are the experts on reducing people's wages. We are the ones making sure that people's wages are not reduced. We are trying to give them a chance of higher pay. Thank you very much for the interjection. I should not be tempted.

BREAK.PARA: One of the good things about the Australian workplace agreement is that it will encourage young people to take up the opportunities of training arrangements through Australian workplace agreements. I actually think that the improved training arrangements through our package will be one of the great benefits—although perhaps hard to quantify. Training is terribly important for the future, and that is why we have made particular and careful provision for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice: is he aware of the ready availability of magazines that advertise for sale recipes for homemade bombs, booby traps and instructions for the conversion of weapons to facilitate automatic fire? If so, is the availability of such literature contrary to the efforts of the federal and state governments to make Australia a safer place? Is the government considering controls that could be placed on such printed materials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Sturt for his perceptive question.
—You wrote it for him.
—No. I didn't write it.
—Your staff did.

—No. The member for Sturt wrote it. In the wake of the Port Arthur incident, and in the wake of the police ministers meeting on 10 May, it is undoubted that the overwhelming majority of Australians want Australia to be a safer place. In this context, it is a matter of some regret that there are available magazines of the type mentioned by the honourable member. He asked about controls in respect of them. Members will be aware that there is, under a combination of Commonwealth and state legislation, a system for the classification of publications and—particularly under state and territory laws—a system of enforcing prohibitions on publication of restricted material.

ANSWER.PARA: Under the national classification code, which is created under that legislation, there is a restriction on the classification of material that promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence. Magazines of the type mentioned by the honourable member would not be able to get classified; they would be refused classification under that code. The Office of Film and Literature Classification, which is the Commonwealth body which does the classification, has no role in relation to the enforcement. State and territory governments enforce the rules.

There are laws which provide for significant penalties. For example, in the ACT, distribution or sale of a publication of the type mentioned carries a penalty of 12 months gaol or a fine of $10,000. An example of the type of magazine to which the honourable member refers and one which some members may have seen is Lock, Stock and Barrel. That magazine has not been submitted by its publisher for classification by OFLC. The publisher is a gentleman named Mr Ron Owen, whom some of you may have seen on television recently. That magazine has, nevertheless, been classified or dealt with on eight occasions by the OFLC. On four occasions it was classified and on the four other occasions it was refused classification.

As a result of that latter action, appeals have been brought by the publisher which have recently been dismissed and the Queensland government has, in respect of those magazines which were refused classification, instituted prosecutions. Those prosecutions have yet to be dealt with, and I make no further comment upon it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Will the minister confirm that Australian workers who want to enforce fair minimum conditions under an Australian workplace agreement will have to commence proceedings in a civil court, such as a Local Court? Given that such courts frequently have waiting lists of up to 12 months, why will such workers not be worse off compared with the current situation in which the Industrial Relations Commission is able to ensure that appropriate minimum conditions are in place before an agreement is approved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the honourable member has not appreciated the design fea tures of the government's industrial relations package. What we have done, perhaps to his great embarrassment—and I look forward to his contribution in the second reading debate—is to use the same remedial processes that you have. Because we reckoned yours were not good enough, we decided to add to them by allowing people access, free of charge, to the employment advocate. Not only is it a situation in which workers are not worse off but the fact is that workers are demonstrably better off. And that is so much the message of our policy, right across the board.

ANSWER.PARA: Will they have access to the courts? Of course they will. We are using the remedies you provided in the 1993 so-called reform act and we are making them better. Thank you very much for the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I ask the minister: is he aware of changes to the Australian refugee program in recent times; and will the government honour its election commitment on refugees?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. On a matter relating to refugees, and given some of the comments that have been made by members on the other side of the House, I thought it would have been one of the first matters raised. But it does not seem to have taken that order of priority.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not comment on the speculation about the size of the program for next year, except to say that our election commitment will be honoured. It ought to be understood what the election commitment was; it was to maintain a separate humanitarian program—and not to reduce the refugee component of the program. I think it is important that honourable members are aware as to some misapprehensions that do exist in relation to the refugee program because of the way in which it was dealt with by our predecessors.

In 1995-96 the humanitarian program was set by the previous government at 13,000 places, but the number of refugee places was 4,000. Of course, what has happened over a period of time is that the government has degraded, very significantly, the refugee element in the program. It was significantly higher in earlier years. The previous government saw fit to institute the special assistance program which was designed to assist people who were thought to be in special need—but never, by any stretch of the imagination, were they seen as being people who were able to satisfy the UN definition of what it is to be a refugee.

Of course, what we saw over time was that the special assistance places had taken up almost half the places of the total humanitarian program. While they may have been folk with relatives here, they certainly were not those languishing in the camps around the world accorded priority by the UNHCR; they certainly were not. The fact is that last year—

TALK.START.PARA: —Send them back to the camps, eh? Where do you think they came from then?

—They came under a special assistance program. Some of them were people who had landed here as boat people and returned in expectation that they would be brought back under a special assistance category. If you want to go through all the categories, I am more than happy to do so. But they were not necessarily asylum seekers in refugee camps accorded priority by the UNHCR.

ANSWER.PARA: But it was in response to a request from the UNHCR to provide additional resettlement opportunities for people from the former Yugoslavia that the former government announced that it would borrow—and I use those words advisedly—2,000 places from the 1996-97 program, including 665 places for refugees. The fact is that the humanitarian program for 1995-96 is, in reality, or has been 13,000. Fifteen thousand was a highly artificial figure. The former government did not budget to pay for the extra 2,000 places this year. In fact, it intended to pay for the places from next year's program.
I have no criticism of the decision of the former government to respond to an urgent need. But it was Labor that manipulated and fiddled the figures to achieve its objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It clearly was. The former government borrowed 2,000 places from next year's program for dealing with the situation of 1995-96. It did not, as it could have done, allocate additional places. The fact is, the starting point for consideration of the 1996-97 program is 13,000 less 2,000 places that Labor has already allocated. In other words, it is 11,000; it is not 13,000. It is certainly not 15,000. The starting point for refugees is certainly 3,335 places, not 4,000.

BREAK.PARA: So the question of manipulation, the question of propriety and the way in which you want to address these issues ought to be understood by what you did when you were in government. The honourable shadow minister ought to have regard to his own reputation in these matters. Did he disown his own colleagues when they took this decision before? Did he walk away from his colleagues? No, he sat silent in relation to these matters. But he wants to come out here now and make a big fellow of himself as though he is more concerned about refugees than anybody else—and the fact is that he has absolutely no concern whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Australian land information group, known as Auslig, the sole agent in Australia for the Canadian firm Radar Satellite International—curiously, also known as RSI? When private Australian businesses place purchase orders with Auslig for data exclusively supplied to it by RSI, are those business required to also list comprehensively their clients who may be relevant to that purchase order? Does Auslig compete with those same businesses for contracts in the public and private sectors? Does the minister agree that this anti-competitive practice involving provision of a monopoly service is inappropriate for a government owned agency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In terms of the technical part of your question, I will get some of that information from Auslig for you. But I think I should tell you that there are some 13 businesses within the Department of Adminis trative Services—and Auslig is one of those 13 businesses—presently under review. That review should be completed by the end of this month. It is about the commercial operations of these businesses, about their effectiveness in the provision of services and, in fact, about return to government and the way they go around business. So we are waiting for that particular review to come in.

ANSWER.PARA: I should also say that we will be looking at the Hilmer principles in terms of that review. As well as that, we will be looking at the community service obligations and the Industry Commission's requirements on contracting out and competitiveness. Once that review is in place we will be looking at the ramifications and obviously making some announcements in the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 21 questions. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
