PETITION.PRESENTERS: McGauran, Peter, MP; Neville, Paul, MP; Slipper, Peter, MP; Truss, Warren, MP
PETITION.TITLE: Marriage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned shows that:

We believe that the traditional Christian view of the family unit excludes anything other than a male and female, living in a lawful marriage relationship, along with their children, and that it is necessary for this to be restated by our political leaders.
We reaffirm our belief in the traditional Christian view of marriage as God's holy institution in which male and female become one flesh. (Genesis 2.24; Matthew 19.5,6)

We reaffirm that God is the author of marriage, and has restricted it to the union of male with female and that such marriage between male and female is commended in Scripture as honourable among all. (Ephesians 5.15‐23)
We reaffirm that such marriage between male and female is ordained for life‐long companionship, help and comfort which husband and wife ought to have of each other. (Romans 7.2,3)

We reaffirm that children are a heritage of the Lord and should be nurtured in a godly home, and that human society can be strong and happy only where the marriage bond is held in honour. (Psalm 127.3)

We reaffirm that incestuous marriages can never be made lawful by the law of any man or government, or the consent of parties, so as to allow those people to live together as married couples. (Mark 6.18; Leviticus 18.6‐28)

We reaffirm that, according to Biblical law, it is forbidden for a male to practise sexual intercourse with another male, or for a female with a female, and that since this is an abomination before the Lord, such as a prohibited relationship for marriage. (Leviticus 18.22; 20.13)
We believe the entire stability and well being of our society depends on maintaining this traditional Christian view of marriage and family (Leviticus 20.15‐16; 18.23‐24)
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives should call on the Government to:
(a) Preserve completely intact the exclusiveness of marriage as being one male and one female.
(b) That the definition of a prohibited relationship in the Marriage Act 1961, Part III 23(2) be amended with the addition of a new clause (c) so that it reads as follows:
(2) Marriages of parties within a prohibited relationship are marriages—
(a) between a person and an ancestor or descendant of the person; or
(b) between a brother and a sister (whether of the whole blood or the half blood); or
(c) between a male and a male or between a female and a female.
Your Petitioners humbly pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr McGauran (from 22 citizens), Mr Neville (from 89 citizens), Mr Slipper (from nine citizens)and Mr Truss (from 57 citizens)

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the gradual decline in Australia's level of foreign aid.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to:
(a) change the focus of Australia's foreign aid from one of economic growth and infrastructure funding to one of DIRECT poverty eradication; and
(b) ensure that, before the year 2000, the Australian Overseas Aid Budget attains the United Nation's target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PARA.TAB: the need to establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia:
that many difficulties experienced by Australian citizens travelling to Croatia are due to the limited services that the Australian Consulate, in Zagreb, is able to provide; and

that these difficulties are directly attributed to travel distance, time and costs incurred, and language barriers encountered when having to use services only available through the Australian Embassy in Austria.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners request that the House should:

PARA.TAB: note the difficulties and inconvenience encountered by Australian citizens travelling in Croatia; and
take appropriate action to urgently establish an Australian Embassy in the Republic of Croatia.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Support Assessment Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament
The petition of certain citizens draws to the attention of the House, the injustices resulting from the Child Support Assessment Act.
The Child Support Assessment Act fails to allow a payee to financially and non‐financially re‐establish themself after an assessment has been made.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to repeal the Child Support Assessment Act and replace it with a fairer system which provides payees with an incentive to keep working rather than becoming unemployed which is an option currently advocated by the staff of the Child Support Agency.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Domiciliary Nursing Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of private domiciliary nursing service providers and others members of the community in NSW and the ACT draws to the attention of the House that the provision of private domiciliary nursing care by registered nurses to the community, in particular veterans, in NSW and the ACT is under threat by the Federal Government's move to pass responsibility for domiciliary care to state governments and the actions of the Department of Veterans' Affairs in passing referrals for care, including nursing duties, to untrained Home Care aides.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House to ensure the continuation of private domiciliary nursing care in NSW by registered nurses to those members of the community who are entitled to such care.

PETITION.TITLE: Sudan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
(a) the Sudanese Government's policies of genocide against Sudanese groups are repugnant, and
(b) the sustained and systematic attempt to enforce Sharia law on non‐Islamic citizens is condemned.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will persuade the Government and the international community, including the UN Security Council to:
(i) impose an arms embargo on the Government of Sudan
(ii) establish air exclusion zones in Sudan
(iii) support the peace initiatives of the Inter‐Governmental Authority for Drought and Desertification
(iv) engage in discussion with all officially banned democratic opposition groups
(v) ensure the immediate access by the United Nations Operation, Life‐Line Sudan and other aid agencies into all areas; and
(vi) Provide teams to monitor human rights in the north, south and the Nuba Mountains of Sudan.

PETITION.TITLE: Gunalda Range
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The following citizens of Australia draw to the attention of the House the substandard condition of Gunalda Range section of the Bruce Highway and the urgent need to realign and improve the road to avoid further serious accident in the area.
Your Petitioners therefore request the House to take immediate action to upgrade this section of the road.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC: 7.30 Report
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The following citizens of Queensland draw to the attention of the House the decision of the ABC to end State based versions of the 7.30 Report.
Your Petitioners therefore request the House to act immediately to require the ABC to reinstate State 7.30 Reports.

PETITION.TITLE: Information Superhighway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition from the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the grave concerns we hold regarding the dangers inherent in the communications Superhighway, with its potential to corrupt and deprave our present and future society if material containing depictions of indecent or obscene material is not proscribed.
Your petitioners therefore request that in regard to Computer Bulletin Boards the House will frame legislation to ensure that the system CANNOT BE USED TO:
1.(a) transmit,
(b) advertise as available for transmission,
(c) possess objectionable material regardless of intended use.
2. the definition of `to transmit' includes `to obtain' or `to acquire'.
We further request that the legislation ensure that `objectionable material' means material which in any way
3.(a) depicts indecent or obscene material

(b) describes, depicts, expresses or otherwise deals with matters of sex, drug misuse or addiction, crime, cruelty, violence or revolting or abhorrent phenomena in a manner likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult person
(c) depict in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult a child who is, or who appears to be, under 16 (whether or not engaged in sexual activity)
(d) depicts child abuse
(e) promotes, incites or instructs in matters of crime or violence, or which depicts denigration of religious beliefs
(f) depicts material which is unsuitable for a minor to see or play (definition of `minor' is the same as in the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1994)
and that the legislation ensure
4. that requests for classification by investigating or prosecuting Authorities shall be completed by the Censorship Board within 60 days, and
5. provide that proceedings for an offence under section 1.(a), (b) and (c) may be commenced at any time after the material has been refused classification.
Your petitioners also request that all of the above be included in section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to enshrine legislation containing the above to ensure that the information superhighway be used to contribute beneficial knowledge which will enrich the lives of all Australians.

PETITION.TITLE: Level Crossing: Warnertown
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of South Australia draws to the attention of the House that funding for the installation of active level crossing equipment at Abattoirs Road, Warnertown remains unresolved.

Traffic flows have been steadily increasing over the Warnertown Crossing in recent years and substantial concerns have been identified regarding the safety at the crossing. In June 1994 Warnertown Crossing met the warrant for flashing light control as identified by the State Level Crossing Safety Committee.

In light of such safety concerns and the difficulties in procuring funding to achieve automatic warning devices your petitioners therefore request the House to urge the Government to provide funding for the installation of automatic warning devices at the Warnertown Crossing. Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

BREAK.PARA: Petitions received.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House:
(1) congratulates Romano Prodi, Massimo D'Alema and all members of the Olive Tree coalition for their magnificent win in the Italian general elections;
(2) acknowledges the results as the most significant national success of the political Left in Italy since World War II;
(3) conveys its best wishes for the success of the Government in pursuing social and constitutional reform; and
(4) recognises that this historic change represents a rejection by the Italian electorate of the sterility of political conservatism and a pursuit of political stability.

I would hope that all members of the House would applaud the historic victory that was recorded on 22 April of the Italian left coalition known as the Olive Tree, under the leadership of Romano Prodi. Mr Prodi was named as the Prime Minister designate by the President last Thursday, and he held his first government meeting over the weekend.

The victory of the Olive Tree coalition is probably the most promising development in the Italian political scene in the postwar period. Certainly it represents a deliberate break with the political failures, instability and corruption of the past. There is no doubt that, as my motion expresses, the election outcome represents a rejection by the Italian people of what has proven to be the sterility and the compounding failures of political conservatism. That was best exemplified by the discredited and rejected Right coalition under Silvio Berlusconi, which includes the neo‐fascist national alliance of Gianfranco Fini. Berlusconi is now facing corruption charges.

It has been the domination of the Italian government by right‐wing conservatives which has paralysed the Italian nation for half a century. There is now a chance for it to break out of this stultifying political straitjacket, but it must grasp the opportunity. The longer term interests of the Italian people would have been vastly better served had the Right coalition collapsed and been rejected years ago. Its persistence was due largely to the survival instincts of its self‐seeking participants and to the financial support of powerful backers who recoiled from what they saw as the possibility of a Cuban‐type communist enclave in Western Europe.

I find quite disturbing the recent development in which the Olive Tree coalition has offered to discuss with the right-wing alliance that it take important posts in the new parliament. It will be a pity if the opportunity is lost to develop a two‐party or a two‐bloc system with a clearly defined government and opposition. For everyone to pursue a role in government has been self‐indulgent and destructive. It has been a formula for instability and political failure. Prodi, with minor centre and left party support, can have a working majority. He should use it.

There are at least two reservations about the future survival of the Prodi government. First, the victory was not complete. The Olive Tree is about 30 seats short of an absolute majority in the 630‐member Chamber of Deputies and only has a slight majority in the Senate. Second, in order to honour the clear intention of the Italian people, it is more important that the Olive Tree coalition govern with the support of the Marxist PRC, or the Communist Refoundation, rather than with the support of any of the neo‐fascist elements of the Right. Prodi has confirmed that he will accept the support of the PRC. I believe he should do so. The Prodi government will be the first Italian government in almost 50 years to include ministers from the left of the political spectrum. The defeat of the Right alliance was long overdue. It finally collapsed under the weight of the corruption scandals which engulfed it.

As the motion indicates, it seeks to convey the best wishes of this House for the success of the Prodi government in pursuing social and constitutional reform. This is a magnificent opportunity for it to do so. In pursuing social and economic reform, it is to be hoped that it is not seduced into an economic rationalist approach, with an overdependence on discredited and failed market processes.

BREAK.PARA: Neither Mr Massimo D'Alema, who leads the coalition's biggest faction, the PDS, the Democratic Party of the Left, nor Mr Fausto Bertinotti, who leads the Marxist PRC, should allow the new government to repudiate or retreat from a commitment to real social reform and social justice. It must remain committed to the importance of the public sector and to a comprehensive system of support for those who are economically and socially the most vulnerable.

Constitutional reform is essential. There is an urgent need to simplify Italy's complex electoral system. It has spawned an array of political parties and groupings which have compounded the problems of achieving political stability and continuity. The Prodi government, for example, will be the 55th Italian government since World War II: 55 governments in a period of 51 years. National political instability on such a scale is a recipe for disaster. The disaster has been expressed in the failure of the Italian nation to achieve its potential. It is a tragedy that the excesses and political self‐indulgence of the past are now likely to inhibit the capacity of the new government to embark on a more ambitious reform program.

It will require the not insignificant talents of Mr Prodi, his ministers, the bureaucracy and the monetary authorities to strike the right balance between the objectives of accelerating non‐inflationary growth, reducing Italy's massive public debt, reducing unemployment and constructing a proper social safety net. To achieve this, an honourable compact with the trade union movement is clearly an absolute essential.

Despite some of the more sensational headlines since the Italian elections, it cannot be said that the new Italian government will be dominated by the Left. All that is certain is that a loose coalition of moderates chose to align itself with the Left in order to avoid a repeat of the extreme Right arrangements of the past with their strong neo‐fascist influences. Such an outcome would have been a disaster of significant dimensions; however, the threat still exists. After all, the extreme Right was still able to capture about 40 per cent of the total Italian vote.

One of my major concerns is that this moderate but anti-fascist alliance represented by the Olive Tree coalition may gradually drift to the right. It would be extremely unfortunate if advantage was not taken of the Left contributing to the restructuring of the Italian nation. To allow a slide back to the past would represent a gross betrayal of the clear intentions of the Italian people to break with it. If this opportunity is lost, Italy may yet reap the whirlwind.

The election results indicated that, within the 630-member Chamber of Deputies, the Freedom Alliance won almost 300 seats. The Freedom Alliance, of course, is the old discredited right‐wing conservative Alliance—and, to some extent, neo‐fascist alliance—because it contains within it the neo‐fascist national alliance. In the Senate, that same Freedom Alliance won about 116 out of the 315 seats. The Northern League, the federalist group which is seeking to establish a federal system, achieved 27 seats. Its longer term objective may well also be secession.

The reason the Olive Tree coalition was adopted as the name for that coalition of moderate to Left members of the Italian parliament was that the olive tree is often a symbol for peace. When an aged persons' hostel in my electorate was named after my good friend Mr A.J. Frame last weekend, I was reminded of that when Mr Frame's sister, Mrs Dawn O'Connor, sang the song The Olive Tree. The words and music of the song were written by both Tom Springfield and Diane Lampert. I would like to record these words:
Tell me, white dove, where will I find the olive tree? For just one branch I'd search my whole life through.
I've heard them say a greener land is waiting there where people wake and find their dreams come true.
High flying dove, please lead me and I'll follow you above the clouds, beyond the stormy sea.
I long to share a world of sweet contentment there in that bright land where grows the olive tree.
I hope that all members of this House will wish them well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that everyone in this House recognises the instability that, regrettably, has been latent in Italian politics since World War II. The current government is the 55th Italian government. There has certainly been stability through the bureaucracy and the Bank of Italy. The government itself has been more characteristic of month by month—if not year by year—instability.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the 55th government since World War II, and without doubt therefore this House wishes the new Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, well. We trust that, in the process, the group of people he has formed into a ministry is able to tackle the problems of Italy to give the Italian people and the European community that surrounds them hope for recovery in the major areas that concern them: unemployment, economic instability and corruption in the public sector. It is hoped that the new government is able to overcome these problems and that, for the sake of the surrounding community, Italy is able to be restored to her proper and effective place within the European community.
Having said that, I must admit there are aspects of the motion moved by the honourable member with which I find myself in disagreement. For that reason, I move:
That paragraphs (2), (3) and (4) be omitted from the motion.

I will come back to some of the details of that in a moment. The essential part of the motion that I wish to retain, therefore, is the paragraph which congratulates the government on its win in the election. I suggest that every member of this House would share that sentiment. I point out to my friend the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) that I have difficulties in every circumstance in our telling other countries where to go and how to do it. I suggest that, whatever his views—philosophic or otherwise—it is inappropriate for the members of this parliament to tell the Italians or anybody else how they should run their country. For 13 years the honourable member has been a member of a government that did not know what to do in this country, yet he is trying to tell others what to do in their country.

Leaving politics aside, I do not think it is appropriate for us to intervene in the politics of other countries. We have a right and reason to express our good wishes, to express concerns if those politics in any way intervene in our own relations with those countries, and in other ways to speak of our aspirations together. But I do not think it is appropriate for us to tell them how they should pursue their particular policies.

I think it is also inappropriate for us to talk about the sterility of past governments, whatever their philosophy. This is particularly difficult at a time when, sadly, even this Italian government is not necessarily going to survive, as suggested, because it is a minority government and the alliances upon which it will depend are ones which may or may not survive the political process. The reality of politics in Italy has been such that one cannot be sure of when that will be. So I suggest to this House that it would be far more appropriate if we deleted those particular words.

Let me address a number of issues in the brief time available to me. The first issue is that Italy is demonstrably an important country to Australia. We have many people of Italian descent in Australia. They are excellent Australian citizens and all of us respect the contribution they have made, are making and will make. The nature of our relationship internationally has been one which has seen Italy perhaps subjugated—if I can put it that way—to our relations with the European Community.

Our prime international relationships with Italy have been more in relation to it being a member of the community than perhaps in any other field—other than in the dialogue apropos of those who are now Australian citizens but of Italian descent. But our relations have always been good. On a number of occasions I have met successive presidents and leaders of the Italian government, as well as leading bureaucrats, all of whom I have found very forthcoming and have made a great contribution.

Of course, the Italian community makes an enormous contribution in other areas. If one looks at engineering, fashions, general design, architecture, music and the arts, one will see there is little doubt of that significant and ongoing contribution that the Italians make. If one goes back in history, one will see that even our language is based on so much that emanated from Rome. As far as religion is concerned, while the Vatican City is a separate state, the Vatican is the centre of a religion which represents still a majority of Australian people. In so many ways the Italian connection is important to us—historically and in the future.

But my concern is where Italy goes in its role within the community and how its impact on the community and the relations between the community and Australia affect us. It is in that area that we look very much to Romano Prodi and at the role he is going to play. I was delighted to see the priorities that he gave to his incoming government.

There is no doubt that if you look at those priorities and recognise the extent of unemployment, particularly in the south, you see enormous problems in the structure of the country itself. If one talks about unemployment in Europe, one does not talk about unemployment in the spread across all of Europe. Northern Europe, as with northern Italy, has far less unemployment than southern Italy.

There is an enormous problem in those southern communities stretching down into the area where the Mafia has its sway and into Sicily and Sardinia. There is no doubt that southern Italy is in a state of significant lower economic activity than northern Italy. There industry is less and, although there is an availability of labour, the level of education, the level of skill and the level of employment are less than elsewhere. So there is a difficulty in the regional spread within Italy, and I think that is a major problem for Signor Prodi.

The next difficulty is the unemployment level. While Australia has a high level of unemployment, we are fortunate in that there are signs, I believe, with the election of the Howard government, of our being able to embark on policies appropriate to generate private sector long-term employment again. To my mind, that is another of the failings Signor Prodi is going to face for the future—if the prejudices of his philosophy are to be implemented.

If he follows only public sector employment, there is little doubt that there will still be a question mark. Is there going to be long-term employment? Is there going to be an opportunity for the recovery of the Italian lira? Is there going to be some prospect of stabilising inflation. Inflation, regrettably, has meant that the value of the lira against other major currencies has fallen significantly.

You can get some measure of that if you compare the value of the lira to the American dollar. For example, in 1990 the lira was valued at 1,198.4 and in 1994 it was valued at 1,611.8. In contrast to the pound sterling, the lira was at 2,133.2 in 1990 and 2,467.3 in 1994. In comparison with the Deutschmark, the lira has devalued from 741.6 in 1990 to 994.7 in 1994. When you look at those figures you get some idea of the fundamental problems of a devaluing currency, of high inflation and of high unemployment. Married to all that is the chronic problem of crime, and crime in high places.

For that reason I was particularly pleased to see included amongst the new ministers a former prosecutor who played such an important role in prosecuting some of those within the Mafia who over the years have tragically impeded so much on the credibility and the integrity of the public life of the Italian community. That former prosecutor, of course, is Antonio De Pietro, the prosecutor whose drive against corruption made him a national hero. He is to be the public works minister. Public works is an important area. It is an area where corruption has been endemic. One of the priorities of Prime Minister Romano Prodi is to try to reduce the level of corruption in that field. So I feel that that is a very good appointment.

It is interesting to note the high academic qualifications of others within his ministry. Academic qualifications are all very well, but what is far more important is a bit of practical commonsense. I am apprehensive that, unless that practical commonsense is applied, there will be worries for the future.

BREAK.PARA: It is also of interest—having heard a bit of the ideology of my friend in his moving of the motion—to look at and compare with the Australian Labor Party the appointments in the Olive Tree ministry. The comment is that women did surprisingly poorly in the share‐out. A Progressive Catholic, Rosy Bindi, got the health ministry. But both the other women chosen are ministers without portfolio, with obviously contrived responsibilities—one for equal opportunities and the other for social solidarity, whatever that means. So I am afraid that the socialists, wherever they are, do not seem to think highly of the other sex.

Be that as it may, I think the whole of this House welcomes the election of this new government. We wish them well in their significant tasks and trust that, under the guidance of Prime Minister Romano Prodi, Italy can continue to grow and contribute in political affairs as soundly as it has in the arts, music, culture, design, engineering, fashions and other spheres for so many centuries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment so ably moved by my colleague the right honourable member for New England and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I hear what the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) says in terms of the amendment and other countries but, considering the sanctions on South Africa and a range of other matters concerning countries and many governments and parliaments over many years, it is not at all uncommon for this parliament to express its views—in some many cases it is much more than its views; it is strong positions vis-a-vis—whether it be in relation to Cambodia, Burma or South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: What the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) has put forward in this motion is extremely moderate. Suggesting that some of this is an interference in the Italian political system is somewhat of an exaggeration. I think even people with the strongest of ill-will would have to recognise that.

BREAK.PARA: As has been said earlier, the Italian-Australian connection has been a very powerful one. The contribution of the Italian community to Australian society has been extremely important. In just a few weeks time we will be celebrating the anniversary of the establishment of the republic. On the first Saturday in June the tradition is celebrated in the Hunter. It is a major function and coming together of people of Italian descent and others in the community to celebrate the formation of the republic. Those of Italian descent have a great sense of pride about their contribution to Australia and certainly have an enormous interest in the country.

There is no doubt that a concern to all of us—people in Italy and people in Australia, people of goodwill—has been the instability of the Italian government. The fact that the average life of a government has been only 11 months has not been good and not been thought well of. Following the recent election, there is now great optimism that we will see a longer lasting government.

Amongst the few matters I should mention in terms of the Australian‐Italian connection is that in Newcastle we are currently building minehunters for the Royal Australian Navy which are of Italian design and use a lot of Italian technology. A great interchange of skills and depth of understanding has come from Australians going to Italy to learn and bring back technology and Italians visiting and looking at how we are handling this exercise. It has been a very productive exercise, and we look forward to it developing further.

The motion tries to pick up and make us understand that for the first time since the war there has been a left‐of‐centre success in an Italian election. That is a major change and major departure. Whether or not that is the first swallow to herald a summer of change is yet to be seen, but certainly what is happening in England post Thatcherism and the now debunking and almost embarrassment of the British parliamentary system and certainly the conservative party—they are walking away from their now much discredited philosophy—is interesting.

What is happening in France is interesting, as is what is happening in America, where we saw the great euphoria with Gingrich and the contract with America suddenly collapsing in one giant heap, and the absolute collapse of the `Dole for President' campaign, so much so that he has now resigned his position to concentrate on his election campaign full time.

All these things seem to signal to many of us a change from pushing individual greed, from pushing materialism and from pushing the idea of individualism to looking much more at our need to understand and support each other and that parliaments and governments around the world need to govern for all by all, which means thinking of all and allowing people to see themselves as part of communities and the interdependence that is necessary.

What we have seen for many years, particularly in some of the countries I have mentioned, has been materialistic measuring and countries being run for the economy rather than the people. In Italy the Italian people are now perhaps saying, `We want a country with a government which governs for us and for the economy and works for us—not separate from us.' Those opposite will see in the next few years that what they are putting forward in their rhetoric may well end up causing here the same surge we have seen in Italy in recent months. I join with my colleague in sustaining the motion. I look forward to Italy having not only a strong, stable government but a government that is caring and committed to all people and governing for people rather than for economics. I think the final paragraph is a valid one. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support the amendment moved by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and that part of the motion moved by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) that will be left after this House, if it ever gets the opportunity to vote on this motion, deletes sections (2), (3) and (4) from the motion currently being discussed.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say at the outset that I find it interesting to observe members of the opposition in this place. After 13 years of government, we now find that they are able to come here and be socialists again. When votes on privatisation are taken in the parliament, such as the votes we had a week or so ago in relation to Telstra, we now find members of the Labor Party vote against privatisation, whereas over the last 13 years we have seen many of those same members opposite vote in favour of privatisation. So I think there has been a resurgence of socialism on the other side.

I listened very carefully, as I always do, to the thought‐provoking comments from the honourable member for Charlton. I think he was able to come into his own today. He was able to state the sort of view that he would have liked to have expressed during 13 years of government. I congratulate him on his courage, although it is certainly belated courage we see today from the honourable member for Charlton. The honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) continued in a similar vein.

It would be churlish of anyone in this place to fail to congratulate the new Italian government. As has been said by previous speakers, it is the 55th government in postwar Italian history. It is quite incredible that governments have lasted on average for only 11 months. The right honourable member for New England pointed out that, while governments may have lasted for only a short period, the bureaucracy and the Bank of Italy have provided continuity, which has certainly been absent from the political process.

In many respects it would have been better for this country had the Hawke and Keating governments lasted for only 11 months rather than 13 years. If that had been the case, we certainly would not have the wreckage of the Australian economy that we see today. We certainly would not have Beazley's $8 billion black hole. We certainly would not have unemployment as one of the ongoing national tragedies in Australia.

PARA.BREAK: Today we are dealing with this important motion relating to Italy. The members who have previously spoken have indicated the strength of the Australian‐Italian community and the importance of the enduring connec tion Australia has with Italy. I did, however, find it somewhat interesting when the honourable member for Newcastle defended paragraphs (2), (3) and (4). He said that we have commented on South Africa, Cambodia and Burma. We certainly have, and I am pleased that we have done so. But I do not think one could ever accuse Italy of being in the same category as those three countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Italians have been a very important part of Australia's history. We probably have close to a million Australians today who have some Italian connection. As immigration from Europe declines, undoubtedly the number of Italian born Australians will decline. But when one looks at the impact and contribution of second and third generation Italians, it is very obvious that a substantial connection will continue. It is interesting that the honourable member for Charlton highlights the election victory as an important victory for the political Left. He suggests that the new Italian government is going to achieve what the other 54 governments have failed to achieve since the Second World War.

One ought to appreciate that, while there may have been a multiplicity of governments in Italy, those governments have over the years performed economic miracles. They have certainly rebuilt the Italian economy after the ravages of fascism in the Second World War. Over the years there has been a tremendous growth rate in Italy under conservative leaders. So, while we all join the honourable member for Charlton in congratulating the Olive Tree coalition on its magnificent victory, it ought to be remembered that the government is not stable. It has a bare majority in the lower house. It has a majority in the upper house. The government is a combination of factions. This government could go the same way as other governments. I think we ought to congratulate it and wish it well. We ought to point out to it, though, that socialism is a failed philosophy right across the world. Socialist governments have been collapsing and continue to do so. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I congratulate you on your appointment. This is the first opportunity I have had to do so. The amendment moved by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is a nonsense. He contradicted himself in his own speech. He said that we should not be debating the internal events of other nations. As if we have not done this in this parliament in all the years that he has been here—and he has lasted more years here than anyone! Then he proceeded to explain what was wrong with the new government and its philosophies. I found that to be a bit curious and to be a contradictory argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Putting that aside, the reason we are persisting with the full motion moved by the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is that this signifies a turning point not only in Italian politics but also in Europe. There has been a very strange phenomenon in Europe. There have been primarily conservative governments at the national level; yet at the level of the European Parliament the majority has for some time been with socialists and Left parties.

This paradoxical situation has arisen, strangely enough, because we have had difficulties in the various leftist and socialist and labour and social democratic groupings, especially in Italy, getting their act together, so to speak, and fighting an election in a coherent way. This is what the Olive Tree coalition did in Italy. They did so on the basis of a relatively coherent platform. It was a moderate, socially democratic platform—a platform which, nevertheless, put forward some new ideas which are relevant not only for Europe but also for the social democratic movement throughout the world. It is necessary to have not only a political response to the New Right and the onslaught of conservatism that rose out of Britain particularly and Thatcherism but also to have a philosophical and coherent policy response. This is a challenge which we in opposition will face to build further ideas. Although we recognise that there were many positive ideas put forward by the Australian Labor Party, we also recognise the need for change and the need for further development of human thought, especially from a perspective of progressive political ideas.

BREAK.PARA: The performance of the Italian Olive Tree coalition will be watched by all the other major countries of Europe particularly, because they have a very interesting combination of ideas. First of all, they are pro‐European. They are strongly pro‐European while, at the same time, wishing to assert the importance of social programs and egalitarian values. They are keen to see a united Europe that is playing its role in the world economy. At the same time, they are interested in ensuring there are social programs that protect the poor, that achieve an egalitarian outcome and that provide for Italy a basis for its economic, social and cultural future.

It is not just the Italian community in Australia that is looking at what is happening. All those people who are interested in political developments throughout the world, particularly those of a left or social democratic bent, are interested to see how this coalition is going to put in place a program which is going to work in the context of the international economy and the limitations which the international economy puts into place. The coalition will put forward programs which will protect the poor and which will involve significant redistribution of resources. It will support both the public sector and the private sector—not, as the right honourable member for New England said, `only the public sector'—in a balanced way. It is necessary to have this balance, as it forms the basis of what a good society should be. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Eoin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have great admiration for the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). He is a man who has great respect for the institution of parliament, respect for his political philosophy and respect for the democratic process. He is the type of Labor person that I have always admired. I have always thought those from the left of the Labor Party are the true Labor people—the people who are true to the philosophy on which the Labor Party was built. Sadly—and I mean sadly—for the Labor Party, there are not many people left in the Labor Party like the member for Charlton, and we are seeing others like those in the right of the Labor Party, such as the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith), the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) and the former member for Lilley, who are more like political machines than people with a passion for a philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no hesitation in supporting the first part of the motion. Of course, I would offer my congratulations to any political leader and political party which is democratically elected. I should add that it is a coalition of parties, as other speakers have mentioned today, and differences will no doubt come about. I certainly wish the new Italian government well. I must indicate my disappointment that the member for Charlton did not extend his effusive kindness to the Prime Minister of Australia on his magnificent win.

The amendment of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) is also to be supported. While I have no hesitation in congratulating the Olive Tree coalition, I welcome the omission of the last three parts of the motion of the member for Charlton. While the member for Charlton wants to recognise the results as the most significant national success of the political Left in Italy since World War II, I would not be too excited about the success at this stage as, given the unstable nature of government in Italy since World War II—we have already mentioned there have been something like 55 governments—Lord knows what could be happening in Italy as we speak.

Indeed, if one acknowledges that one‐quarter of the Olive Tree's votes were for the Communist Refoundation Party whose platform has little in common with its coalition partners, then the first hurdle the government approaches where there is a difference of views within the coalition will certainly test the strength of the coalition and the stability of the new Italian government.

The Communist Refoundation Party is dedicated to higher taxes, high government spending on social services, guaranteed employment through state jobs and wage indexation against inflation, and opposes privatisation and development of the European Union.

Romano Prodi has already ruled out wage indexation and real increases in public spending. That shows the difficulties that will be faced by the new government in implementing its program. It requires the support of the Communist Refoundation Party, yet there are differences in their platforms which do not augur particularly well for the stability Italy requires from its government. Italy certainly needs stability and we wish that upon the Italian people.

While the extreme Left is seeking higher government spending on social services—despite Italy's public debt standing at 124 per cent of gross domestic product—Prodi has indicated his opposition to this. I must also question whether the Left have been welcomed with open arms by the Italian people when the mastermind of the Olive Tree, Massimo D'Alema, pushed Romano Prodi as the coalition's candidate for premier because he appealed to moderate voters. `Moderate' is one of my favourite words. That, in itself, is an admission by the coalition that the Left was not fully palatable to the Italian electorate when they required a more centrist candidate to be the face of the party while the backroom boy, the person calling the shots, had his political upbringing in the Communist Party.

The win by the Olive Tree is probably slightly less than magnificent when it requires the amalgamation of eight political parties—all with differences in philosophy—to form the party, particularly when the Communist Refoundation Party has already given Romano Prodi 100 days to perform. That is a threat against the government and a threat against the political stability which the motion infers has come to Italy but appears to be only cosmetic. While Romano Prodi needs the support of the Communist Refoundation Party to carry through the coalition's reform program, there is a threat if Prodi does not compromise with the extreme Left.

While I would welcome political stability in Italy, this motion may be a tad early to celebrate that stability. While I congratulate Romano Prodi, Massimo D'Alema and all members of the Olive Tree on their endorsement through the democratic process, I would not hail it as a victory for the Left or say that it will bring stability to Italy until the government has withstood the test of time. I certainly wish them all the very best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Richard, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) give consideration to the problems associated with the disabling conditions of dyslexia and attention deficit disorders in primary school children;

(2) undertake to heighten the awareness of the prevalence and the adverse effects of learning and behaviour/attention disorders, in particular raising Government awareness that a significant percentage of primary school children are unable to benefit from current classroom instruction in the early years of school as a result of learning and attention disorders and that subsequently this population is found unable to benefit from secondary education; and

(3) conduct an inquiry through the relevant parliamentary standing committee into these disorders and their effects with a view to recommending preventive and remedial measures which will enable child learning and attention disability to be addressed optimally and that the terms of reference cover but not necessarily be restricted to:

(a) the incidence, within the Australian primary school population, of learning disorders consistent with the diagnostic category of dyslexia and attention deficit disorder or subtypes of these disorders;
(b) the findings which correlate learning disorder/behavioural/attention disorder and illiteracy;
(c) the findings which correlate illiteracy/behavioural/attention disorder with the adolescent problems of unemployment, crime and youth suicide; and
(d) the methods by which these disorders are currently treated and the facilities available to the classroom teacher to provide beneficial instruction.

The nearest thing to a learning difficulty that most adults in this chamber come to experience is finding their way around the maze of corridors in this building in their first few months as a member. I am sure that many of these, dare I say, lost souls find comfort in knowing that help is at hand and that an attendant or others who could assist are only a phone call away. However, imagine for a moment being lost in this great building knowing you are not able to access one person for assistance or, worse still, not having the skills to ask in the first place. Such is the life, frustration and poor skill base of a sufferer of the mental condition commonly known as attention deficit disorder or ADHD.

Most of us know of this disorder not by name but by its consequences. The consequences of ADHD manifest themselves through a number of society's ills. We are all too well aware of increasing school failures, increasingly unemployable people with poor employment prospects, social aggression and vandalism, antisocial behaviour and domestic violence, psychiatric disorders, either diagnosed or suspected, and aggravated sleep and appetite disorders—and the list goes on. These should not be considered mainstream behaviours of our society. In fact, they are linked directly to attention deficit disorder.

ADHD has also been linked directly to communal behaviour. Dr John Yu, the Australia Day Council's 1996 Australian of the Year, called ADHD the hidden handicap in Australia. From speaking with families, sufferers and teachers, this is most appropriate. However, in saying this we must never lose sight of the fact that ADHD sufferers are not necessarily incapable of learning, have lower intelligence or should be considered intellectually disadvantaged. In many cases, the opposite can, and may, apply.

With the evidence already presented over the past two years to this House by me and by others, Mr Deputy Speaker, you do not need me to reiterate that the problem is enormous. In fact, we have only touched the tip of the medical iceberg. On several occasions a number of members on both sides have discussed and debated this, and have offered comments, suggestions and support.

However, the time for rhetoric is passed and we must now put national interests—the particular interests of children and young Australians—before the interests of any faction or party, or any personal agenda. This cannot be achieved in isolation. Indeed, in many respects we, the elected members of parliament, as the representatives of our respective electorates are only the conduit for community demands.

The simple truth is that the parents of either diagnosed or suspected sufferers should now take up the challenge before them and finally get some real action and some real answers. I hope that for ADHD parents this is the final challenge of what have been many challenges. We all know that it is the loudest voice that gets heard. However, the loudest voice is often not backed by the most people. On many occasions it is the most organised voice—the voice that uses the media to advantage, the voice that uses networks, associations, friends and family to spread the word—that is heard.

Parents of ADHD sufferers are not yet known for their assertiveness. Their needs are not yet recognised. They are not yet acknowledged for the important role they play in ensuring that their children are not placed on the drop‐out statistics—or even worse. These parents often go through great confusion and a feeling of lack of empowerment. They are in a state of frustration, simply not knowing the best thing to do at various times. They are likely to be on the defensive when dealing with the comments and criticism of others.

According to Dr Julia Solomon, a leading clinical psychologist with expertise and a passionate interest in ADHD, parents of sufferers now must be more accountable. They must ask for more information about their child's condition; they must ask for and seek out alternatives on how to manage it; they must be treated as partners with teachers in dealing with their children; and they must be given knowledge of the research and theory that validate whatever practices are being used for their children.

I am talking about empowerment for parents and families. Without putting too fine a point on it, parents should consider bringing together all the support groups and forming an ADD action group. It would be a group with members from around Australia, not information deprived but with resources, information and the expertise to deal with ADD and, more importantly, plan strategies for diagnosis and treatment. ADD and ADHD are national disorders. We can no longer pretend that they do not exist. We can no longer label them as yet another yuppie disorder. No longer can we let our children suffer.

In this House we can debate the definitions of ADD and ADHD, we can talk about the causes and solutions; but no‐one can deny that research into ADHD, its causes, symptoms, effects and treatment has snowballed in the last seven years or so. In this time we have established several significant indicators which are accepted as true and on which we base much of our current thinking.

ADHD is a biologically based, often hereditary, neurological development disorder. It affects at least five per cent of children and at least two to three per cent of adults. Some 50 per cent to 60 per cent of children will continue to have the disorder into adult life. Less than 10 per cent of affected Australian children are receiving appropriate medical attention and very few adults receive medical attention. People with ADHD are very likely to suffer from a whole range of disabilities which have adverse effects. Most professionals lack training and experience in this area, and clients and patients are unlikely to obtain the important practical services they require.

On several occasions I have mentioned to the parliament the symptoms of ADHD. These are now part of the public record and are easily accessible. What have yet to be stressed and acknowledged are the depressing conditions associated with this condition. They can significantly affect sufferers in family situations, at school and at work, and in the broader community. We have a long way to go. However, we do need to make a start. This, I believe, is best done in the formative primary school years which are the years when the condition first becomes public, outside the confines of home and family.

We are aware that ADHD is a neurological disorder linked to human brain development in the first eight years of life and linked to chemical imbalances. There is no education for or information available to parents or teachers which explains a child's neurological development or how to determine the levels of neurological development of a child. There is no information provided to parents or teachers on how to note ADHD risk factors and what to do if there are risk factors.

One of the tragic results of this lack of knowledge is that, as educators of young children, teachers and parents can be unwittingly producing ADHD problems and learning difficulties which result in the symptoms consistent with the learning disorder dyslexia. I do not for one minute think that teachers or their methods of instruction are at fault but there is an urgent need for teachers to have some knowledge of neuropsychology. This would assist them in understanding more about brain development, which would help them to understand more about the individual learning needs of children. This, in association with learning theories, would go far in their gaining control of the learning environment in the classroom.

While the education of society remains the responsibility of government, such demands involve a commitment by the government to change and innovate. I believe that Australians rightly insist that the allocation of funds to specific educational needs have adequate justification. Such an allocation must be the outcome of a proper inquiry into the issue by a government committee charged with the responsibility of undertaking a sound assessment of needs, possible outcomes and solutions. It would need to collate available data, consult widely with experts, teachers, families and sufferers; and realistically assess the impact of ADHD on Australians of all ages.

The impact of ADHD on our general society appears to be reaching a level which can no longer be tolerated. In my view, an inquiry that would investigate practical remedies to this crippling aspect of the Australian future is urgent. In saying this, I respectfully suggest that the federal parliament give consideration to the problems associated with the disabling condition of dyslexia and ADHD in primary school children; undertake to heighten the awareness of the prevalence of, and adverse learning effects of, learning behaviour and/or attention disorders; and conduct an inquiry through the relevant parliamentary standing committee into these disorders.

It is an important matter. We cannot continue to ignore it. We have had some inquiries on different things. We had some inquiries on truancy last year but did not consider ADD as a factor in truancy. I am calling upon the chairman of the appropriate parliamentary committee to consider an inquiry into this condition because I think it is important for our children. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion and congratulate the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) on moving it. The problems of dyslexia and attention deficit disorder (ADD) are now well documented. A lot of work has been done, particularly in respect of children at primary school age, both in Australia and overseas. The sooner there is heightened awareness of these conditions among health and education administrators and in society generally, the better we will be able to address the problems. Early identification of the problems is essential and, as with any condition, early treatment is vital.

SPEECH.PARA: The tragedy of the disabilities and, in particular, attention deficit disorder is that the disability is likely to be worse in a stressed or disorganised environment. Those stresses on family life can result from unemployment or from the demands upon a working mother who has a task of maintaining a family and, at the same time, earning a living, which is now a widespread phenomenon. The unfortunate reality is that, as a result of their economic circumstances, it is often the case that families under stress are the least likely to be able to afford appropriate treatment for their children.

As I mentioned, early screening for the disabilities is essential. The sooner a child is able to access treatment, whether it be behavioural or, if necessary, by way of medication, the sooner a child will be able to adjust to new environments that they confront, such as a new school environment, and the ability to establish appropriate peer group interaction. The unfortunate reality is that there remains a lack of consistent information for our teachers and there are still no measures in place for early screening of children to identify whether they have these conditions of dyslexia or attention deficit disorder.

Until a proper diagnosis is made the child, the child's parents, and often the teacher, can come to the conclusion that the child is either unintelligent, naturally disruptive and/or naturally aggressive as a result of these conditions. The tragedy is that the child himself then starts to accept the brand that he has been given and his behaviour becomes a self‐fulfilling prophesy.

Early intervention is essential to prevent that occurring. And, indeed, teachers or school support staff need to be appropriately trained and assured of their legal protections in their role in assisting children with disabilities, including perhaps administering medication. The consequences of not treating these conditions are in many ways self‐evident. But, for instance, in the case of attention deficit disorder there is considerable literature to indicate the prevalence of persistent social disorder on the part of sufferers. Specifically, it is estimated that between 50 per cent and 75 per cent of untreated ADD sufferers will have an experience with the criminal justice system.

Perhaps more depressing is the fact that it is well documented that those suffering from ADD who are of a withdrawn or depressed personality will suffer a suicide rate of approximately 25 per cent. Aside from the tragic human cost, the costs to society of not treating these disorders is immeasurable.

Even when the question is approached from the point of view of our modern obsession with economic rationalism, it is the case that with early intervention and appropriate treatment we can assist these children to become decent, successful and taxpaying citizens. The costs of not addressing the problem are self‐evident.

From the point of view of employability, it is accepted that if a child leaves school at the age of 16 or later and has not achieved a reading level of age 12½ to 13 years, they are not going to be employable in anything other than a manual capacity. They will not be able to undertake TAFE courses nor will they be able to undertake trade apprenticeships.

The government has just announced a program to develop literacy, which of course is to be encouraged. But such a program cannot be successful in isolation from addressing these significant disabilities of dyslexia and attention deficit disorder because any attempt to address a symptom, namely, illiteracy, without addressing what in many instances will be the cause of the symptom will be ineffective.

The failure to properly address these conditions and resultant illiteracy will result in a whole generation leaving school, in this computer age, probably unemployable and may well perpetuate inter‐generational poverty. The literature indicates that treatment of these conditions may require a three‐pronged attack, namely, medication, behavioural treatment, together with occupational or special learning assistance.

Even if a parent is fortunate enough to access such a composite range of treatment, it results in massive costs. It is not unusual for costs of up to $5,000 to be incurred in the treatment of one child. Clearly, poorer families are just not going to have the money available to afford such treatment.

We as politicians commonly hear and indeed commonly use, on both sides of this House, the rhetoric of respecting, fostering and nurturing the family unit. The reality is, we seldom do anything constructive in that endeavour. This motion is an exception; it is a genuine attempt to make a difference to traumas confronting not only many children but also many adults and indeed many families as a whole. The honourable member for Cowan is to be congratulated on raising this very important matter on the floor of the House, as clearly greater awareness is needed.

I recently interviewed a constituent who took her child off the Ritalen medication which had been prescribed because she had heard a well‐known radio commentator attack the condition of ADD. To use her words, `I took her off it because truck drivers use it.' This little nine‐year‐old girl was continuing to eat her school lunch on her own and experience complete peer group isolation without hope of a solution because of cynicism which still exists in society—a cynicism which is unfortunately exacerbated by many sectors of the media. For instance, Medicare benefits for neurometrics testing were withdrawn last year following an ABC Four Corners report broadcast on 27 February.

Following the removal of benefits for neurometrics testing we are faced with a ludicrous situation where a similar QEG test, but based on different computer software, remains on the Medicare schedule. It remains so more because it seemed to be outside journalistic scrutiny rather than any more logical analysis. Clearly, such a logical analysis is required and that is sought in this motion.

There is a need for an inquiry through the relevant parliamentary standing committee as proposed in the motion if only to once and for all jolt the community into addressing these problems. It is wrong—indeed, it is cruel—for supposed media experts to attempt to make parents feel neurotic and/or inadequate because their children suffer from these conditions when they are attempting as best they can to do something about it.

At the same time, there is a need to examine the adequacy of assistance provided to parents in terms of the Medicare rebate for both diagnostic tests and medication and the provision of assistance for specialist areas not covered by Medicare rebate—for instance, psychologists, occupational therapists and remedial teaching experts. There is also a need for appropriate early intervention in our school system which both respects a child's right to dignity and privacy and enables access to appropriate treatment.

We are talking about an extremely widespread phenomenon. As the member for Cowan indicated, it is estimated that up to five per cent of children have it. If we do not address these conditions we are losing a significant benefit that we would otherwise gain for this future generation and, indeed, for generations following that. I wholeheartedly support and congratulate the member for Cowan on this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend and support the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) in moving this motion. I referred to learning disabilities in my first speech and drew a connection between them and a young person's future prospects in life. Mindful of the time, I will perhaps enjoy the opportunity to deliver the full version of the speech at another time. I think I have about five seconds to go. I would like to support the member for Cowan, as this motion is a constructive step in transforming community concerns into better government policy and life outcomes for a significant group in our community.
