That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —By a series of measures the coalition has effectively ended the policy of bipartisanship on immigration and multicultural affairs which has persisted since the time of former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser. Blow by blow still falls. Hot on the heels of revelations in the leaked cabinet document that Minister Ruddock prepared in which he proposed cuts to the refugee and humanitarian program we now discover that there is to be closure of regional offices and overseas offices in the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs which will be draconian in their impact.

SPEECH.PARA: In a minute from the departmental secretary, staff of the department are advised that the department will be moving to close regional offices in Townsville, Newcastle, Chatswood, Wollongong, Sunshine and Geelong. Staff are notified that all closures will be given effect to no later than Christmas of this year.

This further blow, which has a much more dramatic consequence than would have been the case had the department remained as it was formerly—responsible for immigration—is greater now because of the fact that it is obliged to take over the responsibilities of multicultural affairs. The office that was formerly in the Prime Minister's department has been transferred to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs but with no funding. To confirm that fact, the minute from the office of the secretary provides that these cuts that are being made to the staff—170 staff members being lost—are required not only because of the cuts in running costs and savings that were projected by the coalition in the lead-up to the election, but also because they have to make provision for the assumption of responsibilities for the functions of the Office of Multicultural Affairs.

So what we have now is a department which is supposed to be able to carry through a program of access and equity which was endorsed by members of both sides of this parliament, including the now minister, without the capacity to do so. Instead of there being offices on the ground throughout regional Australia, we have a suggestion that it might be served by telephone links. But how can it possibly be concurrent with the added responsibilities of the office of the minister that he perform those functions without staff available throughout regional Australia and with the added responsibilities of coordination that his office is supposed to take up?

Blow by blow is falling on what was formerly a settled position between government and the opposition. We start with the demise of the Office of Multicultural Affairs, which was intended to be able to coordinate across all agencies of government policies that enabled there to be an effective response to those who come to Australia from other backgrounds, particularly those who still have limited fluency in English. People who have arrived in this country need to be given opportunities to find employment, to make their home here and to prove part of an economic success. That is why they have come here.

The access and equity strategy, which was endorsed by both sides of this House, cannot be implemented effectively in an environment where the minister for immigration has that responsibility rather than an office with central coordinating functions in the Prime Minister's department.

As well as that, there has been hypocrisy and deceit in relation to the question of those who have believed the coalition's election commitments that there would be no cuts to the humanitarian and refugee program. In fact, there will be a very substantial reduction. The baseline program was 13,000 in the humanitarian program, with 4,000 refugees. It is certainly true that that program was increased by 2,000 to cope with the crisis in the former Yugoslavia, but anyone who was part of the community seeking reassurances from the coalition that they would maintain the humanitarian and refugee program would have understood the coalition's commitment that there would be no reduction to mean that that 13,000 baseline program would stand and the 4,000 refugee component would not be reduced. There is a direct admission from the minister himself in the leaked cabinet document that those assurances can no longer be met. He says in that document:

My proposal to reduce the size of the Humanitarian Program, with the consequent reduction in the Refugee component, will bring into question our election commitment `not to reduce the refugee component and to emphasise the role of assisting genuine refugees.'

Then, of course, the submission canvasses how that breach of the government's election commitment could be camouflaged or best put for public presentation. That is the kind of approach we are seeing now. It is ethically and morally bankrupt. Deceit is being practised in an area where there had previously been bipartisanship.

The final area where it is crucial that we identify a problem with the administration of this department is in the new‐arrivals situation. It is certainly true that in the election the coalition flagged that they would be seeking to withdraw the availability of benefits for new arrivals, but in their costings they estimated those savings at some $616 million.

Since their coming to office, they would have received information and briefings from the department estimating the savings at substantially less. The brief to the incoming Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) estimates that, rather than $616 million of savings, this will represent $259.1 million of savings, even if accompanied by the most draconian application of a safety net for those whose circumstances unavoidably change. With oncosts, the overall shortfall that the coalition have between their pre-election estimates of savings and those which would appear now to be available to them would be something in the order of $374 million.

That is why the minister is now being forced to make these draconian and quite uncivilised cuts to programs which no-one in this House could have regarded as justifiable prior to the election. If any spokesperson for the coalition had stood forward before the last election and said that what they were intending to do to the refugee and humanitarian program was to actually propose a reduction to a baseline of 10,000, and next year reduce the refugee component from 4,000 to 3,335, they would have been hounded down. But instead they exercised a deceit on the Australian public.

If it is now true that, as a result of the leaking of those documents, their pledges will be maintained, I will be extraordinarily grateful. But the proof of the pudding of that will be whether we see a program which maintains that baseline of a 13,000 humanitarian program and a 4,000 refugee component.

In conclusion, today's grievance debate is a very sad occasion. In the past, debates on immigration and multicultural affairs have not been occasions, in the main, for a division of this nature and of this bitterness. But that wedge is now firmly in place in the Australian community and it is there because of the deceit and the wrongful and hypocritical approach of the government as it goes about making these savings measures because it got its costings wrong on key policy proposals before the election. The government is having to renege and breach its election commitments after its election. It is an exercise which members on both sides of this House should note and go to the minister and say, `We will not stand for these consequences. They affect the most vulnerable in our community.' (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I grieve for all those Australians of whatever age or whatever background who have inadequate literacy skills. I grieve for those children, those young people and those adults who are unable to read or write in English at a standard comparable to their peers or at a level to allow them to fully participate in the life of their nation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 36th Parliament, the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training brought down two reports which have driven the issue of literacy very strongly throughout the decade of the 1990s. The first of those reports, entitled Literacy needs in the workplace: words at work, was a report into literacy needs in the workplace. It was a report of literacy inadequacies in our existing adult population.

During that inquiry, we interviewed many Australians at many workplaces around the nation and found that far too many Australians had difficulty doing a proper job at work because of their inability to read properly. They had difficulty in being able to fully participate in society because of not being able to access simple things, understanding the language on a television program or going to a movie and completely understanding what the language was all about.

During the inquiry I took the opportunity to ask of everyone who appeared before us: given that we accept we have an unacceptably high level of people in society with poor literacy skills, are we still growing the problem in our schools? Mr Deputy Speaker, I can tell you that substantive evidence was received by the committee that we were then still growing the problem, but no submission and no witness was able to quantify that judgment. A number of submissions and witnesses claimed that a change in teaching methodology in primary school reading programs both had been inappropriate and had acted to put at risk a substantial percentage of students in the first three years of primary school.

The second report, entitled The literacy challenge, brought down and tabled in May 1993, was a report on the strategies for early intervention for literacy and learning for Australian children. It was, in fact, an inquiry into early language development of our young students.

We have a problem which desperately needs to be addressed: there are far too many Australians who cannot truly participate because they cannot read or write at the level of their peers. In order to address that problem, we need to bring to national attention the exact circumstances of our failure in teaching young people those skills they so desperately need to have.

In the first report, Literacy needs in the workplace: words at work, I recommended that there be a series of national testing beginning at age 7, grade 3, grade 5, and continuing, in order to find out exactly where we stood and, once knowing where we stood, then being able to address the problem. My colleagues on the other side of the committee—that is to say, the Labor Party members of the committee—rejected all those recommendations, so I had to bring down a dissenting report. Their rejection, I think, was for ideological reasons which, to some extent, still seem to exist in Australian society today. Those reasons really are encapsulated by the teachers and teacher unions for some reason or series of reasons being unconvinced that testing can occur without testing their ability or their results in transferring knowledge or learning to their students.

Literacy skills—learning to read and learning to write—are very difficult to acquire. They do not occur naturally. As we grow up at home we learn to speak in the tongue of our parents, and we learn to speak in the tongue of our peers. But there is no set mechanism that teaches us how to transfer the sounds of the spoken word or speech into symbols or the written word that has the same meaning as those sounds. So we have to have strategies, methodology, applied from the teacher to the student to direct and help the student grasp the meaning of letters and the meaning of words in writing—and the ability then to hear words and transform those back onto a piece of paper, or whatever, in written form.

In The literacy challenge, several of my colleagues and I brought down another set of dissenting recommendations. Once again, those recommendations said that we needed to address this issue of testing in an international sense. We said that two specific things really needed to occur. The first was that all literacy training should include specific instruction in decoding skill acquisition and spelling. We thought it important that students learn how to transform a letter and the sound of a letter, in combination with other letters, into a word and the sound of that word.

We further recommended that the Commonwealth finance, through the Australian Education Council, national assessment of reading, writing and mathematic skills for attainment of all primary school students prior to completion of year 3 and that the results of the national assessment be reported. It is important that we as a nation compare ourselves to other nations; that we have some idea of whether our expenditure in educating young people is achieving results. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we do ourselves immense harm by failing even one student, one young person, and denying them what ought to be a basic right of theirs—to learn how to read and write in the language of the nation.

In The literacy challenge, my colleagues and I said that it is unacceptable that 10 to 20 per cent of children are finishing primary school with literacy problems; it is also unacceptable that the actual numbers of children with such problems are not known. We were appalled that during the inquiry state, territory and Commonwealth education authorities were unable to tell the committee, with any degree of accuracy, the extent of the problem as it exists in primary schools because most systems do not test basic skills on a systemic basis. It appears, however, that numbers could be as high as 25 per cent of

BREAK.PARA: the students. It may represent the majority of school populations in some education districts.

I am pleased to tell the House that, since that report and the national outcry which followed its being brought down, there has been a sea change in terms of acceptance at the state level of some systematic form of testing of literacy skills and at an early age. New South Wales began, under the Greiner government in 1990, to test students at years 3 and 5; Queensland has now begun to do a safety net check of students at year 2 and it tests completely at year 6; the Northern Territory assesses years 5 and 7 in both basic literacy and numeracy; Western Australia is in the process of introducing at primary level a systematic test to back up its anecdotal test, if that is what it can be called, where it surveys teachers and asks for their opinion on how their students are doing; South Australia has, in the last 12 months, introduced at primary level a series of literacy tests amongst a great controversy, largely emanating from the school community; Tasmania now uses basic literacy and numeracy tests at primary level, and that system is currently under review; Victoria, of course, has the LAP test at years 3 and 5; and the ACT is the only one that is missing out.

I am pleased to tell the House that the Commonwealth will now institute a survey form of testing nationally which will encompass 9,000 students across Australia—4,500 from year 3 and a comparable number from year 5. Five hundred of each group will be Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander students. Parents will have the right to decide whether or not they wish their child to participate. It is certainly hoped at the Commonwealth level that we finally, year after year, begin to build a database on how well we are transferring information to our young students, how literate they are becoming and what chances they will have in the future in terms of jobs and further education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance relates to the damage being caused to Newcastle and the Hunter Valley by this new government. Before going into detail about individual programs, I want to put in perspective the nonsense being uttered about the deficit. The first point the community must recognise is that $4 billion of the $8 billion deficit comes from the government's uncosted promises. The refusal of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to give details of the finance costings confirms this. If there is not a gap in their costings, why do they not produce them? I will read into Hansard an excerpt of a letter by Fred Argy, Fred Gruen and John Nevile, all distinguished economists, in today's Financial Review which puts this into perspective. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: But, it is neither necessary nor desirable to seek to reduce discretionary spending by $8 billion over the next two years simply because the economy is forecast to grow more slowly. If the economy is indeed slowing down, such a policy may well slow it down further and increase unemployment in the short term, while helping neither the fiscal deficit nor the national saving rate.

Three of the country's most eminent economists are saying that what is being put forward is neither good economics nor good policy. This is also a massive breach of faith. The shadow minister for immigration and multicultural affairs, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), advised the House this afternoon of the impending closure of six offices of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs—Townsville, Newcastle, Chatswood, Wollongong, Geelong and Sunshine. These offices are in regional Australia.

Anybody north of the Sydney Harbour Bridge who needs to talk to someone from the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs will have to go to Sydney. The office in Newcastle, which has a staff of nine, has done an enormous job. They service 50 or more people in person and more than 100 phone calls a day. Those people will now have to go to Sydney to talk to anybody from the department. The idea that they can do it by telephone is a nonsense.

The hypocrisy that is rampant is reinforced when one recognises that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) took part last year, along with me, in an inquiry into access and equity for people from non-English speaking backgrounds. At the hearings all over Australia he kept insisting that the previous government was not doing the right thing for the migrant community in terms of access and equity. He is now taking away access for virtually one million people. Townsville is further from Brisbane than Brisbane is from Canberra and yet that office is closing. Why does the minister not close the Brisbane office and have the people there deal with Canberra? That is the next step.

The Labor government spent years building and establishing services for regional communities and it is not an understatement to say that that is all being wound back. Let us look at other areas. We hear the throwaway line about the 12 per cent cut to university funding. The university in Newcastle has a budget from the Commonwealth of about $130 million a year. A 12 per cent cut in funding to that university amounts to about $15 million. The effect that will have on jobs in Newcastle will be enormous, let alone the effect it will have on academic standards and confidence.

Working Nation provided about $130 million to help the long-term unemployed in the Hunter. The projected cuts in that respect are in the order of $20 to $30 million. That also means a reduction in the number of people employed to run the program as well as, more importantly, a reduction in the number of people the program helps. We saw the appalling performance today in terms of barrier controls for the Customs Service. Newcastle is a major port. The Customs Service is being cut even further. We have argued for years that it has been cut too much already. This government is talking about being good managers.

In the life of the previous government the number of Commonwealth public servants employed in my electorate alone increased by 1,300. On my estimation, between a quarter and a third of those will now go. They were permanent jobs that employed locals. Graduates of our university could actually stay in Newcastle and work rather than go to Sydney. This government has the hide to talk about the fact that they represent regional Australia. When those in regional Australia understand what they are about—when they understand this slash and burn philosophy and ideology—they might change their minds about how wise they were.

The idea that somehow this is all necessary because of economics is absolute nonsense. These decisions were made years ago. This is not some reaction to present circumstances. Canberra will be frozen up until post‐budget. Who in Canberra is going to buy a car, a house or spend any money by choice when in August their jobs may go? They are jobs in the public sector as well as the private sector. Business people are not going to make decisions until they know what the budget involves.

Anybody associated with any of the Commonwealth programs, departments, universities or services in Newcastle will hold back. Those three professors pointed out this morning quite aptly that this kind of policy will slow down the economy further, create more unemployment and create more panic. Why on earth would a new government set out to frighten everybody for the next four months? What is the logic behind that? What is the policy behind that?

The idea of trying to hide behind some mantra about a black hole deficit is not biting out there and it lacks credibility. The fact that these professors put their names on a letter to a newspaper confirms that. If this government had any economic credibility at all we would not have these three professors putting themselves forward in this way.

What we are seeing is ideology gone berserk. We are seeing an approach to the Australian economy of slash and burn which has long‐term consequences and really does bring into question the understanding and philosophy of those opposite. I watched with great interest the first speeches of so many people from regional Australia and I watched them espouse how their government was going to help. What I want to tell them now is that, back in 1986, a previous minister for immigration made a similar decision, and the backbenchers from regional Australia had it reversed.

BREAK.PARA: It was announced that the Newcastle office for immigration, as it was then, and for ethnic affairs was to be closed in 1986 in the budget. That decision was reversed because we would not tolerate it. I suggest that those on the back benches of the government now should have enough gumption to do the same thing as we did 10 years ago. If they do not, the long‐term effects of contracting services back to capital cities will be both morally and ethically wrong.

People living in Newcastle are entitled to a service—as they are in Maitland, Cessnock or anywhere else up the valley. To go to Sydney to talk to a departmental officer is impossible for many people. As for the idea of doing it by telephone, I refer members to the Hansard of the parliamentary inquiry when the now minister was questioning people about the suitability of telephone services for ethnic affairs. Look at what he was saying and what he was asking when he was questioning them about the efficiency of the telephone translation service. He has got the hide to come forward now and say that not just interpreter services, which are complex and difficult to provide, but also fundamental migrant visas, extensions of visas, applications and sponsorships—all those things which are so day‐to‐day that people see access to them as a fundamental right—will be gone.

As well as that, of course, they are plugging away at all the other ethnic community support services which the department does so well. These people are good people. They have done a great job in my part of the world. They deserve to stay there—and, just as importantly, the people deserve that service. For this government to stand there and posture the way it does is in fact hypocritical. I suggest to the people in the government who live in regional Australia that you should watch out, because your services are going, in the same way as ours have been marked for closure. As they start to go, do not start lecturing us about the reasons. The reasons are the ideology of the cabinet. If you do not sort them out soon, the question of who controls whom is well and truly answered. Today is a day of enormous grievance, and people in Newcastle and the Hunter will be absolutely outraged when they realise what has been decided by the minister and by this absolutely hypocritical government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to grieve today about the legacy left to my constituents by Labor governments, both federal and state. The honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) was talking about what has to happen, and was complaining about the impact of what has to happen; but of course it has to happen because of what his previous government did. I want to talk about what has to happen and its impact on my constituents, and I want you to be well aware of some of the impact that his government has caused this government to have to make. The reality is that when you are going bankrupt you have got to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: My experience is that Labor governments around the world, not just federal and state, all seem to have the same fatal flaw. I come originally, of course, from the UK—as many in this chamber will know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to talk about the Westminster Council?

—Of course, the Westminster Council was a very good example of not being able to balance the books, and I thank the honourable gentleman from Reid for reminding me of it. But I also was brought up and lived much of my adult life through, for example, the Labour years of the Wilson government. The whole process of the Labour Party in the UK was one of levelling down of doctrine rather than one of results. In fact I suppose I could even describe myself as, to a certain extent, a refugee from the Labour governments of the United Kingdom. That was not the only reason that I came here; there were very positive reasons too.

SPEECH.PARA: My electorate of Aston, in the outer eastern suburbs of Melbourne, has a lot of young families, a lot of young people who need jobs, and a lot of small businesses. These are the very areas that the previous government in fact attacked quite viciously in terms of the policies that they implemented. Victoria sustained bad government not only from the previous federal Labor government but also from the previous state Labor government, the Cain‐Kirner government, which tried very hard to bankrupt the state. Jeff Kennett and his government have spent a lot of time—and there has been a lot of pain for the people—sorting out that mess.

To talk about federal issues, what we see from the previous federal Labor government are unemployment rates in my electorate that are 658 per cent higher than when the Labor Party came into power. Twenty‐eight per cent of youth are unemployed in my area. The impact on mature‐age people who have lost their jobs through all the small business closures has been quite a damaging social phenomenon. Small businesses have been struggling. There have been record bankruptcies, and the high interest rate regimes have been absolutely disastrous as well. There have been a whole host of problems associated with the social welfare situation and the inefficiencies and the inequitable way in which it has operated.

It all means that not only have we had those problems in the community but we have also come to government and found the $8 billion black hole. I am not going to go again through the pros and cons of that, as it has been well rehearsed in this place; but there is a need to stop the debt getting worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —`Rehearsed' is the operative word.

—It has been gone through repeatedly and in great detail. For the benefit of the member for Chifley, I refer him to the Hansard where the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has given a very detailed and very explicit explanation of what the $8 billion black hole is—Beazley's black hole—an explanation which, when you were in government, your government was not prepared to do before the election, I would remind you. What that means is that a number of programs, which are good programs, might well come under review, and I want to spend much of my time this afternoon talking about a couple of those programs.

BREAK.PARA: We have already announced that we will be, unfortunately, having to do away with the DIFF program. It will be a sad day for Australia when the DIFF program, which is the development finance structure part of the aid program—in other words, soft loans to overseas countries where they use Australian companies to implement projects—is abandoned. A company called Data Electronics in my electorate has said:
We were about to finalise a contract to supply $4.5 million of flood monitoring equipment to the Ministry of Water Resources in China.
And:
The cancellation of DIFF means that we will no longer be able to compete with European, US and Japanese companies who have this type of aid funding available to them.

If it were not for the disastrous state of the economy that the previous government left for this government, we would not have to be cancelling this sort of project. The member for Chifley, instead of sitting there now making a lot of hot air, would have been better advised making sure that his government kept the country solvent when they were in power.

It is not only a question of DIFF itself and the damage that is doing to companies in my electorate and elsewhere across the country. Of course, the mere fact that we have to take these sorts of measures is not going to do our relationship with other countries, particularly around Asia, any good either. For example, an article in the Financial Review of just a few days ago talked about the scrapping of DIFF drawing a backlash from Asia, and a number of countries are complaining about that. The reality is, of course, that this is a result of your inheritance. You should face up to it because you have actually caused the country damage in the past and there is an ongoing legacy which we are going to have to deal with.

Apart from DIFF, of course, there is also some speculation about the EMDG scheme. I do not know whether EMDG is going to be affected in the budget on 20 August. Of course you do not know, in the same way that I do not know, but there has been speculation. I want to make some comments about EMDG because it seems to me that that is another scheme, if it comes under the hammer, that will be directly attributable to the financial shambles that the other side left behind.

I have a company in my electorate called Jardan Design Pty Ltd, which manufactures furniture. Jardan is a manufacturer of high quality furniture and it distributes it right throughout Australia. In May last year, it was successful in obtaining its first major export order to Japan. That represented a shipment of two 40‐foot containers per month. That has given the company confidence to expand its product line and concentrate more of its efforts towards developing and expanding its potential markets in South-East Asia. It was pleased to report, in a letter to me recently, that this has already resulted in orders from five new export customers in the past year. From its point of view, therefore, it has been able to put on additional employees and grow its business, and that growth in its business is going overseas. It has been able to do this with the assistance that it received through Austrade and its eligibility for EMDG.

It seems to me that, if we have to take financial measures in respect of programs like DIFF and EMDG, we need to make sure that it is clearly understood in the community that these are not things that we want to do but things that we have to do because of the financial irresponsibility of the previous government. That is not just a general political point. It will have an actual impact on the constituents in my electorate, it will affect real jobs in my electorate, as we clear up the mess that has been created by the other side.

Apart from the problems of finance that the other side left behind for us, there are a couple of other things I would mention that were major omissions in their administration that affect my constituents. The first is their failure to effectively deal with issues such as dementia. I have a number of retirement villages in my electorate and one of the concerns is that we just do not have adequate facilities for dealing with people with dementia. Although I have an overwhelmingly young electorate, obviously an increasing proportion of it is getting older. Dementia has to be dealt with in any community.

We saw with the previous administration that you could be either in an aged persons' hostel and there was one rate of support or in a nursing home and there was a different rate of support. But, if you wanted to be in a specific dementia unit which does not require as much money as a nursing home but requires more than a hostel, you could not get special funding; you could get only the hostel rate of funding. In my electorate we actually closed dementia units because of the failure of the previous government to adequately finance those sorts of things.

In my electorate, and in many electorates across the country, there has been an impact on my constituents as a result of the measures that we have had to take due to the legacy we have inherited. There has been an impact on my constituents as a result of what the former government did which will last in my electorate for many years to come. I can assure this House that the Liberal government will have the courage to come to grips with these things, to get the budget back into balance, to deal with the issues of debt and to free up the business community to make sure that we actually start to get this country thriving yet again.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Economy: Budget DeficitExportsUniversity of Western Sydney

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) has provoked me into making a few responses. The new government has come in talking about wanting to lift the standards of parliament. I think it is important therefore that we on both sides of the House speak with some veracity about the matters that we wish to contribute to.

SPEECH.PARA: I think a lot of people might have sympathy with the honourable member for Aston if he referred to the Prime Minister's legacy in 1983 after having been briefed by Treasury that there was a $9.6 billion overspend in his budget. In equivalent terms today, that is $25 billion of overspend. When you talk about this $8 billion, of course this is not an overspend but, rather, a forecast, a projection, by Treasury of the likely outcome. The Reserve Bank has not sent us a note to say, `Look, you're in overdraft, you're overspent.' This is a projection by Treasury of the likely outcome, and it has already refined it downwards.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has made much of this sort of charter of accounting honesty that they are going to introduce as a result of their budgets. If they are so concerned about accountability, honesty and veracity, why won't they table—as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has said—the costings of their election promises? And is it true that up to $4 billion of the amount of money they are talking about is direct election commitments made by the present government during the election? I do not think it does us any good.

The honourable member for Aston is very interested in industry policy, particularly the IT industry. It is an absolute tragedy for Australian exporters that the government is going to cut out DIFF funding. Our DIFF funding is not as good as the soft loans from America, Japan and Germany. We are already at a competitive disadvantage with DIFF, but we are going to eliminate DIFF. We are saying to Australian exporters, `Your pricing has got to be so keen that you'll get no DIFF funding from us, so you're going to have to lower your price to be competitive for that, and then you've got to beat the DIFF funding from other countries who are bidding for projects.' We have already read in the paper that the patrol boat project in the Philippines is in jeopardy with its follow on orders. I suspect that the $2 billion patrol boat project with Malaysia is in difficulty.

The honourable member for Aston also mentioned the EMDG program that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull), who is at the table, often spoke about when he was in opposition. Again we are putting our exporters at a competitive disadvantage. This will cut Australian jobs, cut back Australian industry and make it even more difficult for us economically. This is one of the most short‐sighted approaches to industry policy issues I have ever seen.

PARA.BREAK: I want to talk about a by-election for Blacktown council that occurred in my elec torate on 11 May. I want to congratulate Tony Bleasdale, who is the successful ALP candidate. He has already taken his place on the Blacktown council. We fought a very difficult campaign. We had the Deputy Mayor, Charlie Loudes, as a campaign director and a team comprising councillors Danny Mackin, Peter McAlister and Allan Shearan. They were all working together to develop policies and approaches that Tony, as the candidate, took to the people.

SPEECH.PARA: Tony was a great candidate because straightaway he was out there listening to what people wanted. We developed a very grassroots campaign. At a time when at a federal and state level perhaps we on this side are not travelling as well as we might, we scored a six per cent swing, which is a great testament to Tony as a candidate and to all our members and supporters of the party who rallied behind it magnificently.

In the campaign, one of the issues that the Liberal Party raised was the proposition that Blacktown council should not fund a chair of construction and building services for the Nirimba site, an educational precinct comprising the University of Western Sydney, TAFE and two senior high schools. As far as I am concerned I have always been excited by the Nirimba educational precinct, even though it is in the electorate of my colleague and friend Frank Mossfield, the member for Greenway. It has been one of the most exciting projects for Blacktown.

Funding a chair of the university for building and construction sciences is quite appropriate. Blacktown is the largest local government area in New South Wales. It has about 30 per cent of its land still underdeveloped. It has been a high growth area for a long time. There are heaps of people involved in the building and construction industry or who are owner-operators in the building and construction industry. With a professor, we not only get the teaching value of the professor developing courses but also get the research which will be of direct benefit to companies in Blacktown and in the western suburbs region generally.

A lot of people feel that the people of Blacktown should not have a university; it should go to other, nicer places in Sydney. But we are really proud about our historic role in fighting for the University of Western Sydney and, more recently, obtaining this educational precinct. It really makes a positive contribution to the quality of life of our residents and provides opportunities for our younger population there. The benefit of the chair is that all you are really paying is the start-up costs. Our council has already announced the figure of $100,000 a year for five years and has put some of the money aside. It is currently re-evaluating it.

The council gets the value of the start-up costs because, once it has funded it and it raises the money for five years, it goes on in perpetuity. Council does not have to make any further commitment to that chair. It is not permanently tied to the recurrent funding of it.

There is an argument about whether council should be involved in funding university chairs. I well recall that one of the great programs we had in government was the local government capital works program, which was federal money going directly to fund the capital works of councils who had high unemployment in their areas. If we had adopted that attitude, Blacktown council would never have received the $7 million that it did under the program and we would never have seen the jobs that were completed with that $7 million being completed, as they are now.

I am very confident that when council reconsiders this issue it will take a long-term approach and it will make a commitment to Nirimba and to fund this chair. I am sure that when we look back in, say, 10 or 20 years this will be seen as an excellent decision.

I know the Liberal Party campaigned strongly against providing the chair. But, as I say, in the by-election we got a six per cent swing. So, if you want to take the marketplace of public opinion, there is no better way than actually getting people to vote on an issue. Overwhelmingly—the Liberals ran third—the people rejected this Liberal view that Blacktown should not fund the chair. Last but not least I should make the point that council made a commitment in its 1994 budget speech, and it is very bad to break a promise or break commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Done.

—Just as I was reminding the honourable member for Aston, I do not think it matters whether you are at the local, state or federal level. We all have a stake in trying to be restored in the good esteem of the voters, and one way of doing that is indeed by honouring commitments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —An inheritance is usually accompanied with a high sense of expectation and sometimes brings a sense of joy and some financial reward to someone. It can be quite unexpected. A distant relative or a friend departs this world after a long lifetime of service and perhaps thinks kindly enough about another person to leave them a few dollars or a favourite family keepsake. Today I want to talk about what the former federal government, the Keating government, left as an inheritance to the Howard government.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have inherited from the previous Labor government gives me no joy and the rest of Australia absolutely no joy whatsoever. After 13 years in office, they left us with high unemployment. Over 730,000 Australians are still out of work and wanting a job but cannot get one. To this we can add 1.3 million Australians who are either underemployed, want to work a bit more work and are available or are engaged in other activities and have been discouraged from seeking a job. Youth unemployment in my electorate is getting close to 30 per cent. It has been higher than that figure. Hopefully, we will be able to address that issue.

I also want to look at the high foreign debt that has been left to us by the former government. After 13 years in office, the net foreign debt is in excess of $180 billion. Add to that over $87 billion in foreign equity and Australia's net liabilities to the rest of the world now total over $267 billion.

High interest rates are another inheritance from the Keating government. When we came to office, Australia had the second highest bank prime rate amongst developed nations. We also had low national savings. Our national savings figure was lower than that at the depths of the 1982-83 recession. Household savings are also at historic low levels.

We also have a poor growth record. In the 17 quarters after Labor's recession, our economy grew by 16.8 per cent. In the 17 quarters after the 1983 recession, it grew by 21.9 per cent. We also have lower living standards, and with those lower living standards our world per capita income ranking fell from 10 to 22 in the 10 years to 1993. Poverty and income inequality are worsening.

Coming into office we are also faced with an $8,000 million budget deficit. To put that deficit into proportion, a person would need to win the Lotto every Saturday night of the year for the next 52 years to balance the books. I think that gives people in the community an appreciation of the task that the Howard coalition government has ahead of it.

Let us look at the inheritance again. What we have been left with by the former government is a very difficult situation. We will have to deal with the high unemployment rates. That is not going to be easy. I was interested in the comments by the member for Chifley (Mr Price) about the performance of his former government, the Keating Labor government, but there was very little mention of the difficulties that he has left us with and which we have to cope with in the community.

The current account deficit and foreign debt have forced up interest rates, which are very high by international standards—a testament to our worsening international position. We have the second highest bank prime interest rate amongst the nations that the Economist surveys. Average monthly loan repayments have risen by nearly 50 per cent over the Labor government's term in office. Many Australians have seen the value of their most prized possession, the family home, fall in value. They are being squeezed by high interest rates and falling home prices.

We also have declining incomes. Real wages have fallen by over one per cent over the last 13 years. Inequality of income and poverty have worsened, and those on the lowest incomes have seen their earnings fall the most. Middle Australia has found it harder to make ends meet and save for the future. Poverty, inequality, unemployment and underemployment remain the greatest causes of social misery in our community. Poverty and inequality are worsening. They are the greatest obstacles to opportunity, security and full participation in Australian life.

That message was brought home very clearly to me during the 1996 federal election campaign. When I was handing out how-to‐vote cards at some polling booths in my area on the morning of the election, almost every woman voter who passed me going into the booths to vote whispered to me, `Mr Reid, the coalition must win office. We are absolutely desperate.' I think that was the clearest message I have ever received in my political life of just what a mess the former government left Australia in.

I have tried to detail some of the problems, but there are many more of course. The major problem that we have immediately on our agenda is trying to overcome the Beazley black hole—the $8,000 million budget deficit which was left to the coalition to overcome.

This business has all the shades of the Cain‐Kirner regime when I served in the Victorian parliament. When that government went out of office in 1992, it left Victoria with a $42,000 million debt. It came to pass then that the Kennett government had to come in and make some very difficult decisions to try to get the budget balanced and to overcome some of the debt in Victoria. Obviously, we are going to have to go through some of the same exercises at a federal level if we are to overcome the $8,000 million budget deficit created by the Keating government and left as an inheritance to all of the people in Australia.

The difficult part about this is all of the broken promises of the previous government and the expectation of what it might be able to do for the Australian community. It was very clear when they were making those promises that they would not be able to fulfil them—they had no possible hope of keeping them. It was simply an exercise of telling the community, `We will promise all of this. Then after the election, if we are fortunate enough to be elected, we will immediately break all the promises again—as we did with the l‐a‐w tax cuts.'

Fortunately, the community saw through that ploy and elected the coalition to govern this country and to put the economy of this country back on the rails. That task is going to be difficult. We have been left this inheritance by the Keating government: this is what Labor left the Australian people. It is now our task to address the $8,000 million deficit. There will be some tough decisions to be taken to bring that budget back into balance over the next two years—and it is all due to Labor's failure—but those decisions have to be made if Australia is to prosper in the years ahead.

In effect, the $8,000 million budget deficit has a $180 billion foreign debt attached to it as well. Labor has left a negative inheritance for this nation and its children. The debt that is attributable to every man, woman and child from the $8,000 million alone is over $400 per head, and we are now faced with a $10,000 million interest payment each year. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to share with members of the House my concern about the transfer of nursing home beds from a state controlled nursing home in my electorate. Cessnock's Allandale Nursing Home is the town's largest single employer. The home has a reputation for delivering the highest standard of aged care and has provided the training for many of the Hunter's aged care providers.

SPEECH.PARA: The home has trained many of the town's tradespersons. On that basis, it plays a significant role in employment in the area. The home has also trained many support staff and employs many staff who work in such areas as domestic services and food provision. It employs about 400 people and, until recently, had more than 400 nursing home beds.

The Hunter Area Health Service is transferring by stealth nursing home beds from Allandale to private providers of aged care, most of whom lay outside my electorate. It is the intention of the Hunter Area Health Service to reduce the size of Allandale Nursing Home to 230 beds. The justification given for the transfers is the attempt by the Commonwealth and the states to more equitably distribute the nursing home beds available throughout Australia.

The Cessnock local government area, the Hunter Area Health Service would argue, has an oversupply of nursing home beds. This is based on that historic formula I know most members would be familiar with—that each area should have about 40 nursing home beds for each group of 1,000 people aged 70 or over. On this basis Cessnock does have an oversupply, on face value, of nursing home beds.

But Cessnock's Allandale Nursing Home provides accommodation for many people outside the local government area. On that basis, the suggestion that we have an oversupply of nursing home beds is ill-founded. Indeed, up to 80 persons in the local government area aged 70 or over are waiting for a nursing home bed at Allandale at any one time.

I have read the Gregory report and I am familiar with the challenges the Commonwealth faces in terms of the ever growing expense of providing aged care to an ever ageing population. I am also familiar with the need to change the ratio of nursing home beds and hostel places to provide for the most efficient distribution of funding in the area.

I am also aware that, in the early 1990s, the Commonwealth and the states reached an agreement whereby the states would transfer the control of nursing home beds—those that were left with the states at that time—to the Commonwealth. In terms of the aged care strategy, this may be okay and may seem more than reasonable. But the way that this policy is being implemented in the case of Allandale is nothing short of scandalous, and my reason for suggesting that is twofold.

The Hunter Area Health Service argues that, of the 400‐odd beds at Allandale, 200 or so would be accommodating people outside the local government area, as I just said. They would argue that as a consequence, if you take 200 away, you really have not reduced the number of beds available to Cessnock area residents because they were always being filled by people from outside the area.

But there is a catch. Allandale Hospital, because of its experience, its expertise and the professionalism of its staff, provides very special care. It accommodates many residents and many patients who are not wanted by the private providers. These very highly dependent people are put in the too‐hard basket, and it is always Allandale which is required to accommodate them. These people will continue to be sent to Allandale from outside the Cessnock local government area, so it is folly to suggest that you can take away from Allandale Nursing Home some 200 beds without there being an adverse impact on the waiting list for nursing home beds in the Cessnock local government area.

Another reason why I suggest that the way in which the policy is being implemented is scandalous is the impact it will have on the Cessnock local government area economically. Members would, I know, be aware that unfortunately the Cessnock local government area already has a higher than average rate of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment. I have already mentioned that Allandale traditionally has been not only the provider of jobs for apprentices and, therefore, our local tradespersons but also the provider of jobs generally for first‐time school leavers.

The Hunter Area Health Service is telling us that everything will be okay and that no person will lose their job at Allandale as a result of the transfer of these beds. I have difficultly in coming to terms with that. I do not know where the Hunter Area Health Service is going to place a lot of these people, particularly those categorised as List B registered nurses, who, according to some, do not have any contribution to make outside the area of aged care and cannot be accommodated in other areas where the Hunter Area Health Service provides services, such as surgical support, et cetera. I have a great deal of concern not only for the List B registered nurses, who are very fearful about their future, but also for people generally who will be affected by these changes.

Beds are already being transferred and wards are closing. As a result of the closures, long‐term residents are being moved to other wards or out of the hospital entirely. Over a period, the residents of these nursing homes and their families build great relationships with the nursing staff. You have to remember that many of these patients are suffering from dementia. Moving them around to different wards is a very scary experience for them. This is not something we should be imposing upon people who have worked hard to make this country the great place it is. I do not think this is the way we should be treating them, and it certainly is not a way of expressing our thanks.

What can be done? I understand that this is a difficult issue. As I said earlier, we are talking about an agreement, in writing, made between the Commonwealth and the states in early 1990 which has already been implemented in most states. It is difficult to suggest to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that, while it is okay for this to have taken place in other states and in other regions, we should make a special case for Allandale. Maybe we can. Allandale nursing home is certainly the biggest nursing home in my state and, I suspect, the biggest nursing home in the Southern Hemisphere, so it is a special case. We should be taking into account the fact that such a hefty transfer of beds is going to impact on the users of the facility and the economic make‐up of the town.

I have written to the minister seeking some action on this matter. I am still awaiting a response. I have specifically asked that a moratorium be placed on the transfer of beds from Allandale until the parties involved have had the opportunity to express their concerns and views to the ministers for health at both Commonwealth and state levels. Surely some accommodation can be made for these people. I appeal to the minister for health to respond to my representation, to impose a moratorium, and to set up some dialogue with the states so that he can understand the impact this decision is having and we can have an opportunity to be heard.

There is some suspicion about the way in which some of these transfers are taking place. An article in Saturday's Newcastle Morning Herald suggested that some private providers of aged care are being forced to accept Allandale beds before 30 June. If this is all about the provision of aged care, what transfers before 30 June have to do with it I will never know. It makes the whole thing stink a little. I am very suspicious of the process, and I appeal to the minister for some assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to express my dismay and disbelief at Premier Carr's decision last month to refuse the go‐ahead for North Ltd's Lake Cowal gold project. I know that the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks)—whose electorate, like mine, also borders the lake where it was proposed that this mine take place—has also expressed public concern about this incredible decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The lake is situated between West Wyalong and the town of Forbes. North Ltd is a company renowned in Australia, with about $1,600 million of assets and 52,000 shareholders. It has been exploring for gold in this area since the early 1980s and has spent almost $20 million in this area. It has identified 40 million tonnes of ore containing about 1½ grams of gold per tonne—about 1½ parts per million—which means that you need to process about 25 tonnes of ore to get enough gold to make a wedding ring. North Ltd hoped that, out of this mining operation—if it could have gone ahead—it would have mined two million ounces of gold, earning $1,200 million worth of export income for Australia.

That would have put it not only in the top 10 goldmines in Australia but would have made it the No. 1 goldmine in New South Wales. They intended to mine 230,000 ounces a year for the first seven years of the mine's life, then 102,000 ounces for the remaining four years. The gold is contained in volcanic sediments. It is a very large low‐grade deposit. It goes back about 460 million years. It was proposed to be mined by an open cut operation of about 800 metres diameter and about 220 metres deep. About half of the open cut would have gone out into the lake but the lake would have been protected by an impermeable protection bund. The gold would have been treated on‐site with cyanide. That would have gone out into four tailings ponds about a kilometre from the edge of the lake.

Until recently very few people, apart from the locals, had even heard of Lake Cowal. It is dry 30 per cent of the time. When it is full it is only three metres deep. It is largely privately owned by farmers around the area who, when the lake is dry, graze and crop the lake. If you look at photographs of the lake you can see river red gums growing in the middle of it, and fences and roads running backwards and forwards across it.

The trees in the middle of the lake, because it is dry some of the time, are alive. There is a breeding habitat of some significance for birds, which would be approximately five kilometres from where the proposed open cut would be. I say all this to show, if nothing else, that Lake Cowal is not the New South Wales answer to Kakadu. This is very much a shallow lake which has been dry for over 30 of the last 100 years.

North were proposing to mine there. They were going to spend $180 million to develop this mine. When it got going, it would have involved 180 jobs directly, with about another 180 indirectly. The wages of the miners would have averaged about $60,000 each and, over 11 years, that would have put $132 million into the economy. Of course, North were hoping to find more gold than has already been proved, as is usually the case.

I can tell you that towns like West Wyalong and Forbes were very much looking forward to this because they have been through one of the most severe recessions they have ever experienced. But what happened? I was sitting watching 60 Minutes on 7 April and, at the end of the program, Bob Carr came on and announced that this mine would not go ahead. It was not until three days later that North Ltd, the mining company, was even told officially that this was to be the case. Bob Carr and Minister Knowles, who is the Minister for Urban Affairs and Planning, have not even been to the site to look at it. It is an absolutely extraordinary situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incredible!

—It is incredible. They knocked it back on the report of Gabrielle Kibble, the director‐general of the department and a daughter of Sir John Kerr. It was a 4½‐page report—not even on a letterhead, for heaven's sake—that went against all the scientific findings. I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to that, North had spent $2 million on a four‐volume environmental impact statement and a fauna impact statement which had taken eight years to draw up. That was presented in August last year but was put aside. The Premier, Bob Carr, set up a commission of inquiry which sat in December and January, presented a 120‐page report to the Premier and took 118 submissions. The committee was chaired by the Chair and the Deputy Chair of the Office of the Commissioners of Inquiry for Environment and Planning, William Simpson and Kevin Cleland. These are top people.

The very best people were appointed to the inquiry and they said they were totally satisfied that the show should go ahead, that all the concerns had been addressed and that there were really no worries. It was an excellent report by any standards. It said:
The contrary views of some parties are not supported by the evidence.
One of those parties was the National Parks and Wildlife Service, which had said the mine should not go ahead.

There we have a 120‐page report recommending the mine should go ahead, with $1,200 million for Australia; 180 jobs directly over 11 years—$60,000 a job—and the Premier comes out on 60 Minutes, without even having the courtesy to tell the company, and announces that it will not go ahead—purely on the report of this woman, Gabrielle Kibble. The experts have looked at her 4½‐page report—I have a copy in front of me. They have rebutted it point by point. By any stretch of the imagination she has put up a very shallow report. It is full of half‐truths. It has twisted the facts. It misunderstands the science and, above all, it is totally inaccurate.

She says that because there is some risk—because it cannot be said there is no risk—the mine cannot go ahead. What an extraordinary standard to put on a mine. It would mean that every mine in the country should shut down if this standard were to apply. It would mean that we would have to ban cars because there is some risk of people being run over or killed in car accidents, and so on. She does not even have the decency to put out a report on departmental letterhead.

Yet the Premier put more weight on this report than on his commissioners' report which was scientifically based and 120 pages long. It is an extraordinary situation we have reached in New South Wales where the Premier, chasing the green vote in Sydney, has totally dismissed work for 180 people directly and another 180 people indirectly. It also means that $1,200 million of export income is just thrown away. Even worse, the environmentalists—the scientists who have looked at this area—appreciate that there are rising water tables near the lake, and they have high saline levels. North Ltd were prepared to put $2 million towards that to redress the problem. The Mayor of West Wyalong, David Bolte, says:
The Premier's decision has not saved the environment at Lake Cowal, but has put it at greater risk from rising groundwater salinity.
There have been studies carried out that indicate the lake could be saline in 20 years—

Of course, the Premier will do nothing about that. They have lost the chance of having $2 million donated to save the environment in the area simply because the Premier has been chasing the green vote in New South Wales. It is a totally irresponsible decision by any measure and should be absolutely and thoroughly condemned. I believe that the Australian people, particularly in the electorates of Parkes and Riverina and the state electorates in those areas, will remember that at the next election.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPLY BILL (No.1) 1996‐97Cognate bills:SUPPLY BILL (No.2) 1996‐97SUPPLY (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1996‐97

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Mr Fahey:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it, these supply bills are simply routine machinery matters with no particular policy significance, simply enabling the business of government to be carried on until the passage of the budget appropriation bills some time around November. No doubt that is why this debate has attracted the massive presence in the chamber that it has.
—There is quality here, if not quantity.

—There is indeed quality, and I acknowledge that interjection from my side. But a special significance is evident in these bills this year because they posit such a stark contrast between the pattern and the scale of expenditure that is provided for under them, based as they are on continuity with the past and a continuation of our forward estimates, and, on the other hand, the forthcoming budget bills with the massive expenditure reductions that are there proposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Usually, oppositions support these supply bills. There was one spectacular counter‐example we can all remember a few years ago. But I support, on behalf of the opposition this year, these bills with particular enthusiasm. And I do so because we strongly believe that continuity, with our own forward estimates of the kind that is enshrined in these particular bills, is a proper basis for the 1996‐97 budget—not the manic slash and burn approach that is now being proposed.

These bills do provide an ideal opportunity to expose the significance of the budget cutting process that is now under way, because I think it is not yet even now wholly appreciated just how wrong‐headed, misguided and indeed potentially disastrous the government's budgetary strategy is, not only for the particular groups and constituencies that will be immediately and directly affected by it but indeed for the whole of the Australian economy.

The government's approach in its budget strategy is built around three propositions: firstly, that there is a so‐called $8 billion black hole which reflects the Labor government's mismanagement; secondly, that this constitutes a crisis for Australian economic policy, the addressing of which has to be the highest priority; and, thirdly, any pain that is involved for particular groups in this budget strategy will be amply outweighed, amply compensated, by wider gains for the Australian community.

Needless to say the opposition wholly rejects each one of those points. The points I will be making are these: as to the first, there is not a Beazley black hole but, rather, a Costello con—one simply designed to place the blame on Labor for the savings they are generating to cover the coalition's own irresponsibly underfunded election promises. And, secondly, it is designed to cover a passion for Thatcherite, small government ideology making.

The second point is that, even if there were to be a $8 billion starting deficit, this nonetheless does not constitute a crisis for the Australian economy, nor any evidence of a failure of our economic management. Rather, it is a function of different and wholly legitimate policy choices, which I will spell out.

The third point I will be making is that there will not be the gain to outweigh the pain in this respect, that economic responsibility demands a quite different policy approach—an approach that puts people first, that goes for growth now and which adopts a longer timetable for addressing the deficit reduction and other associated or related issues.

Let us take each of those three points in turn. First of all, the so‐called Beazley black hole is not based on any calculation, any accounting, of what has happened in the past, and it is certainly not based on any calculation about blow-outs of expenditure. It is simply based on a Treasury and other officials' guess about what will happen in the future.

The $8 billion in fact is a puffed up, rounded out, exaggerated worst case figure. The headline starting point for next year—the figure you read about in the press the next day after each budget is brought down—is currently not $7.6 billion but $4.9 billion, and fully $2.3 billion of that is attributable to the coalition's own actions last year in blocking particular budget measures.

The so‐called underlying deficit, which does not bring into account asset sales and particular one‐off things like state debt repayments, is currently, on the government's officials' estimates, $7.6 billion. Even that is rather less than the $8 billion figure they constantly talk about, but it is certainly much less than the $3 billion it will reduce to over the next two years, again employing the government's officials' own estimates.

More importantly, I guess, than those points is that there is every prospect that the growth predictions on which these particular projected deficits are calculated will change again by August, changing in a way which reduces the so‐called starting deficit by several billion dollars. At the moment the Treasury, in making these calculations, has only half of the relevant data. When it made the forecasts that are in circulation at the moment, it had only one quarter of the relevant data for the current financial year. Years ago John Howard distinguished himself by saying that the forward estimates released well ahead of the budget were notoriously unreliable guides to the ultimate outcome. Dead right—they are. They were. They always have been.
Professors John Neville and Fred Gruen and Mr Fred Argy in the Australian Financial Review today, 20 May, made the point with absolute clarity when they said this:

. . . the figure of $8 billion is not itself a firm figure. It is a Treasury forecast assuming no policy changes and a rate of growth of the economy of 3.25 per cent . . . a small difference in the assumed rate of economic growth can make a large difference in the size of the projected deficit.

Again, the point can be made that the size of the possible deficit based on these predictions came as absolutely no surprise to Mr Costello or to the coalition. Access Economics predicted something like a $10 billion deficit based on different growth assumptions before Christmas. The now Treasurer, Mr Costello, was complaining publicly before Christmas about a huge hole opening up in Commonwealth finance. As Max Walsh said in the Sydney Morning Herald on 10 May:
If there was the slightest surprise by John Howard or Peter Costello when they were told that the prospective deficit for 1996‐97 was $8 billion, then you would be concerned about their competence.
That figure was in everybody's ballpark.
That is why the demonising of Kim Beazley and his black hole has, for me at least, a lack of credibility.

The real reasons that the coalition is pursuing what can only be described as this Costello con is straightforward: it is to try in the first instance to put some blame on Labor for the savage spending cuts that are going to be necessary to finance some of the opposition's own irresponsibly underfunded election promises. The coalition promised $6.8 billion worth of new policy measures over the next three years to be funded, supposedly, by $8.9 billion worth of savings measures. We, with the assistance of the Department of Finance, before the election, exposed the coalition as having itself a $4 billion hole in those savings measures. To take just one example, there was $360 million alone in the calculation of the savings that would be involved in the two‐year waiting time for social security for new migrants, a point confirmed by a recently leaked Department of Social Security document. Prime Minister Howard has carefully not ruled out utilising any of the $8 billion savings measures to pay for those pre‐election promises. The strategy is obvious. The strategy is: slash, burn, grab enough dollars to fund at least some of your pre-election promises, enough to remain credible, but blame the former Labor government for it by saying that it is all a necessary strategy brought on by our mismanagement.

The other point is that the government is pursuing in all of this a small government ideological agenda which makes Margaret Thatcher look like Mary Poppins by comparison. The objective is absolutely transparent. Again, they want to off-load on Labor as much as possible of the blame for the pain that will be caused in the pursuit of that agenda.

The second point I want to make—and it is a very important one—is that there is no economic crisis associated with these figures, even if you accept them for the sake of this argument at their own face value. The headline deficit of $4.9 billion is no more than one per cent of our national income, of our GDP. Even the so‐called underlying deficit of $7.6 billion is only around 1½ per cent of our national income. Neither of those figures, one or 1½ per cent, is massive or even very large by international standards. A deficit of 1½ per cent of national income would make us the equal third lowest of the major OECD countries as these figures were listed in the most recent Economic Outlook.

Compare those sorts of figures, those percentages, with what we faced coming into government in 1982‐83 and I think the point is made. The deficit that we confronted in those days' dollars of $9.6 billion was 4.9 per cent of national income. If you translate that into 1996‐97 figures, it is $24.5 billion. It was utterly unexpected, came out of the clear blue sky, and that was a budgetary crisis unquestionably that we had to confront and solve. This is trivial by comparison, even if you accept the puffed up, exaggerated, blown out numbers which I have already referred to.

Our structural deficit, when you wash out these figures for cyclical effects and look at the underlying balance of expenditure and revenue, is estimated by the OECD as the second lowest in that whole group of industrialised developed nations. Only Finland has a better looking balance sheet in this respect. Our deficit is around one‐quarter of the prevailing OECD average. If we had as a proportion of our national income the same average percentage deficit of the OECD countries as a whole, our starting headline deficit in 1996‐97 would not be $4.9 billion; it would be $15 billion.

We just cannot make some of these comparisons too often. Our public expenditure is the second lowest after the United States in the whole of the OECD. Our proportion of taxation, our ratio of tax, to national income, GDP, is the second lowest in the OECD after Turkey. Everyone gets very passionate about New Zealand but, if you collected as high a proportion of tax as New Zealand does, this year Australians would be paying an extra $35 billion in taxation. We certainly would not be talking about budget deficits under those circumstances.

Moreover, our public debt in Australia—another parrot cry endlessly in the economic debate—is the fourth lowest in the whole OECD after Japan, Norway and Finland. Let me answer the question, `How come the budget is not in better shape after 4½ years of sustained growth?' This is a point that many commentators, not just on the government side but in the media, constantly make. Let me answer it by saying it is not a product of mismanagement in any sense; rather, it is a product of deliberate policy choice. In the first place, it is a product of our success in holding down inflation by a whole variety of strategies but, in the process, eliminating the usual fiscal drag revenue that is derived naturally from inflation. In fact, rather than having disguised tax increases through effective bringing in of the tax scale at higher levels and generating more revenue without actually changing the legislation, rather than having those familiar disguised tax increases that have occurred so often in the past, we had a very explicit tax cut. That is where honest and effective government gets you, I suppose.

The second point to make about this is that our progressive tariff reforms, that absolute centrepiece of our industry restructuring policy, have denied us ever increasing amounts of revenue each year. This year those cuts amount to a loss of some $6 billion in tariff revenue—deliberate policy strategy which has a major revenue reduction effect.

Again—the third point—we chose to shield the states from the largest impact of the fiscal fallout of the recession by maintaining their general purpose payments in real terms at the same time that Commonwealth revenue was collapsing. We could have gone backwards and made life much tougher for the states. We chose not to do so. We are now bearing the budgetary consequences of that, but understand why it is that the budget deficit is higher than we would ideally like. It is a result of deliberate policy choices.

Again, we made and we have maintained a massive commitment to expenditure on education and training and job readiness programs. We faced in government in the 1980s new kinds of problems that were not around in the 1970s to confront Mr Howard last time he was in office and were not confronted then by governments anywhere—the problem basically of the information technology revolution which has meant the disappearance in particular of large swags of clerical jobs and the phenomenon of cultural change, especially women's entry into the work force in massive new numbers, reflecting their desire to make a positive contribution to the community and to their own personal satisfaction.

With women in the work force you now have much higher rates of people wanting jobs which, if we were translated back into the world of the early 1980s, would have very different outcomes for our unemployment situation. If we had the same participation rate now as was the case in 1983, unemployment would be down around four per cent rather than the 8.9 per cent it is at the moment.

Recognising the reality of these revolutionary technological changes and cultural changes that are involved in the different structure of the work force, as a government we went about placing massive new resources into education and training and skill development because we wanted to create a situation where our work force would have jobs in this brand new environment and would not be condemned to the status of long‐term unemployed. It was a deliberate policy choice, a very expensive policy choice and one that constitutes a large part of such deficit problem as there is in the budget figures.

Senator Short conceded recently that the ALP did not leave a lot of waste in its government programs when he said in his speech to the ACCI dinner that the former government was in the business of cutting programs which had, in fact, achieved their objectives efficiently and effectively. He said, as quoted in the press a few days ago:
The Government will also need to prioritise between programs which are meeting a relevant objective effectively and efficiently. Such prioritisation is required both within and across portfolios.

That one statement alone gives the lie to the suggestion that we now have any product of Labor government mismanagement waste blow‐outs.
