The truth of the matter is we were a lean, taut government doing things that had to be done and should have been done in the interests of this country and they did have budgetary consequences.

Of course it is true that, other things being equal—I have made this point on many occasions and I will continue making it—it is highly desirable that budgets be brought back into balance and, if possible, surplus to reduce government dissaving. We showed our credentials in that respect by being the only government since the war ever to deliver a surplus, and we in fact delivered four in a row in that respect—a task not managed by anyone else, certainly not the coalition.

BREAK.PARA: Budget balance or budget surplus is not an objective to be manicly pursued at all costs, whatever the cost. Ross Gittins made the point very well indeed in the Sydney Morning Herald on 13 May when he said:

Though it's true that the sooner we return the Budget to underlying surplus the more confident we can be of avoiding another blowout in the current account deficit, such a blowout is not imminent. There is no `crisis'.

Ross Gittins is saying, and so many other commentators have said, there is no crisis. That brings me to the third point: what is a responsible approach to economic management at this stage? What is a responsible budget strategy? There can be no doubt about the magnitude of the assault on the public sector and on public sector expenditure that is now being mounted by the coalition. I can document that assault, as evidence has already accumulated, but I will leave it to my colleagues to do so in the latter part of this debate. Let me concentrate for my purposes on the major theme of what is a responsible approach as distinct from the approach we are now seeing from the opposition. The general point I want to make about the assault is that it is not just a matter of their intense negative impact on particular groups or constituencies, on business, on the higher education industry, on a whole variety of people who are dependent on social welfare and on so many other areas. The point is that a matter of responsible economic policy, the approach that is being adopted, is utterly unnecessary and, in fact, wrong‐headed and utterly misguided.

What the economy needs now is not $8 billion of fiscal contraction but, rather, to consolidate the gains that we have had through almost five years of economic growth and to make a major new assault on the fundamental problem of the Australian economy at the moment, which is unemployment, and to do that by lifting the growth rate back to four per cent or more. The Australian economy is currently growing at an annual rate of around only three per cent. We are in fact one of the fastest growing economies in the OECD. By prevailing international standards in developed Western industrialised economies, three per cent looks pretty good. But we well know by now that three per cent growth is simply not enough to cut unemployment.

To reduce unemployment further we need growth of at least 3½ per cent and preferably four per cent. Private sector economists—it is not just us in the opposition but Westpac and Access Economics—are all saying that the government's cuts, if they go down this path with $4 billion this year and $4 billion next year, $8 billion worth of cuts, will mean at least half a per cent less growth in the economy this coming year and another half a per cent less the following year than would otherwise have been achieved.

Instead of working to help the economy back up to the four per cent growth that we actually need, the budget cuts that are presently in train will actually work in exactly the opposite way. This cut in economic growth will, of course, translate directly into lower job growth. Less economic growth equals, obviously, less employment growth—and we can easily quantify it. The government's cuts, if you do take half a per cent off growth next year, will mean that over 40,000 jobs that would otherwise have been created with growth at the higher level will not be there. And over two years, the figure will be 80,000 jobs lost to this manic pursuit of a budget ideology that says `cut, cut, cut'.

Moreover, there is very little scope for other economic forces—in particular, interest rates, exchange rate and confidence factors—to somehow come to the rescue and cushion the impact, modify the impact, of the government's planned cuts on the economy. It is true that the effect of a fiscal, a budgetary, contraction on economic growth could be cushioned in an environment where interest rates were falling and the exchange rate was depreciating. A reduction in interest rates could certainly stimulate private spending.

However, the government is planning its budget cuts in an environment where, because of the abandonment of the accord and because of the abandonment of wages policy, interest rates in everybody's assessment, from the Reserve Bank down, are more likely to rise than to fall in the immediately foreseeable future. A depreciation in the exchange rate, which might again in the normal course be expected to follow from an interest rate cut, would make Australian goods more competitive on world markets, would be a boost to our exports. But in the real world at the moment, the exchange rate is being, in fact, driven up because of strong world commodity prices and demands for the commodities that we produce.

The effect of fiscal contraction, I acknowledge again, might also be cushioned if somehow the cuts were to translate, as some people have predicted they will, into a massive rise in consumer and business confidence—this intangible lift to animal spirits that is supposed to occur when rough and tough budgetary, highly disciplined decision making of this kind is made. But the point is that on all the available information we have, the surveys that have been done, the hard evidence is that business and consumer confidence are already high, so that any further boost that would be achievable would have a marginal impact on the economy at best.

Before we left office, statistics from the ABS, the Australian Bureau of Statistics, showed that business was planning to increase its investment spending by as much as 27 per cent over the next financial year. With business investment expectations already so obviously buoyant, as they unquestionably have been, there simply is not scope for an additional increase in private investment of the kind of magnitude that would be sufficient to soften the blow of the proposed budget cuts on the economy.

So here we have a government which is planning massive cuts in an environment where confidence is already high, where interest rates are more likely to rise than to fall and where the exchange rate is set to remain very strong. In this environment, massive budget cuts can have no economic impact other than to dampen economic growth. The only other possible justification for further budget cuts is that Australia needs more national savings, and the government has to responsibly contribute to this task by reducing the deficit.

I have already said that the opposition agrees that Australia needs more national saving. But the government's totally unbalanced approach to economic management is not the way to go about successfully boosting national saving. Leaving to one side superannuation policy and all the rest of the longer term measures that we put in place, the best way to get more national saving is very simply to have a strongly growing economy. A strongly growing economy means that people have the extra income to build up their private saving. More economic growth means that more people have jobs which means less government spending on unemployment benefits. That means more tax revenue, less expenditure and more public saving. There is a very strong and a very clear relationship between unemployment and national saving. As unemployment falls, national saving rises. The best way to get national saving up is to get unemployment down.

This point, again, has been very well made by those excellent, well‐regarded economists Fred Gruen, John Nevile and Fred Argy of the Australian Financial Review in a letter this morning when they said this:
. . . it is neither necessary nor desirable to seek to reduce discretionary spending by $8 billion over the next two years simply because the economy is forecast to grow more slowly—
more slowly than was assumed in the 1995-96 budget, that is. It goes on:
If the economy is indeed slowing down, such a policy may well slow it down further and increase unemployment in the short term, while helping neither the fiscal deficit nor the national saving rate.

Let me conclude on this note. The crucial thing in economic policy is not to confuse means and ends. The first priority for economic policy should always be people. The objective of economic policy and of economic management of the economy is to improve people's living standards through providing sustainable full employment and rising incomes.

Everything else—whether it is controlling inflation, reducing the current account deficit, bringing budgets back into balance or surplus, reducing public debt, reducing foreign debt or increasing savings—are second and third order objectives by comparison. They are means to the achievement of the primary objective of improving people's living standards. There are times—there are real crisis times—when absolute priority attention has to be devoted to bringing inflation under control or hauling absolutely unacceptable levels of current account deficit back.

But that is not the situation of the Australian economy at the moment in the view of any serious-minded economic commentator. I have to say that it is not the view of any of the senior chief executives, senior managers or senior analysts in the banks and the financial institutions, the corporate leaders of this nation whom I have been talking to over the last few weeks. Inflation is comfortably within the average two to three per cent underlying rate of inflation range that everyone agrees is desirable to target for and to achieve. The current account deficit has been brought down from six per cent of GDP to 4½ per cent of GDP. It is being comfortably serviced at present at foreseeable export levels.

It is simply not necessary at the moment, if it is ever necessary, to mount some kind of Vietnam style crusade to destroy the economy supposedly in order to save it. It is possible, while being absolutely economically responsible, to choose a very different path in the government's management of the economy and its budgetary strategy over the weeks and months ahead. It is possible to choose a quite different path.

We say the priority for economic decision makers in Australia today should be to resume growth and to make a new assault on unemployment. That is what the priority task should be. You do not achieve that priority task by moving down this particular slash and burn route. You do not abandon the aspiration of getting the budget back to surplus but you spread the task out over longer time periods so you do not have those adverse impacts on growth in the economy.

We say that that is what the priority task should be about—that is, getting growth back up to four per cent and generating the capacity as a result to make a significant impact on unemployment, which is unquestionably the greatest human problem as well as the greatest economic problem in Australia at the moment. That is not what this budget is going to be about. It will be to the everlasting shame of this government that it has so quickly and so conspicuously and so mindlessly failed to meet, in these ways, the real needs of the Australian economy and the real needs of the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! Before I call the honourable member for Canning, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise in this House to speak for the first time, I am mindful of the challenge that lies ahead in delivering responsive government to the people of Canning. I first contested Canning, which is situated in Perth's south-east corridor, way back in 1984. I stood for this electorate in five successive elections before taking my place in this House today. The fact that I was on the campaign trail for so long led many people to assume they could come to me with their problems and concerns and have them resolved. Indeed, some members of the Liberal Party used to refer to me as the longest serving federal member without a seat.

SPEECH.PARA: If any electorate in Western Australia demonstrates how people have turned away from the Labor Party over the last 13 years it is Canning. Every year, every election, more and more people felt their expectations were not being met. The 1996 election saw Labor's traditional supporters desert them as never before.

I want to put on the record my thanks to our Prime Minister, John Howard, and the many senators and members who campaigned so vigorously on my behalf. A special thank you must also go to Senator Ian Campbell and his staff, whose advice and assistance were always readily available.

It truly is a most humbling experience to be elected to represent the people of Canning. Because I have fought so long and so tenaciously to win the honour of representing the people who live in my electorate, I have no intention of wasting the marvellous opportunity they have so generously bestowed upon me. I pledge to serve them with enthusiasm, compassion and fortitude.

Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, let me cast your mind back to 1984 when I first started campaigning: the Berlin Wall still separated a nation; the USSR was a major world power; Saddam Hussein enjoyed the support and the claim of the West in his fight against Iran; and here in Australia there was only one conservative state government. But thankfully times have changed.

When Labor came to power in 1993 Australians had no idea of the tough years ahead. We suffered through the infamous recession we had to have. Our foreign debt skyrocketed and interest rates soared. Far too many ordinary Australians sank deeper into the mire of unemployment. This had a devastating effect, causing family breakups, associated social problems and an escalation in the level of crime. By 1996 the string of broken Labor promises ensured that the chasm between the haves and have‐nots had widened dramatically. What a great legacy from a so‐called egalitarian government! Labor's mismanagement has left its impact on all Australians.

I witnessed hard‐working people struggle to make ends meet and families disintegrate. Small business owners fell into ruin as a result of unfair high taxes and bureaucratic red tape. All of this was introduced by a government that had no inkling of, and probably less interest in, the sacrifices people had to make just to survive, let alone create wealth for this country. In my local area I have a reputation for hanging in there for the good fight, for being tenacious, for being knocked down in one round and getting up to fight another.

The Liberal Party offered a better alternative to the 13 years of Labor hardship inflicted on all Australians. They offered hope and the restoration of quality of life for all of us. It was this belief that inspired me to continue to battle for the right to represent the people of Canning in this place.

Like many Australians, I am the child of immigrants. In 1954 my parents chose to travel halfway around the world from their native Germany. They left behind family and friends to begin a life in a country which to them was very alien—a vast, harsh land, but safe and politically stable compared to the ruins of postwar Germany.

My parents, Maya and Henry Heppekausen, provided me with a stable, loving upbringing which inspired my staunch moral and social beliefs. They encouraged me to form my own opinions early in life, to participate in community activities and to strive towards upholding the rights of the individual and the rule of law. I am thankful for those values instilled in me and I hope they will serve me well when making decisions as the people's representative.

My father often remarks on the wonderful opportunities open to all Australians. I do not take this magnificent country for granted. Indeed, I am proud my parents chose to make Australia our home and become citizens of this nation. We found that if one was prepared to work hard and to save, one's toils could be rewarded with unlimited opportunities and a better future.

Unfortunately, many of those attitudes have disappeared. Much of our pioneer spirit has vanished. That capacity for effort and the determination which shaped the ethos that helped build this great country have largely faded under a Labor administration. Today a significant segment of our community scream in demand for their rights. They have been fed the language of rights without being encouraged to accept the responsibility that earns these rights. We have prisoners' rights, children's rights, illegal immigrant rights and dozens more. All this talk about rights, yet few people are willing to admit to their responsibilities.

As citizens of this country, we all have responsibilities to ensure that Australia is as good a country to live in as we can make it. We have responsibilities to our families, our friends, our neighbours, our employers/employees and to the community in general. Many of those who loudly demand their rights shirk their responsibilities. Yet, if we are to turn Australia around, we should all act responsibly. The emphasis should not be on what this country owes to the individual but what each individual owes to this great country.

It was my late father‐in‐law, Fred Johnston, who introduced me to the tenets of Liberalism. Fred was a foundation member of the modern Liberal Party and a great friend of Sir Robert Menzies. He was a pioneer of Western Australia's meat industry and a passionate believer in the principles of free enterprise. He postulated that those who worked hard were entitled to just rewards. Fred was an inspiration to many people. He was a man of conscience and brilliant ideas who dedicated himself to working for the betterment of others.

When I first met Fred about 30 years ago, many Liberals believed that a woman's role was to work behind the scenes and make the tea, despite the fact that the first wave of female politicians came from the conservative ranks. How delighted Fred would be to see the number of `tea ladies' on the government side of the House today, especially those elected to the key seats that helped John Howard form his government! And would you believe, Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, that all of this was achieved without Labor's quota for women.

I now want to tell you a little about the electorate that I represent. It is typically Australian in its make‐up. Canning extends from the south‐east metropolitan areas of Perth to adjoining rural areas. Named after Alfred Canning—a surveyor who pioneered the great stock routes and rabbit proof fencing—it was first proclaimed in 1948 and has an area of more than 1,200 square kilometres. Although many people think of Canning as being a very ordinary sort of place, some of the best views of Perth can be seen from the hills of our area. These hills, which form part of the Darling escarpment, cradle three of Perth's major dams and supply Perth residents with much of their water. At the other end of the electorate, in Canning Vale, we have the home of the famous Swan Brewery and Western Australia's largest produce markets. We also have some very interesting vineyards, but I doubt whether many members have had their pallets tantalised by these fascinating vintages.

BREAK.PARA: Some people assume my electorate also takes its name from the Canning River, which feeds into the beautiful Swan. As a child, I played on the banks of the Canning River. Back then you could swim and fish to your heart's content. But, sadly, this is another change that has taken place. The Canning River is now polluted and choked with algal bloom. Whilst not quite dead, the river is very dormant. John Howard's government has promised $1 billion to help rehabilitate environmental problem areas like the Canning River. Central to this policy is the partial sale of Telstra, but it would appear that some of those in the other place are hell‐bent on opposing this proposed sale. I can only conclude from this that they do not share the government's commitment to a cleaner, greener Australia. However, I want to remind them that it is precisely this which the coalition was elected to do.

Canning is very representative of hardworking middle Australia. The light industrial areas of Maddington, Kelmscott and Armadale consist mainly of small business which provide jobs for many of my constituents. Large retailers such as Coles‐Myer and Foodland Associated Ltd have their state head offices in Canning Vale. In contrast to this, the southernmost aspect of the electorate is rural, scattered with tourist attractions, orchards, dairy and emu farms, horse studs and timber mills. While this may paint a happy picture of stable employment, Canning, like much of Australia, has suffered from Labor's legacy of high unemployment.

In January 1996 I commissioned a small business survey in Canning. The overwhelming response from employers was total loss of confidence in the future of their business in terms of profit and job growth. Ninety‐two per cent of respondents rated the former Labor government's performance as poor or very poor. Only seven per cent gave Labor an average rating, while just one per cent said that it was doing a good job. However, since the March election, I have been in regular contact with many employers. I sense a new hope. Small business owners particularly have welcomed this government's policies, which will provide opportunities for growth, jobs and wealth creation. They are firmly convinced that these policies, when implemented, will lead to improved living standards for the people of Canning.

Four local government councils, with a combined population of about 140,000, stretch across my electorate. Continuous expansion of both residential and commercial areas within these geographic regions means that adequate long-term planning for roads and bridges is extremely necessary. I have already briefed the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) on the urgency of implementing an integrated road system which will require substantial federal funding in conjunction with state and local government authorities.

As Canning is such a large metropolitan electorate, I have formulated plans for a mobile office. This will allow me to visit schools, shopping centres and retirement homes, making it easier for me to meet with people. Apart from being able to deal with their concerns on the spot, my intention is to encourage people to once again have faith in their government and its process.

Over the last decade, the public's cynicism towards the political process has escalated to an unprecedented level. In many instances, the people view the performance of their elected representatives with contempt. I applaud the Prime Minister's commitment to restore respect for our national parliament in the true spirit of the Westminster system. We have in our hands a great trust, which I feel sure we in this House can all fulfil.

Similar to other parts of Australia, Canning has an ageing population. It has been estimated that, by the year 2010, 22 per cent of Australians will be aged 60 years or over. We must, if we are to remain a humane and caring society, ensure that the more mature members of our community are treated with respect, honour and, above all, dignity.

As a nurse, successful small business operator, local government councillor and service coordinator for the aged, I have sadly on some occasions witnessed the indifferent manner in which we treat many of our elderly citizens, especially those suffering from dementia. This is an area of our health care system where the implementation of an improved means of palliative care is still in its infancy.

Too often, people so afflicted are left to lead an existence of drug‐induced stupor. As a result of this, they experience very little stimulation, which may become a contributing factor to the gradual loss of their faculties. However, their quality of life can be improved. This government's commitment, therefore, to focus more directly on the special care needs of the elderly is most timely and indeed most welcome.

Appropriate facilities for the elderly in my electorate are acutely scarce. Specifically, I have identified the desperate need for more nursing home beds as well as alternative accommodation. As this problem has been allowed to drift for a long time, there is an urgency to act now. By bringing together representatives from community organisations, state and federal governments, I hope to establish a meaningful dialogue so as to ensure that these needs are met in the best possible way.

My concern though is not just for those aged people who suffer illness. Many older folk remain relatively fit and mentally astute. But lately there seems to be the general notion that, once a person reaches the age of 65, their usefulness somehow evaporates.

Age brings wisdom, yet Labor failed to tap into this rich and valuable resource. The previous government rarely listened to our elderly. Indeed, they dismissed their views in favour of those of the social psycho engineers whose sometimes crackpot theories have done much to disintegrate the social fabric of our society. This government will recognise the talent of older Australians. It will broaden the scope in which they can continue to contribute to a range of economic and community activities. It will also ensure that all elderly citizens are given a fairer deal.

Another concern that causes me great distress is the observation of just how fragile families have become. Family life should be the cornerstone of our community. All too often without the support of a stable family environment, our youth run the risk of becoming alienated. They need role models, both at home and in the community, whom they can respect and look up to. Above all, they need a sense of security and values and the opportunity to succeed, which they in turn can pass on to their children. I say this because I firmly believe Australia's best asset is its youth.

As far as providing adequate social services to families, we have inherited the ridiculous situation in which low income married couples with children are allowed to be financially worse off than others simply because they choose to remain together in a cohesive family unit. Financial pressures on families over the last decade have often been the first trigger towards family breakdowns. I intend to take an active role in this government to bring about a change for the better in this area.

Let me briefly touch on a subject which, as a student of politics, I have a great interest in—that is, the question of voluntary versus compulsory voting. I do not resile from the fact that I favour voluntary voting. Pedantic opponents of voluntary voting may argue that, in Australia under the present system, people are not compelled to vote—they merely have to go to a polling booth and have their names crossed off. However, it is my opinion that compulsory voting actually devalues a citizen's right. By making the failure to vote a punishable offence, we have lowered citizens' appreciation of the importance of their choice.

Voluntary voting, on the other hand, gives citizens cause to reflect on the power contained within their vote. I totally reject the cynical and pessimistic view that large numbers of Australians will be too apathetic to vote. Indeed, I believe we have nothing to fear in discussing this important principle in this House.

Before concluding, I want to thank the hundreds of people who offered their time and service to ensure Canning would have a Liberal representative. Volunteers came from all walks of life—the young and old, the disabled, the unemployed, Liberals and disillusioned Labor supporters. It is impossible to mention them all, but I especially acknowledge those six dedicated ladies who worked long hours for many months in the most trying conditions in the hottest campaign office one can ever imagine.

As honourable members would know, one does not arrive at this House without the support of one's family. My two sons, Allistair and Adrian, never complained when they were asked to hand out yet another how to vote card over so many years. My husband, Ian, whose understanding, encouragement and belief in my commitment never wavered, is my best friend, critic and confidant. His objective analysis of the day‐to‐day situation during the long campaign periods was invaluable.

My final words are to the electors of Canning whose desire to have a Liberal government allows me to be here today. I see my new role as the servant of all the people of Canning. I hope that we on this side of the House will have the courage to stick to our policies and to implement them with sensitivity and compassion. The Howard government has given people new hope. I am confident that, by working together with the people, the future for all of us will be brighter.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.37 p.m. to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence this evening by doing something that is a bit unusual for a member of the opposition, that is, giving the government a couple of bouquets. As a new member of the parliament but someone who has had quite a lot of experience in the Victorian parliament, compared with Victorian Premier Kennett, I find the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) comes across as a statesman and a gentleman. Some people might think I have just damned the Prime Minister with faint praise, but I make that observation in all seriousness concerning the conduct of the parliament and, for example, the cut in the size of the ministry from 30 to 28, which is to be compared with the Victorian Premier's view of the Victorian government as a source of reward for his friends and cronies.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, Premier Kennett had the Victorian ministry expanded from 18 to 22, appointed parliamentary secretaries with allowances in the order of $7,000 a year and doubled the allowances for committee chairmen, with the government deciding that it would have all the committee chairs in the Victorian parliament. That was against the custom and practice in the Victorian parliament, where committee chairs had previously been shared around. Compared with that, I have to acknowledge that the Prime Minister at least shows a shred of integrity in reducing the size of his own ministry.

My second bouquet relates to the government's response to the tragedy at Port Arthur. If there is one thing which this community has to do and one thing which we as legislators and politicians have to do, it is to provide an appropriate response to that appalling disaster which befell people in Port Arthur just a few weeks ago.

I believe that the Prime Minister has shown genuine leadership and his response has my total support. Equally, I believe that the response of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has been spot on. It also has my unqualified support. I am pleased that the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) is here this evening because he has had a substantial involvement in this issue.

I should also indicate to the House that the response of the media has been one of great leadership in putting these issues before the public and before us as parliamentarians. I say this subject to the qualification that, in the last week or so, it is my view that the media have provided undue coverage to the representatives of that most unrepresentative of groups, the gun lobby. When you look at opinion polls and observe that more than 90 per cent of Australians support the Prime Minister's package, it seems to me that they really are receiving undue coverage.

By way of example, one of the Sydney newspapers surveyed all of us as members of parliament and asked for our views on three questions: do we support a national system of gun laws; do we support the registration of all firearms; and do we support a ban on automatic and semi‐automatic weapons? I, and virtually every other member of this House who responded, indicated yes to all three questions. Our answers were printed in that particular newspaper.

BREAK.PARA: As I recall, there was only one member who responded to that questionnaire to the effect that he did not support the registration of all firearms and that he did not support a ban on automatic and semi‐automatic weapons. If the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) does not have the courage—does not have the guts—to stand up to the gun lobby, that is his problem. But it does not, in my view, entitle him to undue media coverage when the fact is that the overwhelming majority of members of parliament support—as I do—national registration of firearms and support a ban on automatic and semi‐automatic weapons.

I believe we as a parliament have to have something that we can say to the victims of the Port Arthur massacre, something that we can say to Walter Mikac, whose wife and two children were killed in that event—his daughter, having seen her mother and her sister killed, hiding behind a tree and then being killed herself. We have to have something that we can say to him about our willingness to address these issues.

We have to have something that we can say to people who now live in fear in aspects of their daily lives which are both unavoidable and appropriate. For example, as a parent I send my daughter to Moonee Ponds West Primary School. I feel that I and every other parent who sends a child to primary school ought not to have to worry about whether or not there could be a repeat of the events of Dunblane in Scotland, where a whole class of young boys and girls—some 16 children—were killed by a single assailant armed with a semi-automatic weapon.

When we go to work we should not have to worry about whether we could become victims in our own workplace, as workers at Australia Post became in 1987 in the massacre at Queen Street in Melbourne. At that time I was an employee of Australia Post and I remember very well and very vividly the shock and dismay that was felt by people in Australia Post after that tragic event. When we leave work or when we go to work we should not feel that we, too, could become victims in the way that people going home from work became the victims of the Hoddle Street killer, Julian Knight, who was armed with military training and with military weapons—or, indeed, the man who was going to work in my electorate in Fawkner a year and a half ago and who was killed with a semi-automatic weapon.

We should not have to feel that, when we go shopping, we might have the same situation that occurred in the Strathfield Plaza shopping centre, where people were killed by Wade Frankum. Finally, we should not have to feel that, when we go on holidays to some of Australia's most picturesque and attractive landscapes, as Port Arthur is, or to other places, we might become the victims of a mass killer, as occurred just a few weeks ago.

We have to have something to say to people who are concerned about these things. We have to get together as a community, as a national parliament and as state parliaments to address these issues in the way that the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General, with the full support and cooperation of the opposition, have been doing.

A supply bill includes within it supply for the parliament, including supply for the Senate. On that note, I want to congratulate the Senate on the steps that it has taken to hold an inquiry into the tender process surrounding the casino in Victoria. There are a lot of questions that need to be answered arising out of such an inquiry—questions to which Victorians wish to know the answers and are entitled to know the answers.

I ask this House: how is it that, when ITT Sheraton put together a bid which was $80-odd million in excess of the bid put forward by Hudson Conway, or the Crown consortium, ITT Sheraton was not the successful tenderer? What in fact happened was that the tender was put out again for further bids and the Crown bid mysteriously rose by $80-plus million to equal the ITT Sheraton bid. Then the Crown consortium was able to win the bid.

How is it that the Treasurer of Victoria, Mr Stockdale, was able to ask for and receive details of those bids? How is it that Ron Walker and the Premier, Jeff Kennett, could be seen sitting on the dock of the bay—Port Phillip Bay—when they had been warned against contact, discussing presumably the weather during this bidding process? How is it that after the casino contract was awarded to Crown the Victorian government made so many decisions which advantaged the casino in so many ways that surely ITT Sheraton would have been prepared to up their bid very substantially had they known that these things were going to occur? These are appropriate subjects for a Senate casino inquiry.

I also urge that inquiry to investigate the most recent revelations concerning the Premier's and Felicity Kennett's purchase of some 50,000 shares in the Guangdong Corporation through the intercession of Mr Bruce Mathieson. What many members of parliament may not be aware of is that, long prior to revelations by Today Tonight a week ago, people were coming to me and to other members of the opposition screaming about the preferential treatment being given to Bruce Mathieson. He had bought up hotels which had been unable to get poker machine licences. They had applied for licences but had not been given them, and when the hotels were sold to Bruce Mathieson he was able to jump the queue and get poker machine licences. Those are matters which the Senate casino inquiry ought to investigate also.

Looking at a supply bill provides an opportunity to study what situation our economy is in. These days the most dominant feature of our economy is the way in which it has become so internationalised through transport and communication advances. Companies are simply able to relocate their businesses from Australia to other parts of the world at the drop of a hat. That imposes a tremendous discipline on Australians who wish to maintain our standards of living. It certainly poses challenges to the labour movement, to the trade union movement.

History shows that we had a situation a century ago and in previous centuries associated with the industrial revolution where employers were able to effectively pit worker against worker, pay very low wages and have very poor working conditions as a result. Trade unions were able to band workers together and gradually and progressively improve living standards and working conditions.

But the internationalisation of our economy and the way in which companies can simply relocate overseas at the drop of a hat certainly challenge that. It is important, in my view, that we look at lifting the standards of other countries because, if we are unable to do that, we will end up finding our own standards progressively diminished. We need in this regard a social clause in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. I regard that as a very important thing which this parliament ought to be pursuing in order to protect the living standards and the working conditions of working Australians.

In this country we have had during the past decade the accord, which has been fundamental to securing Australia's international competitiveness, to securing lower industrial disputation and to securing the wellbeing of ordinary workers and protecting their wages, while at the same time enabling reforms in the area of superannuation, employment growth, Medicare, child care and others to be pursued. The accord has been of immense benefit to workers, to employers and to the whole community.

As a result principally of the accord, Australia has been handed over to the incoming coalition government in very good shape. I think the correct analogy is with that couple visiting Australia at the moment—the magician David Copperfield and the international supermodel Claudia Schiffer. I think that our economy is in as good a shape as Claudia Schiffer. Unemployment came down from 10 per cent in 1983 to some 8.5 per cent when it was handed over to the coalition. All the while the participation rate rose from 60.4 per cent in March 1983 to 63.4 per cent in March 1996. Inflation has come down from 11.4 per cent in March 1983 to some 3.7 per cent in March this year, so inflation has been reduced by two-thirds.

Prime interest rates have been reduced from 14.5 per cent in August 1983 to 10.75 per cent in August 1995—reduced by a quarter. In relation to industrial disputes, in January 1983 the number of working days lost was 105,000, whereas in January of this year the figure was 20,000. So we have seen industrial disputes reduced by in the order of 80 per cent.

Regarding the budget deficit, we inherited a budget deficit of $9.6 billion—some 4.9 per cent of GDP—compared with the figure of $4.9 billion which is used by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) at the moment and which represents less than one per cent of GDP. Rarely in politics does an incoming government inherit an economy in such good shape. But the government refuses to recognise this. They want to resort to the magic of Claudia's partner, David Copperfield. So the chief sorcerer—the Treasurer—says that, if you repeat the magic words `black hole' often enough, one of those black holes is going to appear. What he needs to understand is that, if you repeat the magic words three times and no black hole shows, that is a trick that you ought to abandon.

There are other ministers who fancy themselves as magicians as well. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, wants to perform that old trick of trying to saw a woman in half but, instead, is applying it to the university sector. Senator Vanstone believes that you can cut funding by 12 per cent and still have a university sector catering for the same number of students. She wants to see the HECS repayments for students rise by the order of 30 per cent. In my view, if you want to perform that particular magic routine you will end up looking not so much a magician as a clown. We have a Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism who did not pull a rabbit out of his hat a few weeks ago. What Mr Moore pulled out of his hat was a new tax. So we have a number of ministers who think they are David Copperfield.

PARA.BREAK: In addition, we have a government which fundamentally is suffering from anorexia. It thinks that the economy is overweight, when in fact it is very nicely proportioned and, certainly, surgery is no cure. The government is behaving like a troubled adolescent, ashamed of the nation's economy. It cannot stomach the sight of itself in the mirror. The govern ment wants us to believe that the economy is in terrible shape and that the beautiful curves are in fact hideous distortions.

BREAK.PARA: The coalition's prescription for the Australian economy is a starvation diet. Regrettably, as we all understand, anorexia is in fact a very dangerous condition. I would urge the government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't make light of a very serious condition. You should be ashamed of yourself!

—Order! If the member for Wills will just resume his seat for a moment, the member for Ballarat is not even in his seat and is still planning to participate in the debate. I remind him that he is abusing the standing orders. The member for Wills has the call.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is in fact a very dangerous condition. Just last month we had unemployment rising. I implore the government not to do what it did last time—which, in the words of Paul Keating, was like something out of Laurel and Hardy: you went for the handbrake and it came off in your hands. We are in a very delicate situation and, if the government engages in the kinds of cuts that it is proposing, it will cause the economy to slow, when what we need is the very opposite.

BREAK.PARA: We need an economy which is moving more rapidly and we need policies which will promote growth in this economy, not policies which will slow growth in this economy—which are the kinds of policies in terms of spending cuts that this government is proposing. I urge the government to re‐think its strategy, which I believe could be a very dangerous strategy for the economy. I invite the government to remember that when you think of the economy you should think of Claudia Schiffer and not try any of that David Copperfield stuff on us, because we are not going to fall for any of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Kingston, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's maiden speech and ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jeanes, Susan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 September 1943, Dame Enid Lyons stood in this House and made history. In her first speech here she acknowledged the turning point that was marked by her arrival. Fifty‐three years later, in the 38th Parliament, times have certainly changed. There has been much attention paid since the election to the fact that we now have 23 women members in this House. While it is aesthetically pleasing to look around the House and see the different colours scattered here, the scattering represents meagre progress, as 53 years on there are still only 23 out of 148 of us here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is indeed a thrill to stand here in this House for the first time and speak as Dame Enid did 53 years ago. As I was putting these words together, I rang the Parliamentary Library to see if they could suggest a term as the male equivalent to `maiden', which is associated with qualities like youth and virtue and the state of being single. I should not be surprised, therefore, that there is no male equivalent. In the absence of a suitable word, I have decided to refer to this as my first speech.

The 84,777 electors of Kingston have indeed bestowed upon me an enormous honour. My constituents can be assured that, together with their dependants, they have my total commitment as the vehicle for the expression of their political rights in this place. I look forward to fulfilling this commitment for as many years as I enjoy their confidence to do so.

It is customary in one's first speech in this House to thank those who helped you to get here. I must therefore start with the two people who perhaps pay the highest price for the attainment of my political goals—my daughters, Lauren and Jenna, who, quite surprisingly, are here tonight. Being their mother is and always will be my most important and most cherished role. I also thank my parents, Barbara and Bill Jeanes. As I move around my electorate meeting families in crisis—families where children suffer in the most horrendous ways—I am constantly reminded of the fortuitous start that I had in life through the plain good luck of turning up in the nursery bearing the name tag `Jeanes'. And, of course, I must thank my long‐suffering partner of 20 years, my husband, Bruce, who is also here tonight in the gallery.

The two‐party preferred swing in Kingston was 3.6 per cent. An analysis of the swings across the marginal seats in South Australia shows that visibility played a significant part in the final outcomes. Of particular note is our preoccupation with election posters. According, therefore, to my husband, the work that I put in over the 12 months leading up to the election was responsible for only half my swing. The other half, according to Bruce, was won by him, my dad, Don Phillips and their poster operations team.

I did not see Bruce very much during the campaign as he was very busy every night repairing, replacing and just putting up over 1,000 of my posters. After the election, he found that he could no longer escape at night. He had to come home and spend time with me, causing him considerable adjustment problems! I must also pay tribute to the hard work of my committee headed by my dear friend Trevor, whose ongoing humour, advice and support is treasured. Our team included people like Rod Callagher and Joan Turner, who continued to strive to help me get here simply because they believed that this country desperately needed a Liberal government at this the federal level to restore responsible economic management and social cohesion.

After the hard work put in by so many, it could be easy to miss the meaning of an election victory and subsequent arrival in this place. It is an awesome responsibility, and indeed a great privilege, to represent the political rights of others. I think that the importance of what has happened to me, and the immense responsibility that I now have, is finally sinking in.

On the night of the election, I do not think I really realised that I had won. When my opponent rang at about 9 o'clock to concede defeat, all I could think of was to say, `Are you sure?' This did not seem to please him much. He sent me a warning on national television that he would leave a message for me in my office. And what a message he left! As my staff and I entered the office for the first time, no-one took much notice of a report that was left in the front bookcase about the viral diseases in rodents and ruminants. Nor did anyone bother to look at the chapters about the effect of these diseases on humans. It was not until we went into the kitchen that the meaning of the message began to be understood. There were indeed many little messages left in the kitchen drawers and the cupboards. The small, brown creatures that left the messages had my staff and I squealing with delight—not terror of course—as we stood on our desk tops and desperately dialled the department for the pest controller.

From the age of about 12, I have been fascinated with politics. It has in fact taken me 26 years to get here. My appetite was whetted when Steele Hall, the then Premier of South Australia, wanted to make the electoral system fair to ensure that the votes of all eligible people were of equal worth. As a 12‐year‐old, I was struck by the inherent justness of this reform and I became a devotee of Steele and the Liberal side of politics.

I would like to pay tribute to Steele for his active participation as our campaign manager in the Kingston campaign. His support and counsel I have truly valued. I would also like to pay tribute to Senator Robert Hill for giving me my first break in this business and for his continuing friendship and support.

I would also like to thank Senator Vanstone and the member for Sturt, Christopher Pyne, and his FEC for their contributions and support to my campaign. Perhaps the greatest contributor to my successful arrival in this place is my dear friend and colleague the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus). I have had the benefit of an apprenticeship to my party's most outstanding marginal seat campaigner. Chris, I have learnt from your successes and I have had the benefit of learning from your mistakes.

Even more importantly, our families will no doubt enjoy a lifelong friendship. I am thrilled that Alex is here tonight with Bruce and the rest of my family in the gallery. The one achievement of yours, however, that I have absolutely no intention of repeating is to ever win by 14 votes. I well remember the tension of those 2½ weeks after the 1990 election when no‐one knew whether or not we had won the seat of Hawker—but win it we did.

I could not let this opportunity pass without mentioning the departure from the other place across the hall of one of its most worthy senators. Senator Baden Teague's term expires at the end of June. I am truly saddened that I will not have the benefit of his company or counsel as I embark upon my work here. Baden is one of nature's true gentlemen and a rare specimen of uncompromising honesty and decency in our business. I wish Baden and Kathy a happy and constructive life after politics.

Every new member who arrives in this place no doubt has the intention of changing the world, to make it the way they think it should be—and I am no different, in that respect, from any other new member. There are, however, two problems that will be encountered by us all as we attempt to change our worlds. The first is that events in this life and in public life generally seem to have an inertia of their own. To change the direction is much harder than any of us ever imagined. There is always an interest group waiting in the wings to jump in and accost any member who wants to take something away from them or disturb their patch. They will fight to the end to defend their ground. Changing the status quo is a lot harder than one could ever imagine.

The second problem is that we do not always acknowledge that the way we want the world to be is not necessarily the way others want the world to be. This is perhaps the biggest hurdle of all. At university I studied political philosophy and had the good fortune to be a student of Professor Bill Brugger. Bill taught me that you must always search for the truth. The problem with this, as he also taught me, is that everyone's truth is different. So I am mindful of the fact that things as I see them are not necessarily as others see them. My deduction, therefore, is of course that others are not always right.

I am most fortunate to enjoy Bill's ongoing counsel. He, along with my friend that urban guerilla, Cherie Hoyle, bears the responsibility for keeping my conscience and my soul in a state of good health. So I come to the job and to the decisions I must make in the job with a commitment to search for all the relevant factors. But even in the event that you have all the necessary information available to you, you still have to make judgments based on more than just a balancing act. Judgments have to be based upon an ethical foundation and must contribute to the advancement of human society. My goal in this place is to contribute to the advancement of human society.

No political philosopher throughout history has ever got it entirely right. Philosophers build their life's work based on a depiction of human nature, and the fundamental problem is that an all‐encompassing picture of human nature is yet to be accurately constructed. Obviously, all those philosophers held up as having achieved greatness had something useful to contribute. Those who I believe have provided the most use are those who have perhaps not adhered to a rigid ideological position, those who have not sought ideological consistency for the sake of ideological consistency but who have perhaps been more pragmatic, more willing to look outside their own experiences for answers. Those who search for the whole truth and who have accommodated a range of human characteristics as they go about their work have the most to offer.

At university, the philosophy of liberalism captured my imagination, not the atomistic liberalism expressed by those whose rhetoric emphasises terms like `individual rights', but the strand that emerged through the work of John Stuart Mill and later built on by the likes of my personal favourite, Leonard Trelawney Hobhouse. Together with their peers, they recognised the interdependence of humans and the proper role of government in supporting the conditions for positive interdependence. They extended the concept of individual rights and freedoms to recognise this interdependence and the rightful role of a democratic government in ensuring the rights and freedoms of all—not just the wealthy, the privileged and the powerful.

BREAK.PARA: Michael Walzer, a contemporary writer, provides the most practical guidelines to policy developers in the liberal vein if their aim is to promote justice throughout all society. Walzer examines the various social and cultural goods that Western societies value and argues that one's success in one sphere should not bar one's access to the goods in another sphere. These are the great liberals who all provide me with the inspiration I need as I pursue my goal of contributing to the advancement of society.
At this time in our nation's development there are three key policy areas that I believe need to be addressed and my aim is to contribute to advancement in these areas as a member of this House.

Firstly, my experiences over the past 18 months as both a candidate and now as a member have, at times, shocked me. I have met a much larger number of children and families than I would have ever thought existed who have been affected by the most horrendous incidences of child abuse, and in particular child sexual abuse. I do not understand where we have gone wrong as a society to produce so many people who sexually, physically and emotionally abuse children.

My government has initiated a tough regime of national gun control measures in response to what can only be described as one of Australia's greatest tragedies, and I applaud the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) for his decisive and responsible action. But restricting access to guns is not the only measure necessary to protect the Australian people against some of their own.

We have to find out why people get to the stage where they do things like this. What goes wrong in the development of people where they depart so far from reality and from basic rules of behaviour? It seems that these things can begin to go wrong very early in the lives of children. Too many families seem to have lost the skills that are necessary to produce healthy, well‐adjusted adults, and this is undeniably our nation's greatest shame.

Those who bury their heads in the sand and deny the fundamental right of children to a healthy family environment by denying government its rightful role to ensure their protection must share the responsibility for the shame. It is for this reason that I have come to believe that we need to look at establishing something like a commissioner for children, perhaps based in the Human Rights Commission, with extensive powers to protect and foster the rights of Australia's children.

Our children deserve an advocate who will conduct ongoing research into the extent to which their rights are not upheld and their needs not met, to provide advice to governments on the basis of this research and to hold governments accountable for their actions to remedy problem areas. The ills of our society cannot be cured until we address this fundamental problem.

It is partly for the reasons that I have just outlined that I am also interested in the area of family policy and industrial relations policy, and I thank the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) for his support of my interest.

In recent weeks I have spoken to a number of employers across Australia who have successfully implemented measures to accommodate the family responsibilities of their employees. Apart from the massive social benefits to the country in treating employees like whole people who have lives outside of the company, there are considerable commercial advantages in doing so.

When employees have their minds on the job and not on family problems they are more productive. When employees return to work after parental leave the company does not lose the training investment previously placed in them. And when employees are treated as whole people, when they do not suffer the frustration and guilt associated with not being able to meet their family responsibilities, they go home and make better family members.

The Business Council of Australia and the Australian Financial Review have awarded a number of Australian companies—and yes, even the multinationals—for the initiatives that they have taken in this area. Companies such as Esso, Alcoa and Australia Post serve as outstanding examples for other companies to take up the challenge. These companies are leading the way by providing such services as family counselling and child care, by allowing flexible working hours, work at home and permanent part‐time work. They are increasingly seeing the benefits to their employees and, therefore, to their commercial competitiveness.

The main impediments to achieving family friendly workplaces are cultural rather than practical. As these companies improve their competitiveness and are increasingly seen as doing so because of their family policies other companies will follow too. But there is still a long way to go and I intend to play a major part in talking these issues up.

I envisage a system in the not too distant future where parents with young children are able to share both the income earning and the child rearing responsibilities in the household by participating in part‐time work and other family friendly measures for that portion of their working lives.

Implementation of the government's industrial relations policy will go a long way towards removing many of the barriers built into awards that limit the availability of part‐time positions and to facilitating the flexibility that parents with children so desperately need.

But the healthiest society in the world is worth nothing without a healthy environment. Hence the introduction of my third main policy interest, environment policy—although I suspect that a society which values its children would also value its environment. On both scales Australia has some dreadful shortcomings.

My electorate of Kingston has some of the most spectacular scenery that this country has to offer, including the rolling hills and vineyards of the McLaren Vale wine region, which produces many award winning wines—a fact which I shall be proving shortly to some of my colleagues. But, sadly, our beautiful coasts and hills suffer from the effects of European settlement. I do not doubt that our ancestors never intended to wreak havoc on the landscape and leave behind the chaos for their descendants to deal with. They did not have the information available to them that we have now to understand the effects of our actions on our environment.

But we do have that information and yet we are still continuing with land use activities that have resulted in the fact that half the mammal species across the world that have become extinct are Australian native species. On recent NGO figures, we are still spewing 33 tonnes of greenhouse gases per person into the atmosphere each year.

The coalition went to the March election with a policy to establish a trust fund, a substantial fund that would provide the resources to redress Australia's environmental degradation for many years to come. This was the only area of policy in which we made such a powerful and permanent commitment. The establishment of the fund depends upon the sale of one-third of Telstra. I hope that the other place does not deny the restoration of Australia's landscape, waterways and coasts based on a misplaced ideological fixation with public ownership.

I would urge all senators and members of the community with an interest in the environment to concentrate their energy on building a corporation that meets the communication needs of all Australians in a fair and equitable manner. The luxury of rigid adherence to a tired old ideological fixation is one that the Australian environment and indeed the Australian telecommunications consumer cannot afford. The emergence of ethically responsible corporations and investment funds could provide models for reference as the Telstra bill moves through the other place and the attention of senators would be usefully employed exploring such avenues.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to the many wonderful people in my electorate who give of themselves for our community without getting anything in return. There are many dedicated people who collect and sow native seeds to revegetate our barren and eroded landscapes, people who give of themselves to provide transport, aid and perhaps the most necessary service of all—companionship to our frail and elderly. There are people who work through the churches to provide assistance to families facing hardship and who pick up the pieces when families shatter. There are parents in the school canteen and on the sports field coaching our children. Without these people our communities would be much the poorer.

The economic backbone of Kingston is the small business sector. The coalition's support of small business as expressed in our election policy is one of the reasons that I am standing here tonight. I look forward to continuing to work with the small business people of my electorate to ensure that my government's policies continue to be of benefit to them.

As federal members of parliament we are well compensated for the work that we do. But I admire those who are elected to local government, and expect that all members will appreciate the commitment of their local government colleagues who give up so much of themselves for their communities. My electorate is indeed most fortunate to be served by mayors Ray Gilbert, Jim Aldridge, Colin Haines and the young Trevor Fletcher, who work tirelessly and too often without thanks to make the south a better place to be. These are the people who really matter in our society across every electorate of Australia, but we are indeed fortunate to have more than our fair share in Kingston. My staff and I look forward to continuing with the productive and harmonious relationship that we have established thus far with the local community to ensure that the south becomes an even better place to be.

We get a lot of advice in this business, but in closing I would like to acknowledge the advice given to me by the Mayoress of the City of Noarlunga. Edith said to me: `Just enjoy yourself, Susan, and then you can't help but do a good job.' I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker: what better advice could any member get?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset let me congratulate the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) on a very interesting and well‐delivered first speech in this parliament. Let me also congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew, on your elevation to the Speaker's Panel, that distinguished body. I ask you to pass on my congratulations to the Speaker, the Deputy Speaker and the Second Deputy Speaker. I am sure each of these people will fulfil their office with distinction. I also welcome the new members to the chamber and offer my congratulations on their first speeches. One hopes that the enthusiasm and vigour with which they have committed themselves to the challenges of public office do not grow dim as the years pass by.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say for myself that after 13 years in this parliament it is a change—not necessarily a refreshing or stimulating one—to be on this side of the chamber. I console myself, however, in the belief that it will not be long before Labor regains its rightful place on the treasury bench in this parliament. The bill that we are debating, the Supply Bill, confirms that.

Now that the election of 2 March is part of history and many people are commenting on it or reading messages into the outcome, I will take this opportunity to put a few of my own comments on the public record. Many of the people who voted against Labor were young couples in their thirties who have known nothing but a Labor government in parliamentary terms. These people, in general, live in a large house on a tiny block of land in a new subdivision on an ever rapidly expanding new housing estate. There are a few in my electorate. They usually have two cars in an agapanthus‐filled cul‐de‐sac ready to drop the kinder at the long day care centre. Both of them are in work and mortgaged to the eyeballs and their great worry is whether their swimming pool—which is slightly bigger than their neighbour's—will actually fit on their tiny block of land. These are the people who voted against Labor, yet these are the same people whom the conservatives will hit the hardest.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello), a couple of weeks ago during question time, was boasting about the view that the conservatives had captured the blue‐collar vote. Mr Deputy Speaker, as you and I know, this is nonsense. The conservatives captured—or, perhaps, recaptured—the middle-class vote. In my area, a traditional Labor heartland, Labor's vote was maintained. In fact, I was one of the few people who actually had a swing towards me. In the suburb of Cringila, for example, Labor maintained 85 per cent of the two‐party preferred vote, as it did in Lake Heights, Warrawong, Berkeley, Port Kembla and Warilla. We all got votes of this proportion. There was a slight vote against Labor in the new development areas of West Dapto and Albion Park, which are experiencing a spasm of new housing development.

At the time of the last election many people wanted to punish Labor for real or perceived sins. I can well remember advising voters in my area not to give Labor a hiding, and I am proud that the voters in Throsby—unlike voters in so many other parts of Australia—stuck with me and Labor. Unfortunately, voters in other areas got their rocks off in five minutes of voting glory. But what a price they will pay, a price some of them are beginning to realise only now—not least, of course, the members of the National Tertiary Education Union, Wollongong University Branch.

Members of this union were locked in a pay dispute which all four local federal members in the Illawarra area publicly supported. We, in fact, lobbied in Canberra in support of the Wollongong university academics' rightful pay claim. The branch president, Michael Morrissey, wrote to me and my Illawarra colleagues on 18 January advising that the university academics would be voting against us. He said that at a general meeting it was resolved unanimously that the union would be campaigning actively against any party or individual in opposition to their current pay claim.

The actions included leafleting, a publicity campaign targeting nine marginal seats in New South Wales, participating in anti‐government demonstrations and determined industrial action. So be it. I, as I am wont to do, responded to that letter. For the public record, I will read part of what I said to Mr Morrissey about this threat to me. I thanked him for his letter of 18 January informing me that the union was going to campaign against the Australian Labor Party in the federal seats of Gilmore and Macarthur. I went on to say:

As you would appreciate, in a democratic society how one casts their vote in a general election is entirely a matter for the individual. If the National Tertiary Education Union feels that they will get a better deal from the conservatives, and on all their social and economic issues that they will be better treated by the conservatives then I suppose, regardless of what I or any other Member or candidate says, they will vote for the conservatives. Being academics one would assume that some research would be carried out into the record in regard to the conservative and ALP policies regarding universities and I would be somewhat surprised if the academics reached the conclusion that they would be better off under the conservatives, but then one lives in a world of surprises. I guess nothing really surprises me. Undoubtedly, too, after a federal election all Labor members—be they in government or opposition—will remember the activities of the various interest and lobby groups during the election campaign.

I would be surprised if the disruption to enrolments of university students was a main issue in the forthcoming federal election. I must say that at this time in the lead up to an election I receive on average four letters a day from various interest groups throughout Australia informing me that unless I take some particular action or endorse some particular program various people will not vote for me.

It just so happens that I can also remember flicking through the local newspaper a couple of weeks before the election and seeing an open letter from Mr Morrissey suggesting that the ALP should be put last on the ballot paper in the Illawarra.

That is fair enough in a democratic society, but imagine my surprise when on 1 May 1996 the Illawarra Mercury carried an article under the heading `150 uni jobs may be axed'. In that article, Mr Michael Morrissey—the same Mr Morrissey who had campaigned so loudly during the election period for the election of a coalition government—complained about academic staff losses and cuts in higher education research grants. The article quoted Mr Morrissey as saying that he urged all residents to write to their local federal members to protest about those cuts.

When residents write to me protesting about those cuts, I send them out a copy of my letter of 22 January to Mr Morrissey. I also send them a copy of Mr Morrissey's letter to me of 18 January. Academics obviously have very short memories; politicians have very long ones.

Today, at the front of the University of Wollongong, the students marked out the size of the cuts on university functions and services proposed by the government. I support the students' action, but again I have to wonder whether it is all a little too late. The University of Wollongong is within the boundaries of the electorate of my colleague the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), but many of the students are from my electorate of Throsby. During the recent election campaign, the student representative council put on a `meet the candidates' seminar. Those who turned out were, in the main, plants or stooges. The average student there was fairly apathetic to the campaign.

Both the member for Cunningham and I warned the university and the students during the campaign about what was in store for them if a conservative coalition was elected. But they were too apathetic to take any action and I suspect that a number of them, especially the academics, voted for the conservatives. So disgusted was the local newspaper at that forum that it gave the article about the meeting the heading `Yawn—student forum fails'.

The students at that university, and universities in general throughout Australia, will pay a price for their apathy and for being so deluded by the conservatives. Incidentally, the impact on the economy of the Illawarra will be in the order of $50 million in wages lost.

As you would be aware, speculation has been rife for some time about the government's intention to cut the public sector. Broadly, we have an idea where the cuts will be made and what implication these cuts are going to have. Of course, as all ministers are parroting the same line, we will have to wait until 20 August when the Treasurer announces these cuts in the budget. We know that all Australians are about to face a tidal wave of cuts, with 20,000 Public Service positions being gutted. Every single department and agency will have a date with an axe. There is no place to hide. The effects will be real; they will be felt by all of us and will be very painful.

Australians have always enjoyed the sport of giving public servants a good kick, or making them the butt of some good one‐liners, but they certainly do not hesitate to pick up the telephone and angrily inform me and my office of what an outrage it is to have to wait in a queue at the local office of the Department of Social Security, the Taxation Office or the CES.

BREAK.PARA: Recently we have been hearing about the tragic experiences of abused young children, and children in New South Wales. We have all thrown our arms up in despair. But is there a realisation that perhaps, if the departments charged with ensuring the welfare and wellbeing of these children and young people had been better resourced with staff, some of the experiences these kids have had could have been prevented?

This is not bleeding heart stuff. It is the reality of cutting back on staff in departments charged with an important service delivery. The former Premier of New South Wales, now the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey)—and I am pleased to see that the honourable member for Gilmore (Ms Gash) is in the House because she would know this too—should face the fact, and it should weigh on his mind, that it was his government that inflicted substantial cuts in the Department of Community Services, especially in the Nowra area.

In the Nowra area, it was so bad that the department would only deal with kids who were actually at risk. It did not have the staff there to do the whole of the investigative or reporting work. That was the result of the conservative government in New South Wales cutting funds to that service in Nowra—and the fact that that was happening was a disgrace. Now it is trying to rectify that and has, over recent months, drastically increased the staff in that department. But it is a matter of training the staff and bringing them up to speed. Had those cuts not been made, I am suggesting that much of the abuse and neglect which has been experienced by many of those kids—kids we all throw our hands up about when we read of child abuse and neglect—might well not have happened.

This government is being true to the old adage: penny‐wise and, indeed, pound‐foolish. Customs Service staff, for instance, will be reduced nationally by 400. In my own electorate, which has the major port facility of Port Kembla at its centre, the Customs Service staff will be cut from 15 to five. But that is not the end of the matter. The remaining staff will now have to operate office hours of nine to 5 p.m.

Port Kembla, one of the busiest port facilities in Australia, will now be a prime target for drug traffickers, shonky importers and others of ill repute. They will know that they will not have to undergo inspections or clearance requirements of Customs—because all the Customs officers will be able to do there is the paperwork. They will know that, if they arrive at a jetty in Port Kembla, they will not be met by enforcers of the law but by a couple of fishermen angling for a catch. Port Kembla will be open to all kinds of abuse; it will be the gateway of abuse—and all due to the government's penny‐wise, pound‐foolish approach to the public sector.

Members are aware that I take a great interest in shipping. Later this week I will again have the opportunity to indulge this interest by addressing another foolish piece of legislation. But I have often heard the now minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), and some of his colleagues go on about the cost of shipping operations. These Customs Service cuts and the implementation of office hour shifts to our port will do nothing but increase the costs of shipping. Should a ship arrive outside of office hours of, say, nine to five imposed on Customs Service officials, these ships will be forced to wait out at sea until the office hour shifts recommence on the following day.

Is the government seeking to reverse the efficiencies made on the waterfront in recent years? Or will it, as I suspect, use this in its hate war with the Maritime Union of Australia? Meetings of trade unions, community groups and public sector organisations have already been held in the Illawarra to campaign against these cuts. Any community, political and industrial campaigns against these unjustifiable attacks on the public sector have my own support and, indeed, that of my Labor colleagues.
