The conservatives have no mandate to savagely cut the public sector, its employees and its services, nor do they have a mandate to close the Wollongong office of the department of immigration, as they announced today. It amazes me that here, in the most ethnically diverse part of Australia, they are going to replace that office of well‐trained officials with a telephone service. On an average, I would contact that office four times a day. I use that office at least once a day. On some occasions I use it four or six times a day. Every time I use it, I go there as a last resort; it is always a difficult case.

In my area we have many residents from former Yugoslavia, be they Serbs, Croats or Macedonians. They might be having great difficulties with migration; they might have great concern about families and great worries about visas. How are they going to deal on the telephone with an office in Rockdale when they want an extension to their visa or, indeed, a visa? What if they want to make a personal inquiry or lodge a migration application form? Instead of going to the office in Berelli Street, Wollongong—which is their right—they will have to go to the office in the Sydney suburb of Rockdale. To do that will take them away for a day.

As someone said to me today about the closure of the office in Townsville—and having been on a committee of inquiry that was looking at people coming down, or the possibility of people coming down, through the Torres Strait and entering Australia there—do they think that Townsville is next door to Brisbane? I thought it was bad enough with people from the Illawarra having to go to Rockdale, but now it is even worse with the people from Townsville having to go to Brisbane or maybe having to make telephone calls.

This new government has no mandate to sack nurses, police and teachers, to allow fewer TAFE and university admissions, to increase waiting times for nursing homes and child‐care centres, to allow longer queues at Social Security and CES offices, to close regional Taxation offices and offices of the Family Court and to reduce funding to a host of other important programs and agencies. The justification for these cuts is to satisfy the conservative craving—to imitate the tactics of Thatcher's Britain.

The government is using the traditional caution of the Treasury to exaggerate the budget deficit and to con the electorate into believing that these cuts are needed. It is a standard textbook approach adopted by conservative governments throughout the world. The fact is that there is no fat to trim from the bone. Australia cannot afford these cuts. The public sector provides vital community services which Australians are entitled to and indeed deserve. These cuts are not just about job losses; they are about undermining service delivery. We cannot afford to do without the public sector and we will fight to keep it.

I do not think the government realises the fight they are going to have on their hands. We saw a bit of it in Sydney last Friday. I can assure them that the people of Wollongong and the Illawarra will not accept this. We have always had a reputation for militancy in that area and we will continue that way.

It saddens me that Australia will go from a country which, over recent years, had one of the lowest levels of industrial disputation in the Western world—and that is a record that we have held in this country—to a country which has one of the highest levels of industrial disputation in the world. That is due to the ideological bent of this government to smash the trade union movement. Those who have had a background in the trade union movement will not stand by and see that happen. We will fight these cuts. We will continue to fight attacks on the trade union movement as we have done in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Bradfield, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in rising to make my first speech in the parliament, I, through you, would like to congratulate the Speaker of the House on his election to the highest office that the House can confer upon a member and wish him the courage and wisdom that the position requires. I also congratulate my friends and colleagues from both sides of the House on the quality and depth of their first speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: I am honoured to be here to represent the people of Bradfield—an electorate that covers what is known commonly as Sydney's Upper North Shore. Proclaimed in 1949 and named after John Bradfield, engineer and bridge designer, it follows the Pacific Highway from Chatswood West in the south to Wahroonga in the north, across to Belrose in the north‐east and Castle Cove in the south-east. It is predominantly a residential area, within which live some of the most influential and resourceful people in the country. That is what makes it most special. It also contains a number of light manufacturing, service industries and commercial industries and some government administration.

From the outset, and on behalf of the people of Bradfield, I wish to acknowledge the loyal service and hard work for over two decades of my predecessor, Mr David Connolly, his wife, Monique, and their family and wish them well for the future. I would not be here now if it were not for the dedicated hard work and sacrifice of so many people, only a few of whom can I now specifically recognise. As I mention them, I am reminded of the words of Isaac Newton: `If I could see further than others it was because I stood on the shoulders of giants.'

To my father who instilled in me the value of education, decent tolerance and respect of others and a work ethic that he thought was always in the Australian Labor Party, thank you. I thank my mother, Pat, for her intelligence and her empathy and for teaching me the importance of having a passionate commitment to those things in which you believe.

My wife, Kate, married a doctor, not a politician. Yet when I told her on 7 September 1994 that I had `had enough' and would seek Liberal Party preselection, her response was, `I knew that some day you would do this. It is not something I would want for us and our children, but I will do my best to support you.' In giving up what little financial security and privacy we had, moving interstate and then being indirectly subjected to some rather insensitive ridicule and denigration, she has given much more than me.

To my son, Tom, who has already told me he would `not like to be a politician', and to my daughter, Emily, who understands that I have gone into politics `to help other people', thank you. I would also like to recognise a number of those people who at times, with some courage, reached out to support me: Don Glover, my campaign director, mentor and friend; Rhondda Vanzella, the Northern Regional Metropolitan President of the Liberal Party, who recognised the urgency of the party's situation in 1994 and has followed me the length and breadth of Australia ever since to promote the Liberal message; Doug Lowe—this may seem unusual—a former Labor Premier, my friend and mentor who taught me that no‐one has a monopoly on what is right or wrong and to always look for good in others; Bill and Betty Flick; Peter and Norma Beckley; Denise and Ross Reid; Tony Fox, my FEC president; Robert Longstaff; Kathryn Greiner; Michael Yabsley; and, in particular, my friends and colleagues from the Australian Medical Association who in 1993 conferred upon me the privilege of leading what was at times a dangerously difficult agenda for reform but one that was badly needed.

Also, I would not be here were it not for the courageous foresight of a man I have come to love, respect and admire, that is, my friend Dr Bruce Shepherd. Above all else, he has taught me the importance of being prepared to fight for the things in which you believe and that the solutions of life will be found in helping others to help themselves and their families. Finally, I mention Raphael Klaesi, a man whom I had never met but who designed the Bradfield logo, which says, quite simply, `Put your heart in it.'

PARA.BREAK: There are others whose lives have touched me and who played a significant and critical role in making me who I am. They are people whose names I do not remember. But when you attend a cot death at 5 o'clock in the morning, or you visit a home just after midnight when parents have been informed that their teenage son has been killed in a car accident, or you sit in the kitchen of a modest home where the bank is about to foreclose due to unexpected unemployment, or you visit the home of a young girl who has been raped by her father—although nothing prepares you for these experiences as you struggle with your helplessness and your inability to pro vide sufficient comfort, more than anything else they are some of the experiences that will keep me true to my principles and certainly not change me by the time I finish here. Those principles are commitment, compassion and conscience instilled in me sequentially by my parents, the Jesuits and the Hippocratic principles upon which the medical profession is based.

SPEECH.PARA: So why am I here? What will drive me and what are some of the issues to which I commit myself? I did not plan on being a politician but there were a number of critical events that happened to me as I went along. On 2 June 1992 I spoke to the National Press Club about unemployment and the health consequences of it. When I had finished, Ian Spicer, the then Executive Director of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, was asked a question about the employment of young Australians. He got up and gave a reply that was based then on a survey that the chamber had just done of the top 200 employers in Australia. Essentially he was proposing a change to the way in which youth wages and conditions were to be negotiated.

Before he could get his backside back on the chair, Bill Mansfield, the then Vice‐President of the ACTU, sprang to his feet and said, `Absolutely under no circumstances will the union movement of Australia ever talk to employers about anything like that.' As I stood there listening to this, I thought, `My God, listen to this. Here are the people who create wealth in this country and who could and should employ more Australians saying, "This is what the problem is, whatever the merits of the solution," and then the Labor movement is saying, "No, we're not even going to talk about it," at a time when we have 34 per cent national youth unemployment and 47 per cent youth unemployment in areas like Liverpool in New South Wales.'

When I was Vice‐President of the AMA, I was told by the Labor health minister that I should `not bother telling the then government what I thought it ought to do and that, if I wanted to change anything that government was doing, I would have to change the government'. I was then told by his successor that people were `wasting their money having private health insurance' and that they ought to do what she did. When I inquired what that was, it was to pay cash. There we were representing a million families in Australia earning less than $40,000 a year, half a million people on health care cards and 800,000 pensioners who still made enormous sacrifices to care for themselves and their families, and government wasn't listening.

When I went through the preselection experience—which I know the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) found equally character building—one of my preselectors said to me, `Dr Nelson, you seem to be in a bit of a hurry. Why don't you wait until you're 40 and your wife has another baby? If you really want to be in politics, we'll find a nice place for you to go where you do not have to cause all this trouble.' The lady next to me suggested that I would be more comfortable in the eastern suburbs with an earring. You are damned right I am in a hurry.

Every hour of the day our children are going into debt, with Australia's current account problem at the rate of over $2 million an hour. At the end of every day there are 48 small businesses in this country that have gone broke. There are 800 people leaving private health insurance every day to rely on public hospitals because they can no longer afford the premium. So despairing are they of the kind of future they see ahead of them that every day one young Australian between the ages of 15 and 24 commits suicide and another 50 try.

There are dozens of families who find day after day what some of us have been on about for a number of years—that is, unless we change the way that wealth is created we have absolutely no hope whatsoever of providing institutional, residential or nursing home care to the population as it ages. And we were told, `This is as good as it gets.' For people in business, if you did not like it you were instructed by the previous Prime Minister to go back on to PAYE. I can tell you that that is what I am doing, but I do not think that is what he had in mind when he gave the advice.

I have surveyed the people of my electorate to find out the things that are most important to them. Apart from the aeroplanes that have been pushed over our houses day after day, the broadband cables that are being rolled out and over which we seem to have no control and telecommunications towers popping up all over the place, the things that are most important to them are essentially Australia's foreign debt, taxation reform and Australia's health care system.

There was a time when Australians and others frequently referred to us as a `lucky country'; but you do not hear that so often these days. It seems that in many ways luck has become our problem. Over the last 13 years in particular, every year we have sold a little more of our country and we have borrowed more money from overseas to maintain an unsustainably high expectation of what government can provide. Our current account‐GDP ratio, running at around 5.5 per cent, is more than twice that of any other OECD country. We have run external deficits in 28 of the last 30 years. Our net foreign debt is 40 per cent of GDP. We spend four per cent of GDP servicing our debt and equity obligations, and it is increasing. We have a miserable savings rate nationally of 18 per cent of GDP and a disposable personal income savings rate of three per cent.

The much touted ACTU-government accord, about which the member for Batman made great things in his maiden speech, has basically reinforced the very things that stopped job creation. It has reinforced and given support to budget deficits, which have put pressure on interest rates. It has basically supported an inefficient and inequitable taxation system. When you look at the results of the ACTU-government accord you see that in the first 10 years—from 1984 to 1994—with an average annual growth rate of 3½ per cent, 160,000 jobs were created in the private sector. But unemployment still increased from 687,000 to 850,000.

The new `cures' for unemployment—training, job subsidy schemes, moving widows and middle‐aged people onto pensions—do not work. If you talk to people in business, including the businesses in my electorate or anywhere else, you find that they could and should employ more Australians, but they cannot and they will not because the tax system is far too complex, the industrial relations environment is far too inflexible and they are overloaded with bureaucratic and administrative burdens. These are the things that the Howard government is moving right now to address.

I believe it is time in Australia that we had a serious debate about taxation reform, which has never been a sane pursuit. The first thing we need to do is educate Australians about the language—what is sales tax, what is payroll tax, what is wholesale sales tax or FBT. The entire system needs simplification. The monumental size and complexity of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the entire industry which surrounds it are in themselves arguments for change.

We need to move away from a tax system which is focused on the very things we are trying to encourage—employment, productivity and savings. We cannot encourage wealth creation without simplification and we cannot sustain government spending without broadening the tax base. The looming impact of the Internet on tax avoidance completes a picture of national urgency on this issue, to which I will be the most committed during my time here.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) was reported in the Australian Financial Review on 30 April this year as saying that `revisiting the consumption tax debate would not be helpful to the ALP'. That may be the case. It is probably not helpful to the government either, and I suspect it will not help my personal political career. But what about us doing something that is `helpful' for Australia's next generation and committing ourselves on both sides of this chamber to putting taxation reform back on the political agenda? The Business Council of Australia's Access Economics modelling, about which the opposition was so preoccupied a couple of weeks ago, calculated long run gains from reform of indirect taxes and subsidies at two per cent of GDP, or $10 billion. We could finance a lot of education, health or Aboriginal services from that amount of money.

As the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) said only two weeks ago and I have maintained for a long time, the present health financing arrangements are unsustainable. Australians need to realise that there is a limit to what governments can provide in terms of health care. Until such time as we provide support, political and financial, for people who wish to look after themselves and their families by supporting private health insurance, then frankly we have no hope. I also think it is time that we on both sides of politics worked as much as practicable towards setting some priorities for what the Australian government can and will fund in terms of health care.

Another area which I think more than any other during my time here will change the political, economic and social priorities of this country is the ageing of the Australian population. By the year 2001, the number of people over the age of 65 will have increased by 27 per cent. By the middle of the next century, a third of us will be over the age of 65. At present we spend more on housing criminals in Australia than we do on caring for people in nursing homes and residential institutions.

Whoever is in government, and hopefully it will be us for many years to come, there will continue to be people who are unemployed. There are serious human and health consequences of unemployment: 50 per cent more doctor visits a year, 35 per cent more admissions to hospital, a death rate which is 17 per cent higher and a 20 per cent higher death rate for the wives of unemployed men.

I believe that we ought to be considering, as the Anglican Bishop of Brisbane, Peter Hollingworth, argued unsuccessfully in 1992, that it is time in Australia that we started to pilot on a voluntary basis community development employment programs for people who are unemployed as a means of maintaining a sense of self‐worth and self‐esteem. Similarly, it is time that we changed the attitudes of Australians toward those who are unemployed. Most people who are unemployed are unemployed through no fault of their own. They are not dole bludgers or anything of the sort.

Over the last 13 years we have created a world in which many Australians expect that the Australian government will provide for them and we have cut a whole range of people out of the economic mainstream. I think it is time that we said to every Australian, whoever they are or wherever they were born, `There is a place for you. We will care for you, but we want you to make some kind of contribution to our future.'

On average, as I said earlier, one young Australian commits suicide every day, and there are another 50 who try. There are many reasons for it. It would be wrong to say it is entirely the fault of government, but government plays a big role in determining what kinds of values and priorities we have. In looking at the problems young people have we find 30 per cent of those who are looking for a job cannot find one and 60,000 young people in this country are long-term unemployed. There are 22,000 homeless children whom we know of, and we have 600,000 kids living in poverty. We have countless numbers who are remaining in the education system beyond their natural abilities for jobs that they think are not likely to exist. The threshold of resistance to despair has been lowered for a generation that have really lost confidence that we who profess to lead in public life either do not understand or perhaps do not even care about the sorts of problems they face.

Like my colleague the honourable member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes), I will be arguing for a national office for children and for youth, to put all kinds of legislation up for scrutiny in terms of what it will do for children, to give young people a political voice in the system so that they feel their future is not simply the subject of political exploitation, and to coordinate and advocate programs for young people.

One of the other issues to which I remain deeply committed is that of the health of Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Life expectancy is 15 to 20 years less than that enjoyed by non-indigenous people. We are unique amongst countries in the developed world in that we are not reducing the gap between life expectancy for indigenous and non-indigenous people. I spent time in Kenya and in Tanzania for World Vision. People asked me what it was like. Of course it was terrible, but I can tell you that, with the exception of AIDS, I did not see in those countries anything as bad as I have seen in Aboriginal Australia.

There are many reasons for it, but I think the former health minister, Graham Richardson, gave us some insight into the cause of the problem when, whilst visiting the Kimberleys—a trip for which I declined an invitation, by the way—Charles Woolley of the 60 Minutes program asked him, `Why, Minister, after 11 years in government, is the situation still so bad?' He said, `I have spent a lifetime reading polls, and concern for Aboriginal people is not in the top million issues worrying the voters.' Amongst the numerous solutions which need to be undertaken and which our government has already commenced, I think we need to work with Aboriginal people, as Noel Pearson said in 1994, to see whether in fact welfare payments can be changed in some way to provide resources to Aboriginal people in a different way which might provide better outcomes.

Yes, I am one of those people who watch A Current Affair at 6.30 and I am one of those people who read the Daily Telegraph—please don't tell Phillip Adams that—and my blood pressure goes through the roof. You ask yourself how one person can make a difference. How can any of us as individuals here, whatever side we are on, make some difference to it? I am not what you would call, I suppose, the orthodox person to be privileged to be the Liberal member for the seat of Bradfield. I did not learn Liberalism the way many of my colleagues did. But, as far as I am concerned, it is the political expression of a life that is spent amongst people. It is about familiarity with hard work, self‐sacrifice and idealism in everyday life. It is about asking yourself, as Ronald Reagan used to say: is the government the problem or is the government the solution?

The real challenge for us is to see that we confront controversy in a constructive and a considered manner, to keep challenging the nation's thinking on a range of fundamental social, health and economic issues. In doing so, I think we need to question whether we are relating decisions we make to values that society has. Over the last 13 years we have become a selfish country of people who think that their rights are more important than their responsibilities and value is more important than values. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is here tonight and he is a man who represents what leadership is all about—not the drivel that was fed to us in the election campaign from the other side. Real leadership is about trying to evoke in people a genuine desire to overcome our own self‐interest, to support things which are best for the community and for the country. Creating common ground and trying to find solutions to intractable problems are far more difficult tasks than ideological invective and party political abuse.

I want to see this country become one in which we value the health and integrity of human life, as the Prime Minister has demonstrated in the last three weeks, as much as we do achieving our economic objectives. In the end it is what we believe, our sense of values and the way we behave which will determine our destiny—not some of the things which have preoccupied this House in recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join other members of the House in congratulating the new member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) on an impressive and interesting first speech. I welcome him to the House and note that he moves in a longstanding and extraordinary tradition in the seat of Bradfield in that the first member and now the latest member for that seat started out their political careers with an ALP membership ticket in their pocket. Billy Hughes was the first member for Bradfield between 1949 and 1952. He was known by some in Australian politics as the Little Digger, but I must say that we on this side of the House still call him a Labor rat, because we do have long memories and these things we never forget. The seat has had four members: Billy Hughes, Henry Turner, David Connolly and now Dr Nelson. It is quite remarkable that two of those members started out with the Labor Party. I suppose that we on this side of the House need to take solace from that fact and appreciate that it is probably the only way we would ever penetrate a blue ribbon tory seat like that and the only way we would ever penetrate the blue rinse set or the BMW set on the North Shore of Sydney. It is an interesting thing.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today we had a debate about the quality of Labor Party preselection outcomes. I can assure those opposite that in the Australian Labor Party, whether you are male or female, whether you are young or old and whether you were born here or born overseas, there is one guarantee, that is, you have served a good apprenticeship for the cause of Labor. You have probably tied a good part of your life, your emotions and your commitment to the cause of Labor. There is none of this walk‐in, walk‐out stuff on our side of politics, whereas you can walk into the Liberal Party one day and the next day you walk out as a candidate or even a member of parliament.

So, while there may be some criticisms from time to time about Labor Party preselection, when it comes to a lifetime commitment for the values that we hold dear, looking at our members and the things they have been through in politics, there is no revolving door. I can assure the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) that there is no walk‐in, walk‐out style of preselection and commitment in the Australian Labor Party.

These bills are the first granting of supply to the Howard‐Fischer government. It is appropriate for the House to examine the strategies by which this supply will be used and to understand the way in which this government is developing its policy framework. Indeed, I think it is fair to suggest that there are four defining characteristics of the Howard-Fischer government. The first is its repeated breach of election commitments to the Australian people. In the election campaign, Prime Minister Howard put his hand on his heart and promised the Australian people there would be no new taxes or tax increases if he were elected on 2 March.

Since then, we have seen a three per cent import tax—a tax that hits all consumers in all parts of Australia. We are about to see a 0.2 per cent increase in the Medicare levy, albeit in extraordinary circumstances. The government is even going so far as to moot a death tax in aged care. It has been one of the suggestions for the budget in August. Later this week we will see in the parliament, despite the promise to reduce the uplift factor on provisional tax to six per cent, the permanent rate for small business and for self‐funded retirees throughout the country being kept at 10 per cent—in clear breach of coalition election commitments.

Away from tax, the record gets no better. The coalition promised that, if they were elected on 2 March, no Australian worker would be worse off. Under their industrial relations policy, the Minister for Industrial Relations, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith), supported the individual bargains struck at Tweed Valley. That was a case where the individual contracts transferred $250,000 net in benefits from the workers to the company—a clear instance of where the workers of that enterprise, under the individual contracts and exploitation, are much worse off. It was an agreement supported by the Minister for Industrial Relations, yet he said that no worker would be worse off under this government.

The Minister for Industrial Relations is back to supporting a youth wage—a policy that does nothing more than churn workers through the work force. It simply displaces older workers in the retail sector and replaces them with younger workers at a lower wage. There is no net gain in employment. Those younger workers are worse off, contrary to the coalition's very clear election promise.

The government has announced that it opposes the ACTU's submission for a living wage, the idea that a higher minimum wage can be struck in Australia, a wage which covers the cost of active citizenship. An initiative which any government should support in a country with a strong traded sector is a strong minimum wage in the non-traded sector. Again, contrary to its commitment to working Australians, it is failing to support the ACTU in that very important submission to the Industrial Relations Commission later this year.

BREAK.PARA: In social policy, the record is even worse. HECS is to go up. There is speculation about a co‐payment. There has been a breach of the policy to introduce the ISDN telecommunications link throughout all of Australia. There is speculation about increased pharmaceutical payments for pensioners. There is the certain breach of their commitment to maintain financial assistance grants at the projected rate for local government. There are the cuts to the non-government school sector. Again, these are all in clear breach of the coalition's election promise.

The business programs they promised to keep are now under the axe, like the export market development grants program. None of this of course has anything to do with the budgetary position. None of these breaches—none of these broken promises—have anything to do with the fiscal position. But do not just trust me on that. Trust the Prime Minister. It was the Prime Minister, then the Leader of the Opposition, who was asked on the John Laws program, `You have a choice: keep your promises at a fiscal cost or break your promises to balance the budget. What is your choice? What is your promise to the Australian people?' Again, he put his hand on his heart and said, `We will keep our promises, even if it means a budget deficit.' So that is the measure of the man, that is the measure of this government and that is the measure of his moral standards in public life. You cannot even believe the Prime Minister's promise to keep his promises.

The government have tried to establish this bogus alibi about the budgetary position. There is one thing about a flaky alibi: sooner or later the cat gets out of the bag. It was the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on the Sunday program on 12 May who was asked by Laurie Oakes:
If Treasury revises its growth forecast again, will you change your $8 billion target in the budget?
The Treasurer, in response, said:
Yes, but I wanted to make this point. The black hole was the non‐disclosure. That was the point—the non‐disclosure.

There in a very neat summary—a clear question and a clear answer—is a total exposure of the flaky alibi, the so‐called budget hole. The Treasurer said that if the forecasts change then the fiscal position changes, and the allegation can fall to nothing. The Treasurer acknowledges that, if the growth forecasts by Treasury were to improve, the allegation about a budget problem would dissolve because the question of the fiscal position is not related to May 1996; it is a forecast. It is the Treasury talking about what might happen, in their assessment, between July 1996 and June 1997. It is nothing more than a forecast. If the growth forecasts change, then the budget numbers change—and he acknowledged that.

So if the Treasurer is into disclosure and a charter of budget honesty and open government, perhaps he could tell us the latest forecasts. He can whip them together within 48 hours, so we know it can be done. He should make those statistics available to the House. Beyond that, his comments indicated the very good point that he regards the so‐called black hole to be a question of non‐disclosure. It is not a fiscal point, it is not a point about the budget. He said it is about whether or not the budget figures, no matter their size, dimension or accuracy in the context of an election campaign, were going to be revealed. It is not a question of the budget forecast for 1996‐97. He said that this is a disclosure point.

The absolutely rich irony is that the Treasurer was talking about a disclosure issue on which he had been a regular forecaster. Back in December, Access Economics published figures to say that because growth is slowing Commonwealth outlays will blow out and revenue will tighten. As a product, the budget will have a larger deficit than the Treasury had initially forecast. That is not surprising. Every single public and private economic forecasting group in Australia has acknowledged for 12 months—quite sensibly and quite naturally—that the economy was slowing through that part of the business cycle.

The Treasurer is saying that even though he had been advised by his shadow treasury, by Access Economics, that the budgetary position was weakening he was willing to go into the election campaign with a particular set of promises which he now cannot fund or keep—so he is seeking an alibi. He is saying, `Look, the Labor Party has done all these things wrong.' But the Labor Party has done nothing wrong or unusual in the lead‐up to the election campaign.

What other sources do we have? We have none other than Two‐neurone Tim, the Deputy Prime Minister, who let it slip in the campaign that the budget was weakening. No less a Liberal authority than Jeff Kennett also said the budget was weakening. So they knew all these things. There is no disclosure issue because they were the ones doing the disclosing in the lead‐up to the election campaign, saying that the economy was slowing and that the budget position was weakening.

There is no black hole; there is a set of forecasts which can change from day to day, week to week or month to month, depending on how quickly the Treasury cobble together their forecasts. These things have been common knowledge in the public debate, not least within the Liberal and National parties, for at least 12 months. That is the truth and substance of this flaky, weak, dissolving alibi that the Liberal Party has tried to construct.

What are the Liberals trying to hide? It is fairly clear that they are trying to hide the revival of Fightback. The things those on the conservative side of politics truly believe in are called Fightback. That is no secret. But, in their assessment, the things they needed to promise to win an election were not called Fightback; they were called different things that they had no intention of implementing. The things they believe in, the things they want to implement, are called Fightback. This is the sole reason for the construction of this awkward and flaky alibi.

Of course, they are also trying to hide the weakness in their economic strategy. This Howard‐Fischer government is committed to a low growth, high interest rate strategy. The motto of this government is: all pain, no gain.

At the moment the economy is not yet at the bottom of the business cycle. And this when the monetary authorities would have been looking for an interest rate cut. There would have been a cut if they had certainty about the future movement of wages. If there had been an agreement with the Australian trade union movement on wage outcomes 12 to 18 months from now, the monetary authorities, the Reserve Bank of Australia, would have had the certainty by which they could cut rates.

But what happened on election night, 2 March? That certainty was ripped in two, it was thrown out the window. Any concept of cooperation and sensible wages policy agreement with the Australian trade union movement was torn in two. John Howard tore it in two. He ripped away the prospect of wages certainty and, as he did, he dissolved any opportunity the Reserve Bank had in the current economic circumstances to produce the interest rate cut that the Australian economy would otherwise have received.

But, again, don't just take my word for it. Syntec, the independent forecasting group—no friend of the Australian Labor Party necessarily—have said that under a Labor government with the accord in place, with wages certainty, with that certainty in the pocket of the Reserve Bank of Australia, there now would have been an interest rate cut. It is a great shame that that has not been the case.

Out of that we have had a flow‐on effect. You cannot have monetary policy in the wrong position without damaging other parts of the economy. People have been asking why the Australian dollar is so high. It is because our underlying inflation rates are too high. The Australian dollar, which is driving down our export competitiveness, which will have a contractionary effect on the economy in the medium term, is too high because the underlying interest rates are too high. They are too high because the Prime Minister tore up the accord on 2 March.

It is not only home buyers, small businesses and ordinary Australians who are suffering from high underlying interest rates under this government. Exporters, the traded sector and Australia's international competitiveness are also suffering.

I have to say this about the coalition: looking at the sweep of economic policy as it is being made around the world with the globalisation of capital movements, you cannot do anything dumber than rip up wages policy. You could hardly do anything dumber in the current context, because as you globalise the economy your fiscal policy is not the weapon that it was because you get the spill‐over effects on the external account, your monetary policy is subject to the convergence of interest rate patterns between nations, such is the mobility of capital. So the one thing governments could have left in their hands to have autonomous, national economic policy instruments at their disposal is wages policy.

On 2 March, John Howard got in his hands the capacity to form a sensible agreement with the trade union movement and he ripped it in two to the lasting cost of home buyers, small businesses, exporters and the standard of living of ordinary Australians. It was a dumb thing to do. It just underlines the fact that under this government it is all pain and no gain. But, again, don't just trust me on it.

We had a debate earlier today about the relationship between fiscal policy and interest rate movements. What does the Reserve Bank have to say about it? The Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) has come out and said that his fiscal consolidation strategy will produce an interest rate cut. He does not make interest rates; the Reserve Bank makes them. What did the Governor of the Reserve Bank say on 28 March? He said this:
What does all this mean for monetary policy?—
talking about their budget strategy—

The short answer, accepting that the foreshadowed fiscal restraint will be delivered, is probably not a lot. There is no presumption at this time of any trade‐off between fiscal restraint and interest rate reductions.

So the pain of the $10 billion cuts and their impact on middle Australia and living standards across the nation is all for no gain. No interest rate cut from the horse's mouth—the Governor of the Reserve Bank, the monetary authority, the man who sets the interest rates says there is no trade‐off, contrary to the nonsense that the Minister for Finance, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister tell this House.

Look at contraction, the other arm of their budget strategy. Look at an economy that is slowing as a deliberate product of this government's policy. You cannot take over two per cent of GDP out of the income expenditure stream and not slow the economy. This budget strategy is knocking half a per cent off the growth rate. It is taking 30,000 jobs out of the public sector and, as they come out of the public sector, jobs come out of the private sector because there is a loss of spending power, particularly in regional economies.

You get a loss on average of $67 million worth of spending power out of every federal electorate. If you divide the $10 billion cut by 148, there is $67 million of lost public spending power coming out of every electorate and there is no automatic replacement effect by the private sector. In Campbelltown, in Liverpool, in the seat of Werriwa that means unemployment, that means a slowing economy, that means a loss of resources, a loss of aggregate demand and spending power that just will not be replaced.

But again, look at what the coalition's own fellow travellers have to say. Access Economics in its five-year forecast: `The budget is shaping up as a key short-term negative for 1996-97.' It is going to push unemployment back over nine per cent. `These policies will bleed money away from the wholesale and retail trade sector', the very backbone of the small business sector that this government says it supports. So it is all the pain of a contracting budget, higher underlying interest rates and a loss of international competitiveness out of the appreciating dollar and all for no gain.

The House is entitled to ask, as are businesses and households across the nation: where is the growth coming from over the next 12 months? It is not coming out of the interest rates; they are too high. It is not coming out of the appreciating Australian dollar because it is driving down competitiveness. It is not coming out of fiscal strategy because the budget is being contracted. The growth is coming from nowhere other than the prospect of the international business cycle. This is an historic change for the Australian economy because under the previous government we led the world, not only on the OECD growth table but in leading the world out of the bottom of each business cycle.

But what is happening under the Howard-Fischer government? We are falling off the back of international growth. We are falling off the back of the rest of the world in terms of the opportunities we could make of global markets—all pain and no gain, particularly in regard to living standards, the social wage cuts, the high underlying interest rates, the deregulation of the Australian labour market. What does it add up to? It adds up to a government that has no answers, a government that effectively wasted its years in opposition, ripped itself apart, Left versus Right, Howard versus Peacock. The things they believed in—they popped out in 1993; it was called Fightback. They have no mandate to do those things. They have no answers.

There is no answer in the twin deficits theory that the Treasurer subscribes to. That was tried at the end of the 1980s. It did not work. There is no answer in the competitive advantage theory. You can have all the micro‐economic reform and competition policy under the sun and it will not produce full employment in Australia because of regional and labour market imbalances. They have tried reduction of the welfare state in other parts of the world—the United Kingdom, throughout Western Europe, the United States. It just does not work. This is a government without answers, a government without any hope of improving living standards throughout the Australian community, a government which deserves to be thoroughly condemned by this House as it deals with the first supply bills of the Howard-Fischer administration. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Cook, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mutch, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come to this place from the mother of Australian parliaments, the New South Wales Legislative Council, to what I am constantly advised, particularly by those who have made it to this place, is the greatest chamber in Australian parliaments, the super league, if you like. Having departed from the Legislative Council with few regrets and high hopes, I certainly will not disagree with that assessment. I am not the first to make the transition from the place Henry Lawson described as `the fossil house'. Six others have come before me and two still sit in this chamber and have made firm and, I would add, distinguished imprints. In following the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin), I hope not to let the side down. Indeed, I feel quite at home here, where the standard of debate in my view approximates more the quality of debate in the Legislative Council as opposed to what passes for debate in the New South Wales lower house bearpit.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as I look across the chamber and see the rump of the Labor Party I sometimes wonder how debate will continue. It seems that even though they have been given a spanking by the Australian people they still like to lecture us. So please forgive me if tonight I use the lectern and I lecture you a little bit.

Looking at the shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), I sometimes suspect, because we did spend some time together at the college of law, that some people that know us both would fear for the safety and future of our country. But I do suspect also—and I hope sincerely—that the standard of both of our debates has improved since those carefree days.

Anyway, the standard in this place, which I think is very good, is a new phenomenon for which we should be indebted to the new House rules under the new enlightened management. And I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate our new Speaker on his well‐deserved elevation and his refreshing manner in the chair.

I note the words of sympathy by the Governor‐General, on the opening of parliament, for the victims, their families and friends, who have suffered and will continue to feel the pain for the rest of their lives as a result of the tragedy in Port Arthur. Among those who died was Zoe Hall, a young solicitor who was my constituent and with whom I played competition squash some years ago. Zoe was one of the most delightful people you could ever wish to meet. My sad condolences are extended to her family and many friends. They must be suffering a grief we can only begin to imagine.

A few weeks ago, when I took the oath of office, my family Bible was left behind in all the excitement. As I could not contemplate beginning my federal parliamentary career without the blessing of my ancestors, I have it here with me today. As is the custom, it lists the birth and death dates of Mutches. My great‐grandfather, William Murdoch Mutch, is listed there. He came to Australia from the Scottish highlands in the 1880s. Written also in the careful copperplate writing of my grandfather, Francis William Tait Mutch, a veteran of World War I, is the name of his mother, Sarah Davies Mutch, who, as a young woman, bravely journeyed across the seas on her own with four young boys, the progeny of William's first union, as well as her own babe in arms, Thomas Davies Mutch.

My political inspiration, Tom Mutch, was a minister in the Storey, Dooley and Lang governments. With Lang, he clashed bitterly, and was eventually a refugee from the hate‐filled factions of the New South Wales ALP. Things have not changed, as the shadow minister for competition policy, who knows all about cronyism and nepotism, would vouch for.

In 1934, Tom Mutch contested the federal seat of Werriwa as a UAP candidate. He narrowly failed, and I feel great pride in fulfilling, at last, this ancestral ambition to go federal. I also have a few inherited scores to settle with the ALP, who ratted on a good man when they abandoned Tom Mutch. On my mother's side, I am a seventh‐generation Australian, a descendant of Edward Whitton, an entrepreneurial convict who arrived aboard the Scarborough on 26 January 1788. I am also the descendant of Antonio Crameri, who left the beautiful Swiss valley of Poschiavo, over a century ago, to seek a new life in this wide, brown land.

BREAK.PARA: I make mention of these ancestors because they were immigrants and pioneers and, in remembering them, I am also reminded that we who have inherited the comparative luxuries of Australian citizenship should respect the determination and often the courage of those today who sometimes battle great odds, both physical and bureaucratic, to come to our country. We who have been born lucky can never afford to be complacent about our custodianship of this bountiful land.

I have travelled a bit—not nearly enough—across this great nation. As a modern man, I have seen Uluru, on a fine day, from a Qantas jet. I swear it pulsated like the great heart it resembles from above. I have swum among the warm coral waters of the Great Barrier Reef. I have been to the back of Bourke and seen Michael Cobb's monster sign by the Mitchell Highway. I have dodged kangaroos at Cunnamulla, perspired at Mungo and eaten pasta on Lygon Street. I have paid homage at the shrine of Peter Lalor, that great conservative rebel. What I have seen is a vast country with few people and unbounded potential.

Having had some experience in government and opposition, albeit as a back seat passenger wondering at times who is doing the driving, whose foot is on the accelerator, I have arrived at some simple pragmatic beliefs. I do not altogether subscribe to John Fahey's argument that vision is bulldust. But I have come to the conclusion that the four‐way test inscribed on Rotary gift pens is about as much philosophy as anyone needs.

We do need to have a dream, a plan for the future and a road map detailing the course we would like to take. We also have to have some idea about the mechanics of the vehicle that is supposed to get us there. I believe that members of this government and its ministry have a great deal of confidence and certainty about where we are going. My only caution is that I believe we should temper economic rationalism—which is good in a measured dose—with economic nationalism, which recognises the realities of a chaotic world.

My experience as a diligent government backbencher has left me with a repository of experience which I hope will be of some use to this government. Much of what I believe to have been useful was my work on parliamentary committees. I served a long time and attended, I think, a record number of meetings of the Regulation Review Committee, which did an enormous amount of work to unstrangle the people of New South Wales from bureaucratic red tape. As chairman of a backbench committee, I wrote reports on the security protection industry and the private investigations industry. I am very proud of my efforts, particularly in relation to the security protection committee; but, alas, the benefit of both these reports is yet to be utilised by the New South Wales government.

As chairman of, or participant in, many other committees, parliamentary backbench or party, I wrote or contributed to many reports. One of the most interesting I wrote was on the question of voluntary voting. In all of this, while some recommendations were implemented—usually by appropriation—I regret that all the enthusiastic work that goes into the nitty‐gritty of political and parliamentary life is often overlooked in the expedience of seeking and maintaining power for its own sake. I will therefore be one who is aware and vigilant of the need for governments to listen to the views of the party room, to seriously review the copious work done by backbenchers, and to take with a grain of salt the advice of those who spend their lives in plastic bubbles.

My personal beliefs have been shaped by a family upbringing where we moved to the Sutherland Shire in 1969 and built Kankinya Kindergarten, which is run today by my sister Annette. As a family business, it was all hands on deck. I used to clean and polish the floors at night. Later we built a caravan park at Heathcote, where we did all the landscaping ourselves. While my father worked in the textile industry to provide a stable base, it was my mother who established the family businesses. Now my father has dedicated his retirement so far to Heathcote Tourist Park. In fact, we have given him a rare day off today to be here in the gallery with my mother Shirley, my sisters Annette and Julie‐Anne, Aunty Pat, my cousin Maureen, my wife Jenni, and baby daughter Grace Elsie—Baby Gracie. It is easy to see that behind every hopeful man there are a dozen women propping him up.

I recall reading prior to my preselection an article describing the electorate of Cook as the perfect seat. It is bounded to the north by historic Botany Bay and the Georges River and, to the south, by the sparkling waters of the Hacking River, reflecting the beautiful gums of the Royal National Park. Our eastern boundary consists of the golden beaches of Bate Bay patrolled by world renowned surf lifesavers. Cook is also the home of ET and the mighty Sharks: no member could ask for more.

The electorate of Cook is also now a blue‐ribbon Liberal seat. Before the election, the margin in Cook was 3.5 per cent. It is now over 12 per cent, representing a massive swing of nearly nine per cent—extraordinary in a seat held by the coalition prior to the election. This spectacular result can be attributed to a number of factors, not least being the Howard factor, the Keating factor, and a positive local campaign which was run from my home in Sylvania Waters—our home, I should say. Our home became the focal point for all activities; our home number was posted on billboards all around the electorate. The atmosphere was festive, reflecting the palpable feeling all around that this time we would make a difference.

I do not want to reveal our trade secrets to the ALP, which obviously needs them, but they ran a negative and clueless campaign in Cook. In fact I am still waiting for my opponent to concede defeat; someone should tell him. But I can reveal that our engine was stoked by Beatrice Brown's jam tarts and chocolate cake, and by Ida and Bill Mowbray's delicious sandwiches, the piles of which were only kept in check by the voracious appetites of the Miranda‐Cook Young Liberals.

Day after day teams from the Woolooware branch, the Sylvania branch and the Cronulla women's branch came to our home to produce the material that was distributed by other teams on the weekend. There are so many to thank, but at the risk of leaving some out I would like to thank Norma and Bruce Scotland, Uncle Kevin and Adrienne Schreiber, John and Pauline Chad, Clive and Vicki Johnson, Marilyn and Tony Parkes, Dallas and Wade McInerney, Duncan Riley, Frank and Heather Newbery, Kathy and Anthony Clarke, Brenda Grosz, Barry and Katrina Munns, Les and Val Coy and Beth Adams—the A team—Nona Henderson, Thea Brown, Joan Walton, Marj Dyson, Myrt Little, Pam Lewis, Heather Parker, Julie and Noel Foldi, Pat Monk, Richard Cohen, Craig Farr, Natasha Johnson, Jack (General Patton) Hicks, Matt and Brook Daniel, Eric and Jan Dobbie, Charlie Francis and Jack Slattery, Roy Helm and Andrew Wilson—and those from far away, such as Robyn Young, Ann Youl and Rocky Wood, who all combined to send me to Canberra.

I leave till last my campaign manager and daughter's godfather, Malcolm Kerr MP, the member for Cronulla, who believes that the turning point in the campaign came when we changed the authorisation on pamphlets from M. Kerr to the unabridged Malcolm Kerr. How can I possibly disagree?

It was a massive effort, but the feedback was overwhelming. We received over 2,000 responses to our surveys. People were genuinely delighted that they had been given an opportunity to have their say, and I wrote back to them all. One regret I do have is that the Hon. Paul Keating has chosen not to be with us today because many voters asked me to convey personal messages to him.

I have come to this place with a shopping list of things I would like to raise early in the life of this parliament. For some years I have been interested in the issue of preserving the census on microfiche for the future use of medical, historical, demographic and cultural researchers. My good friend Nick Vine Hall, Australia's pre-eminent genealogist, who is in the gallery tonight, is leading a campaign of tens of thousands of Australians to review this act of historical vandalism. They know that by destroying raw census data we are failing to record the existence of every Australian for posterity. Other records provide only pieces of the mosaic that represents our population.

There is also to consider the important issue of medical research. Only yesterday a noted geneticist, Dr Max Nicholls of the University of New South Wales, said in frustration that `the census could provide an invaluable tool for future researchers into rare diseases and in forensic science, and it is an act of stupidity to destroy it'. I fully agree and have undertaken to pursue this issue in the party room.

The question of airport noise is one of major interest to many in my electorate. I would like to commend the decisive and professional approach of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) and his advisers in the implementation of our election policies and in the follow-up of issues raised. This has been in marked contrast to the fudging, dishonest approach of the previous government. For instance, I am pursuing the issue of aircraft on take-off turning east out to sea after passing Kurnell, therefore avoiding the Cronulla peninsula entirely. In a meeting organised by the minister, I was surprised to discover that this issue had not been properly assessed by the previous government. It will be done now and proper answers given, whether they be favourable or not.

People are looking for an honest approach and decisions—something not given to them before. The fact that the long‐suffering people of Kurnell voted for me in preference to my ALP opponent, giving me a 20 per cent swing and an historic victory at Kurnell, is an indication of the anger and frustration they felt towards the duplicity of the ALP. I may not be able to offer them salvation, but at least I visited them all and listened to their concerns.

The plight of small business is also a matter that received considerable attention in my campaign, and I am pleased to see that the government is moving quickly to focus on removing impediments imposed on small businesses, many of them by government, to free up this sector, the real engine room of our economy. I have convened a local small business task force, chaired by Frank Dowling of the Shire Monthly business monthly magazine, which has already met, to link in with the government's small business task force and report to the government on ideas and suggested reforms emanating from our local perspective.

Another thing I am doing to serve as a conduit between small business and government is to make myself available on Saturdays. I call it my Saturday surgery—with apologies to all the doctors who are with us tonight—so that people like small business proprietors who cannot see me during the week have this opportunity to bring their concerns to me. I am getting a great response and feel that these representations will drive much of my activity in this place.

An issue has been raised with me by Bernie Clarke of the Botany Bay Planning and Protection Council. He is concerned about the degradation of Towra Point, an area in my electorate with international significance for migratory birds. It could well be that a possible solution to wave erosion caused by the dredging of Port Botany and the construction of airport runways is the construction of a below surface breakwater to ameliorate the frequency of wave action. I have written to the minister seeking advice on whether a proposal might be submitted under our coast and clean seas initiative.

This project, along with many others I would like to advance in the environmental interests of my electorate, depends on the Telstra legislation achieving passage through the Senate unamended—a fact I am sure is appreciated by those many Democrat voters who gave me their preferences on 2 March. While my Labor opponent ran a negative campaign on two issues only—the sale of Telstra and the local environment—I was still able to attract 52 per cent of Democrat preferences.

PARA.BREAK: As I explore more of this place, I am often asked where I am from. When I mention Cook and Cronulla many comment on my predecessor, the Hon. Don Dobie MP. The word that springs to most people's lips is an old‐fashioned word—gentleman. Don Dobie has been a father to his electorate for over a quarter of a century. My own early political hopes were inspired by a trip to Parliament House, now Old Parliament House, where my class from St Patrick's College, Sutherland, was looked after by Don Dobie. I hope that after my sojourn in this place I will be re membered with nearly as much affection as Don Dobie. I wish him well in his retirement.

BREAK.PARA: I am continuing his tradition. Today I went and saw pupils from Kirrawee Public School who came to visit this great place. Most of the pupils who put their hands up when asked whether they would like to be Prime Minister were the girls. That is a sign of things to come.

In closing I would like to thank my family for continuing to be the most important influence on my career and, of course, my whole life. My wife, Jenni, and baby daughter, Grace, are a constant source of pride and joy to me. Some members might be aware that in my political career so far I have not avoided difficult issues and have been subjected to some bitter personal attacks and suffered some disgraceful public vilification and much harassment. That is well known to my friends Dr Max and Meg Wallace, who are also in the gallery tonight. Frankly, none of this has had the slightest effect on my morale because the people who matter to me are sitting up in the gallery, with me as always.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Cook (Mr Mutch) on his maiden speech and particularly commend him for the respect paid to the former member for Cook, Don Dobie, who gained the respect of all members on both sides of the parliament. Before speaking on the supply bills, I want to congratulate the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) on his election as Speaker of this House.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last parliament it was my pleasure to work with the honourable member for Casey, who was the deputy chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I am sure in expressing my delight and pleasure at his election to that position that I am also expressing the good wishes not only of the members of that committee but also the secretariat of that committee. To date, as Speaker, the honourable member for Casey has endeavoured to do his best to display fairness to both sides of the House and that comes as no surprise to members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. He has our best wishes and goodwill.

BREAK.PARA: I also take this opportunity to congratulate Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl on his appointment as Deputy Speaker. He was kind enough to refer to a friend of mine, Clarrie Millar, who is no longer a serving member of this House. Clarrie was a very colourful member. There is no point in my pointing out to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that we had the pleasure of serving together in the last parliament on the Procedure Committee. Some of the things we tried to tackle were not easy. The thing that stood out in my mind was always your reasonableness—that is, you are prepared to give things a go and take a reasonable approach in all the deliberations. This trait, in your new role as Deputy Speaker, will stand you in good stead, and I would like to personally extend my congratulations to you.

If I did not mention the election of the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins), I would draw some ire from this side of the House. While we express confidence in the roles that both you and the Speaker will fulfil, we have already had three years of Harry. I am sure that Harry, too, will continue to make the mark in this parliament that he did in the last parliament, but under different circumstances, and that he will enhance the top panel of three.

Because one of the supply bills is for the parliamentary departments, it gives me the opportunity to talk about what might constitute an independent Speaker and what might constitute better parliamentary behaviour. This is one of the aspects that the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) took into the last election, and presumably we will see it in practice.

In terms of the fairness of your good self and Mr Speaker, it is always the opposition which will support you most stridently in that regard because we are the ones who will be the great beneficiaries of any demonstration of fairness. In fact, it is usually governments of the day which try to restrict the opportunities of Speakers and Deputy Speakers in dispensing fairness. Mr Deputy Speaker, I say to you and to Mr Speaker that you can always look to this side of the House when you are valiantly trying to make fair rulings, and you will have our total support.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I thought I should draw to your attention something that has proved quite successful in the Senate in improving parliamentary performance. Admittedly, the government of the day was quite critical of the initiative but, as I say, it has stood the test of time. Speaker after Speaker has complained about the fact that they are restricted by current standing orders and that they can only apply them as they stand, notwithstanding the many points of order that are drawn to their attention.

However, the Senate has adopted a time limit of one minute on questions and four minutes on answers. As I said, initially the government of the day—which was our side—was quite hostile to the change, but it has improved performance immeasurably. It is interesting that the new government has gone along with that system. Maybe, if it tried to change it, it would not have the numbers, but there no longer seems to be an argument amongst senators about the time limitation on questions and answers in question time.

I would say that, after fairness, the preparedness of the government—after all, they have overwhelming numbers—to introduce such a limitation here in the House of Representatives is another test of improving parliamentary performance. Do it for a trial period, if you like, under standing orders. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have introduced standing orders for a session only, but I think it would be of great benefit to the government because it would discipline the ministers, as it has in the Senate.

I suppose I am a little old-fashioned, and I sincerely apologise for that. I have always described myself as a sort of traditional Labor man. One of the traditions in this place that I particularly enjoy, and I think I share this with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), is the ability of members of parliament to get up, other than in second reading debates or maiden speeches, and give a speech without reading it—none better than Clarrie Millar, whom we were talking about a little earlier. If it is not introduced or not enforced by the Speakers or Deputy Speakers, I would certainly encourage all the new members who have made their maiden speech thus far to get to the point where they can actually deliver a speech without reading it.

I can recount to the House the time when I was sitting on the government side listening to an opposition member and busily doing some work. I suddenly heard him intone that he took exception to government members laughing. I immediately spun around to see which government members were laughing. There was none, but it was written in the speech and he faithfully read it out.

The other issue I would like to raise in terms of lifting parliamentary standards and the role of parliament is one that my colleague the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) raised this morning—that is, amalgamating the parliamentary departments. It is an issue of great sadness to me that Mr Speaker has started off his reign by cutting back committee staff. There are some real savings to be made both in efficiency and in money by getting away from this anachronism of every department within the parliament having its own parliamentary head.

I am not trying to point score, but it is a matter of record that we have tried previously to make what is a sensible, micro-economic reform and productivity improvement but which has been hotly resisted by senators, in particular the now government senators. But, if we are asking the workers and industry out there in voter land to make sensible changes, sometimes we also have to demonstrate that we are part of that scene and act consistently.

Also in terms of accountability—and I mean no disrespect or impertinence to the Speaker, as I have already raised this with him—the House of Representatives department is the only department, whether it is a quango or it is a department of state, that does not have any scrutiny. I know that governments of the day or, more appropriately, the executives of the day delight in that particular situation. It is convenient to the Presiding Officers, because they are able to bury expenditure in the Department of the House of Representatives. But, again, particularly from a government that is hacking and slashing on expenditure, it seems to me to be quite a contradiction that the Department of the House of Representatives does not have a staffing and appropriations committee, which could basically assist Mr Speaker and the Deputy Speakers in the administration of that important department.

I have long been an advocate of the committee system, which was a very recent product in the 1980s, for the House of Representatives. Amongst a lot of benefits, I always think of it as the university of the parliament—that is, the opportunity to meet the best academics, the top public servants and people in private capacities. It is an opportunity to test and to weigh up your views. In the majority of cases, committee reports are bipartisan reports and they do not reflect lowest common denominator approaches. I think committees are absolutely great and they do this parliament great service.

But they are badly in need of reform. I have to say to honourable members that we are really setting a bad example. Firstly, we are maintaining too many committees. We are not reviewing the number of committees nor reviewing how effective it may be for a member of parliament to serve on—I think `to serve' is an overstatement—or at least to be a member of so many committees.

If I said to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it is really the members of parliament who serve on committees that make the difference, you of course, in your singular way, would pull me up and say that it is really the quality of the support staff and the tremendous effort they put in that makes us perhaps look better than we might otherwise be. It is an absolute tragedy that we are now going to prune committee staff, because we will limit the effectiveness of committees.

I would like to see fewer committees and more staff. An idea I floated in my own committee in the last parliament is that I think it would be absolutely fabulous if we could change the employment conditions for some positions and offer university graduates a traineeship, if you like, for one year where they would not be paid full Public Service salaries but they would get an opportunity to work with a parliamentary committee, with all the benefits that conferred. It would be on their curriculum vitae and they could then move on to a course position that they sought. If we were able to give young people that sort of opportunity and they were able to then move on, we would get the best of both worlds. We would have young brains and young enthusiasm. We would be giving them an opportunity and getting all the advantages from that. They in turn would be getting an opportunity to go into some very worthwhile careers.

When talking about having an independent Speaker or enhancing the role of parliament, these are the sorts of benchmarks I think we should set and against which people could judge, perhaps whenever we again go to the polls, how successful Mr Speaker and his deputies have been and how successful the Prime Minister has been. From a very sincere point of view, I wish them well. I would be absolutely delighted if I were to learn very shortly that all of them were to be implemented. I fear that that will not be so.

I have a few minutes to talk about the Supply Bill (No. 2), which allocates $1.720 billion. Again, I want to return to a point that I made in an earlier speech: unfortunately, members of parliament are not held in high esteem, in particular when we are seen to be duplicitous, cynical or breaking promises. I think it is unfortunate that the Prime Minister has based much of his approach, in terms of slashing and hacking the expenditure, on the allegation of a black hole of $8 billion.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that you, having listened to so many debates and contributions from different members, would know that that $8 billion represents an estimate by Treasury about how the economy is likely to be, rather than an actual overspend or overdraft. As I said a little earlier, it is not as though Mr Howard has a note from the Governor of the Reserve Bank saying, `Dear Prime Minister, I regret to advise you that you have spent $8 billion more than you have.' These are projections; that is what he is talking about.

Indeed, it ill‐becomes the Prime Minister to start lecturing and hectoring the opposition when he was advised by Treasury when he was the Treasurer that there was a $9.6 billion overspend—not an estimate but actual—and he chose during an election to keep that quiet. Translated into today's dollars, that $9.6 billion is not an $8 billion overspend or black hole. It is something like $25 billion in 1996 dollars.

The thing that we on this side of the House find so difficult is that the Prime Minister will not come clean and table the Treasury or Department of Finance advice about what the costings of his election promises were. After all, he said he would introduce a charter of budget honesty. If we asked people whether they are in favour of a charter of budget honesty, of course they would say yes. Do they want members of parliament, Prime Ministers and Treasurers to act honestly? Of course they would say yes. Why, then, do you disappoint those who would support you by not acting consistently, by not tabling that information? Is it true that that estimate of election promises is in fact $4 billion? I believe it is. There is one way it can be settled.

Lastly, I would like to say that there has been a lot of speculation about the budget and how many public servants are going to lose their jobs. I know that, out in voter land, having a go at public servants is pretty good fun, particularly if you can identify them as being Canberra public servants. But let me say that one in five public servants employed on the Commonwealth payroll actually lives and works in Canberra. Four out of five work in electorates like yours, Mr Deputy Speaker, like mine, and like that of the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans), the shadow minister at the table. So when we say we are going to hack and slash public servants, what we are really saying is that we are going to have fewer public servants to do the same jobs that they were doing in our own electorates.

I expressed a concern to the head of the Prime Minister's department, when we were on the expenditure committee, that you can get more and more efficient public service activity. But, if you are not careful, you lose sight of what the actual job is that you are trying to do. Take someone, for example, trying to ring a Department of Social Security office. You have to go through a telephone queuing system, you have to be competently able to identify what it is that you want, but you actually cannot ring your local office any more. I think that is sad.

If there is one thing Australians ought to have as a fundamental right, it is to be able to talk to the decision maker in the public service face‐to‐face—or at least on a telephone. You settle far more problems better in that way than you do through these anonymous queuing systems. Not everyone is functionally literate and, particularly in my electorate, old people and people who are functionally illiterate have great difficulty with some of the technological innovations. We should understand the disadvantages that we are placing them under.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to finish my address as I began it. I would like to sincerely congratulate you on your elevation, and also Mr Speaker. It is said that members of parliament come into this place with a prime ministerial baton in their knapsacks. A lot of us would say the highest honour any member of parliament can have is to serve as Speaker or Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Pertinent to the supply bills we are debating tonight is getting our current account back in order. Earlier today, in a speech I made which was cut short, I referred to my dismay at the fact that Premier Carr had put the kybosh, if you like, on a potential goldmine in the south of my electorate, on the border between my electorate and the electorate of the member for Riverina (Mr Hicks), at Lake Cowal. If the mine was allowed to go ahead it would return $1,200 million in export earnings to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the Premier has stopped that mine for all the wrong reasons. Before he did so he set up a commission of inquiry into the possibility of letting that mine go ahead. That commission called for submissions and 118 came in—most of which, I might add, were in favour of the mine. The Premier and his relevant minister, Craig Knowles—the Minister for Urban Affairs and Planning, and Minister for Housing—set up the commission.
