They appointed the commissioners, as is their right, and they set the terms of reference for the inquiry.

They appointed the highest people possible for that inquiry, namely, the Chairman of the Office of the Commissioners of Inquiry for Environment and Planning, Mr William Simpson, and the Deputy Chairman, Mr Kevin Cleland. So they had top people for that inquiry who, when they sent their 120‐page report to the Premier, wrote a covering letter of three paragraphs. I will just read the last paragraph which says:

Our report canvasses the various conservation, environmental, developmental and social issues brought before the Commission of Inquiry. We have weighed and balanced these aspects of the proposed development and are satisfied,—
I repeat that, `are satisfied'—
subject to compliance with the strict conditions we recommend, that conservation and environmental considerations do not preclude you granting consent to the Lake Cowal Gold Project.
There it is. I cannot go through the whole 120 pages but if we turn to the executive summary that they put before the Premier, it is interesting to read out a few paragraphs:
Submissions were received from 118 parties. The Department of Mineral Resources and the Bland Shire Council—
that is based on West Wyalong in New South Wales—

strongly support the proposal as do many of the businesses in West Wyalong. The Australian Heritage Commission, Department of Urban Affairs and Planning, the Environmental Protection Authority and the Department of Land and Water Conservation note the potential for ecological impacts but do not object subject to strict conditions of consent . . . Government agencies generally recognise the local economic and social importance of the development. The majority of local landholders support the development provided their amenity and livelihood is protected.
In the next paragraph they say:
In our assessment we have recognised that the conservation significance of Lake Cowal must not be underestimated or compromised.

On weighing and balancing the scientific and technical evidence before the Inquiry we are satisfied that the impact of the Lake Cowal Gold Project on the environment of Lake Cowal will be low and will not be ecologically significant in the short or long term. The contrary views of some parties are not supported by the evidence.

Of the 118 submissions, 75 were in favour, and others from the National Parks and Wildlife Service and some of the green groups were against but, as the commission of inquiry clearly says, the contrary views of some parties are not supported by the evidence. They summed up by saying:

We have concluded that a maximum cyanide level of 50 mg/L CN(WAD) as proposed by the Company should apply to the tailings discharge. We also recognise the need for the conservation of biodiversity and ecological integrity to be assured at Lake Cowal. Consequently, we recommend that as well as the extensive monitoring proposed by the conditions of consent the Company fully fund a waterbird conservation program to be undertaken jointly with the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

We are satisfied that the Lake Cowal Gold Project will bring positive economic and social benefits to Bland Shire and the State and that it will not compromise the recognised national and international conservation values of Lake Cowal in the short or long term, subject to the conditions of consent we recommend to control and mitigate potential environmental impacts.

There it is, a very clear recommendation indeed to go ahead with this goldmine that would have created 180 jobs directly with an average wage for the workers in this country of $60,000 each per year. The Premier came out at the end of one 60 Minutes program and knocked it on the head and did not tell the mining company, North Ltd, until three days later that this mining project, which would have been the largest goldmine in New South Wales bringing $1,200 million of desperately needed export income to this country, had been rejected. The Premier based that on a 4½‐page report that was written by a Gabrielle Kibble, the Director‐General of the Department of Urban Affairs and Planning.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very bright lady.
—Interestingly enough, she is a daughter, I believe, of the late Sir John Kerr. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: While many of the environmental risks of a gold mine proposal can be adequately monitored and safeguarded, any risk in the Lake Cowal environment may not be tolerated given the significance (national and international) of the wetland.
She goes on to say in this report:

BREAK.PARA: . . . risks cannot be totally eliminated unless mining does not place.

In other words, if an activity of mining takes place at Lake Cowal there will be some risk, no matter how small, and that is not acceptable. She has brought a new standard into mining in this country which must mean that because any mining encompasses some risk, there is to be no mining in Australia. That is the logical extrapolation of what this lady has said. It has set an incredible standard in this country. I have a letter from the Executive Director of the Minerals Councils of Australia, David Buckingham. He says:
Indeed, if the NSW Government was to apply the same criterion of no environmental impact, it would, by denying all development options, effectively shut down the State.

One of the things that Gabrielle Kibble raises in her 4½‐page letter is blasting. She says that blasting and associated vibrations will have an impact on bird breeding at Lake Cowal. But the birds that breed there are five kilometres away from where this development is proposed. What are the vibrations going to be like five kilometres away from the blast?

Last weekend I was at Peak Hill where we have just opened a new goldmine. It is half a kilometre from the central business district of the town and they blast at Peak Hill every day. The blast lasts for one second and the vibrations at the nearest house, which is only 200 or 300 metres away from the blast, are of the order of one millimetre and last for one second. That is acceptable to the human beings who live there. While the blasting is going on, the birds which have got used to it fly around and do not take much notice of it. At Lake Cowal the birds are five kilometres away, yet the vibrations on the ecosystems of Lake Cowal are apparently going to adversely affect the breeding of the birds there.

It is this sort of nonsense that has shut down a $1,200 million project. We must be the richest country in the world if we can afford, based on this sort of nonsense, to turn away $1,200 million. I will just read from a report by an eminent ornithologist and wetlander, Dr Peter Fullagher, as reported in the Forbes Advocate in my electorate on 23 April. He said:

The development of the proposed goldmine at Lake Cowal is not an impediment to the lake being listed as a Ramsar wetland in the broadest technical sense. The minor intrusion of this mine well away from the waterbird habitat would not preclude its listing and it indicates a clear misunderstanding of the Ramsar convention principles to argue that the proposed mine would preclude the wetland being listed.
He goes on to say:

Evidence was presented to the independent commission of inquiry which establishes that the proposed goldmine is unlikely to affect the special ecological values of Lake Cowal in either the short or long term. Environmental changes have occurred and are continuing to occur in and around Lake Cowal but still it retains its high conservation and ecological value.

No doubt he was referring to incidences like the 30 per cent of the time when the lake is totally dry and is farmed by farmers driving their tractors around the paddock. This would make more noise over a longer period of time than blasting—of course, driving a tractor around lasts longer than one second a day—and has had little or no impact on the birds breeding there.

I hope that sense will prevail and the Premier will look at these things again and take into account the fact that, if North Ltd is allowed to go ahead and develop their goldmine, they are prepared to spend $2 million on doing something about the rising water tables which are a problem because the water carries a lot of salt. Most of the experts say that within 10 or 20 years we will have a severe salinity problem in Lake Cowal. That, more than anything else, will destroy the lake as a bird breeding habitat. I hope the Premier will say that those benefits more than outweigh the detriment that Gabrielle Kibble refers to.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Just when I thought I could not hear of anything more vacant‐minded than the government's planned cuts to the Australian Public Service, along comes Senator Vanstone with her blueprint now to wipe away some 12 per cent, or over $500 million, of Commonwealth funding to our universities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot understand the thought processes going on inside the minds of the government's razor gang if these cuts are in fact to be undertaken. We are not talking about some stray $500 million here—a loose half a billion dollars tucked beneath some vice‐chancellor's academic gown. Let me make very clear to the members on the government benches in this House what we are really dealing with. I will speak slowly so that it will sink in.

I am really concerned that cutting funding to the extent now being mooted will cripple our universities irrevocably. Our students' education will suffer appallingly. The higher education industry, of which Australia is so justifiably proud, will fall into a penniless heap. Australian businesses and employers will no longer be able to bank on the fruits of a highly skilled work force—our universities will no longer produce enough people with the required skills to satisfy demand. The high international reputation of our universities will be tarnished forever.

Am I really getting through to the government benches? Do they really know what it is all about, Mr Speaker? Perhaps if I put it another way. I know that some of the government's members have university aged children of their own. Think of the extent to which they too will suffer. Think of when they come home and say, `I couldn't get into my lecture today because all the seats and the aisles of the theatre were full of students,' or `I can't study for my exam because all the books in the library's special reserve have been taken.' Think of how they will react when you do your little dance and glibly tell them to `send the bill to Beazley'.

A recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald by the Vice‐Chancellor of the University of New South Wales, Professor John Niland, who I understand is a great friend of the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey), may help put some government members further in the picture. Professor Niland made the point that higher education exports now generate more than $1.3 billion a year—comparable to our wheat exports which earn Australia $1.5 billion, and iron and steel which pulls in $1.4 billion.
According to Professor Niland, a 10 per cent cut in funding—not 12 per cent but 10 per cent—would reduce these exports by over $130 million. He continued:

Export earnings are passed on as increased spending and produce additional ripple effects. Regional economists estimate this multiplier to be approximately two. So that an initial fall in exports . . . of $130 million will translate into a reduction of national income of about $260 million. That corresponds to some 11,000 jobs and a loss in government tax revenue of around $55 million.

Surely when you look at figures like these, the government members opposite can see that cuts in this area will not save us anything—they will cost us dearly in monetary and in social terms. Cuts on such a scale are in fact self‐defeating.

Take a look at how many overseas students Australian universities cater for today. Think of the $1.8 billion they bring to Australia. Think of how the quality of their education will suffer and how it will affect our ability to market Australia's higher education system overseas.

Really, do the `business gurus' opposite realise there are plenty of eager tertiary institutions in the UK, Canada and the US which are just itching to get a slice of the lucrative international education trade which Australia currently enjoys?

Members should be aware that, as with the Public Service, the previous Labor government eliminated waste and inefficiency in higher education to Jack Sprat proportions. Commonwealth funding per student has fallen by 9.3 per cent in real terms over the past 12 years—there is no fat left from which to carve.

The coalition even criticised us for our reduction in funding. In its own policy statement it said that Labor's `significant per capita reduction of Commonwealth funds has had a detrimental effect on quality'. And they now want to cut $500 million more. From your own logic, can I ask the members opposite me what they think this will achieve.

Senator Vanstone says that our universities should `sensibly realise the problem we are in, and sensibly work out how to get out of it'. I put it to her that cutting funding by 12 per cent does not make sense; it is in fact illogical in the extreme.

I feel closer to my own electorate and the University of Western Sydney. We worked very hard over many years to get that up and running. It is a fine institute and it too will be affected by these cuts.
The minister would do well to remember the recent point made by Professor Michael Osborne, Vice-Chancellor of La Trobe University. He said:
Education is not cheap. It never has been cheap and if it is made cheap it will render our country cheap.
If their current mind-set is anything to go by, I fear that Senator Vanstone and her colleagues will soon be governing a nation cheapened beyond repair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to mention a couple of examples of the difficulties that fathers are facing in relation both to child support and to access, examples that have come to my office recently. The first case involves a father who came to me. He has not seen his daughter for something like 18 months. He showed me a history of the accounts that he has had to pay to solicitors over a period of some five or six years. This chap is a storeman. He has outlaid something like $12,000 on attempts he has made to get access to his daughter. He gets an order for access, he gets orders of enforcement. The orders subsist for something like five months. They are complied with. At the end of that time they are then breached and he has to go back to court. This chap is an ordinary worker, he has outlaid something like $12,000 and he has not seen his daughter for something like 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: But what happens? He has the Child Support Agency on his back constantly. Having outlaid all of that money and having not had the proper support from the court structure to enforce those orders, he has the other arm of the state after him for child support in those circumstances. That cannot be right, and something has to be done about it.

In the other case, a gentleman came to my office and was shaking all over. I asked him what was the matter. He said: `I am getting more access to my children than the order specifies, so I sought a variation with the Child Support Agency in relation to maintenance.' The application for a variation was sent to his former wife. No response was made. So the variation was made. But about a month or so later, when the former wife responded to the variation, he found himself with an accumulated assessment of the order of $6,000. He was horrified at this. When he made some inquiries into it he found that his former wife did nothing other than supply a copy of the access order. In other words, the access order was relied on by the Child Support Agency to establish the fact of access. That is, the Child Support Agency accepted that the order was evidence of the access when in actual fact the real access that he was exercising was much greater.

So there we have two examples of a system that is really out of control. I recall that when I was in practice at the bar, when an order was breached in relation to access in relation to an ex-nuptial child, an application for enforcement was taken to the Supreme Court. The judge said to the respondent: `I propose to give your former partner access this weekend. What do you say to that?' She said no. He replied by ordering that a writ of attachment be issued forthwith. That meant that by Friday evening of that night that person was in prison.

On Monday the judge phoned me and said: `I want that matter relisted.' She was brought up before the court. He said to her: `Do you intend to let your former partner have access to that child?' She said yes. She was immediately discharged and not another thing was ever done in relation to that matter. In other words, as I understand it, access was exercised properly and throughout. But the Family Court seems to be unable to come to terms with the fact that the power always lies in the person in control of the children. The non-custodial parent never has that power.

BREAK.PARA: The Family Court seems unable to recognise that and unable to enforce its orders. It has to be recognised that the court will never have respect in the community unless it enforces its orders properly and thoroughly. It ought to take the example that I outlined earlier of Mr Justice Connolly in the Supreme Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adams, Dick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke the week before last in the House about the terrible massacre at Port Arthur. As a result, some of the members of the House have approached me about how to make a contribution to the Port Arthur Victims Appeal. I have made some inquiries about the appeal, and I thought I would let the House know who will benefit and how the appeal will be conducted. The appeal has been established to provide financial support to the victims, the families of victims and the local community of Port Arthur.

SPEECH.PARA: Can you imagine what it is like to be suddenly without your wife, your husband or your child? They play a huge part in your life, and suddenly they are there no more. Clothes still need to be washed, lawns still need to be mowed and wood still needs to be cut. That simple support system that we all need and that we have all developed has suddenly disappeared. You cannot replace it, but you need to do something. What if you yourself had lost a hand or had been injured and temporarily incapacitated? You would need help.

A management committee has been established to distribute the appeal funds based on a specific set of principles and guidelines and will consist of three qualified people who will be appointed by the Governor‐in‐Council. Beneficiaries of the fund will be the immediate families of the deceased victims, the injured and their immediate families, witnesses of the incident and their immediate families, the Port Arthur community and any other person the committee believes needs help.

The funds will be used for financial assistance for such things as immediate emergency costs arising from the incident such as funerals, transport costs of the deceased and the immediate families of interstate and overseas victims and the victims' families visiting the site. Also included are costs arising as a consequence of the incident which are not recoverable from elsewhere such as counselling for immediate families of overseas victims, any gaps or shortfalls in medical costs of injured victims, uninsured property that was destroyed or damaged, costs associated with personal and family hardship resulting from the incident and other associated costs which are not covered by existing government programs.

If the appeal funds permit, the committee may establish a trust fund to support dependants, whether they be children, spouses, other relatives or other dependants of the victims. It may also consider the allocation of funds towards research into the prevention and management of and recovery from major traumatic incidents and provide for the establishment of a permanent memorial.

The appeal fund, as at 20 May, stands at over $2 million. There are many organisations that have responded in kind, whether it be additional assistance to the Tasman Council or the provision of accommodation and food for families of victims. If anyone would like to have further information about the committee overseeing the appeal or any more details, I have them in my office.

People wishing to make a donation can do so through any Commonwealth Bank branch throughout the country or, if they wish, I can collect any crossed cheques made payable to the `Port Arthur Victims Appeal Account' and take them personally to the Tasmanian government on their behalf.

Also this week I have organised to have 20,000 more Port Arthur appeal stickers to be printed. This has been made possible by Tasmanian federal members of parliament from all political persuasions putting in a donation. More of these excellent locally designed stickers can now be circulated around Tasmania and the mainland which can result in raising another $40,000 towards the appeal.

I thank all my Tasmanian colleagues for their help and enthusiasm for this project. I thank all those who have expressed their condolences and those who have offered their help. I know the Tasman community is grateful for the concern shown by so many people. The families and friends of the victims and all those who have been involved in helping them will gain a little comfort from the generosity of our nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the three or four sentences I spoke earlier today in support of the private member's motion of the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans). He and I had raised this issue of learning difficulties long before it was publicised quite widely in the Bulletin 's cover story last week called `Learning the hard way'.

SPEECH.PARA: I made reference to learning disabilities in my first speech and drew a connection between it and a young person's future prospects in life. While the member for Cowan and I share a belief that reliable research into learning disabilities is sadly lacking, I am advised by a constituent that US research suggests that as many as one in five unemployed youth academically and socially underperform because of a learning disability. These kids fail to fulfil their potential because their information processing, cognitive or sensory dysfunction is not addressed by the mainstream learning environment.

Learning disabilities are clearly a significant challenge for government, policy makers and parents, as well as the students themselves. When kids hit hurdles early in life, surely it is our duty to help to show them the way over or around or to guide them to achieve excellence in another field rather than risking them not participating at all.

My awareness of the plight of learning disabled kids was heightened by Ms Janette Lee and her son Trevor. Ms Lee is a resident of Langwarrin in Dunkley by the bay, and is coordinator of the local learning disabilities network. The network aims to improve the lives of children with learning disabilities. The group works towards raising the awareness of issues relating to learning disabilities, providing support and information and encouraging the full participation of children with learning difficulties, LD, in educational and recreational opportunities. The group sees its primary role as an educative one: to raise family, community and professional awareness of learning disabilities. I am sure that the group would be very pleased to see the discussion that we have had in this place today about the subject.

While the states have primary constitutional responsibility for schools and special education, the Commonwealth continues to play a funding and leadership role. Under the national equity program for schools, the Commonwealth has a special education component which is described as a supplementary program only. It is unusual, to say the least, that this program specifically excludes the funding of students with learning disabilities. The Commonwealth provides funding of about $70 per head to help with the provision of services for students with disabilities, except for those primary and secondary students who have a learning difficulty. Kids with a learning disability miss out. Some states simply assume that the schools are addressing this issue through global funding allocations. The reality for one of my constituents is that she and her son have had to travel great distances in search of a school that has a supportive teaching practice and the educational environment to bring out the best in a student with a learning disability.

I hear the arguments that governments always have to draw a line in the sand somewhere, but it is clear to me that the problem of learning disabilities is increasingly becoming a mainstream issue and that our predecessors buried their heads in the sand over this issue. It is intriguing that, while learning disabilities are specifically excluded from the special education program funding available to primary and secondary schools, the issue is on the agenda of many universities and TAFE colleges. For example, assessment guidelines accommodate learning disabilities and take account of other aspects of educational achievement.

Because of the apparent correlation between students with learning disabilities in their formative years and academic and social underperformance in later years and into adulthood, I support the member for Cowan's call for a parliamentary inquiry. The increasing emphasis on investing in the early intervention and remedial action for literacy and numeracy underperformance is widely endorsed. We need to extend this approach to learning disabilities more generally via revised government policy settings.

We cannot let our kids down because, when it comes to letting them down today on learning disabilities, too many young people will end up being down on themselves for the rest of their lives. If children are inattentive, overly impulsive or hyperactive, some people might at first glance dismiss this behaviour as attention seeking. The National Health and Medical Research Council's 1990 report suggests that between 10 and 16 per cent of our children have learning disabilities. The problem cannot simply be dismissed as a ploy by children to attract attention. We need to be reliable and clear in diagnosis, creative about teaching practices, encouraging in the learning environment and able to inform parents and friends about appropriate supportive behaviour.
A parliamentary inquiry would be a constructive step in transforming community concern into improved government policy and better life outcomes for a significant group of people in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to draw the attention of the House to one specific issue of concern as it relates to the planning of roads in Cranbourne North—an important growth area within my electorate of Isaacs and located within the city of Casey, which is perhaps the fastest growing municipality in Australia and, indeed, firmly entrenched within the south‐eastern growth corridor, as it is euphemistically known. The city of Casey was, in fact, formerly known as the shire of Cranbourne prior to the amalgamation of municipalities in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: This fast rate of growth in the city of Casey imposes significant responsibilities on planners to develop communities which meet the long-term interests and needs of residents. Of course, such planning must involve residents at the consultative level. I am concerned that in this particular instance this may not have been the case.

In 1990, by way of some history, the then Victorian state government developed broad brush plans for proposed roads within the south-eastern growth area—and, specifically, within the area of Cranbourne North. Within these broad brush plans, there were no roads specifically named or designated, except to say that some, for example, were deemed to be subarterial, as in the specific instance of what is known currently as Golf Links Drive—a road to which I will turn shortly.

Subsequently, in 1993 and 1994, home owners purchased homes at what one might call top dollar. These homes backed onto a golf course and undeveloped rural land and were purchased at top dollar for the privilege of the serenity and solitude that such an urban location bestowed. These homes were purchased largely through the agency of L. J. Hooker Pty Ltd.

It has been suggested now by the city of Casey, formerly the shire of Cranbourne, that in November 1993 the shire of Cranbourne circulated a notice to all residents who bought homes which backed onto the golf course and rural land. That notice advised that objections in regard to planning amendment L100 were sought. Planning amendment L100 proposed the construction of what ultimately will become a four-lane major arterial road adjacent to the quiet golf course and certainly running through the rural land which abuts the back fences of the residences in question.

No resident, at a public meeting I attended recently, attested to ever having received a notice offering the opportunity for objections to be submitted; and, indeed, no resident has ever personally approached me with the view that they had received any such notice. The first that residents became aware of this proposed road was in 1995 when they read about it in the Melbourne street directory.

Interestingly perhaps, L. J. Hooker has since circulated these residents with a newsletter asking whether or not they want their homes to be sold. I believe that residents whose homes back onto the golf course and the proposed road, who paid top dollar for the peace and quiet of the adjacent undeveloped land and who, in all likelihood, were not afforded the opportunity to object should not have a major road intrude into their neighbourhood, particularly given its detrimental impact on both the quality of life and property values in the area.

In light of the above, I call on the city of Casey to initiate an amendment to the local planning scheme to downgrade the status of the proposed Golf Links Drive or, alternatively, purchase vacant land to the north of the area in question which is currently set aside for a quarry and re‐route this road to allow residents who were probably not afforded the opportunity to object the right to live the quality lives they sought by purchasing land in this particular area in the first instance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dondas, Nick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak about the north‐south railway. Over the years there has been much discussion regarding the rail link continuation from South Australia via Alice Springs to Darwin. The railway would link the rest of Australia to the Northern Territory. It has been talked about for 86 years. The logic of the line is compelling, but until now construction proposals have not been so convincing.

SPEECH.PARA: The freight levels are the single most important factor in determining the right time to build the railway. Since the Wran report, the ABS has significantly increased its estimates of domestic freight. Symonds Henderson has just completed a survey which shows the freight task to be even higher—1.787 million tonnes carried an average of 1,649 kilometres.

This railway project is very important for the Australian community. It is not just a railway for the Northern Territory; it is a railway for the whole of the Australian community. It is not a pipe dream. I believe the information we now have on this project is convincing. I have a letter, which I will read into Hansard, from the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) to the Minister for the Railway in the Northern Territory, Barry Coulter. The letter states:
Dear Minister,
Thank for your letter of 1 April 1996 concerning the proposed Alice Springs‐Darwin railway. I look forward to our meeting on 2 May 1996 to discuss this matter further.
I can confirm that the Government believes that the private sector is the key to the construction and operation of this new line and its policy is designed to facilitate a private sector investor.

The Government is prepared to provide the existing Tarcoola‐Alice Springs line free to a private sector developer prepared to build and operate an Alice Springs‐Darwin railway. To assist in this process, survey of the proposed track between Alice Springs and Darwin will be completed.

In relation to taxation issue, I note that taxation incentives for investment in rail transport facilities are available to eligible projects through infrastructure borrowings. Any other tax issues raised with the Government would be a matter for further consideration.

The letter is signed by the minister. Not only is the Alice Springs to Tarcoola link important but the funding commitments by the South Australian and Northern Territory governments are also important. The South Australian government has said that it is prepared to put $100 million into this venture. The Northern Territory government is also prepared to put in funds. The Northern Territory government has spent some $75 million on upgrading the port facilities in Darwin. The finalisation of the corridor is also a very important factor.

I am pleased to see in the minister's letter that the government is going to finalise this corridor. The government has been talking to people in Korea and the United States and is hopeful that a financial package will be brought before the government for consideration. The railway does have a lot of community support. A survey on this matter was recently carried out in the Northern Territory. Over 80 per cent of territorians support the construction of the rail link from Alice Springs to Darwin.

A very important factor that has been overlooked in previous discussions in regard to railway is the environment. I am led to believe that the railway will stop the emission of 100,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per annum and there will be a saving of some 2,000 million litres of fuel over a 50‐year period. We have to also take the defence factor into consideration. In my maiden speech, I made mention of the defence facilities in the Northern Territory. I also mentioned the fact that in 1995‐96 spending by the defence department exceeded some $54 million. I am aware that the defence department does support railway infrastructure being completed between Alice Springs and Darwin.

We also need to consider the land bridge concept whereby cargo can be discharged in Darwin and freighted south to capital cities much quicker by rail than by sea. If cargo had to go from somewhere in the Timor Sea to Brisbane, Melbourne or Sydney there would be savings of many days if it was discharged in Darwin and freighted by rail rather than by sea. The other important factor is that it will help expand the mining industry in the Northern Territory. In my maiden speech, I also referred to the fact that some 40 per cent of Australia's wealth is produced in the northern part of Australia. We believe that the rail link will certainly engender a lot more interest in the development of the mining industry. (Time expired)
